Gen. Grant had another good day yesterday. It was passed much as he had passed Wednesday, rising early, dozing during the morning, riding in the afternoon, and submitting to an examination as a witness in the Fish case, before the hour for dinner.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26.--During the present session of the General Assembly of the State there have been many disgraceful scenes, but this afternoon the climax was reached, and, whatever may follow, it is not likely that the House of Representatives will ever be more thoroughly disgraced than it was to-day.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 27.--James Hubbartt, living a few miles north of the city, celebrated his one hundredth birthday to-day. He was born in Delaware March 27, 1785.

READING, Penn., March 30.--Ex-County Treasurer Stephen W. Boltz, of Lebanon, who has just made an assignment, was short in his accounts $9,000. CLEVELAND, March 30.--W.D. Hoyt, a young married man, saw a tramp prowling around his residence last evening and shot him, killing him instantly. The body was taken to the Morgue and to-day identified as that of Charles Stanley, a colored man about 30 years of age, who had a mania for looking into windows to see ladies at their toilet. Hoyt was held in $5,000 bail to answer to a charge of manslaughter.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 30.--Near the village of Van Ettenville, in this county, this morning, a team ran away with a wagon containing Elijah Ruger, a prominent citizen; Mrs. Julia Wheeler, and John Hardy. ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 30.-- The seal fishery is proving a great success. St. John, the chief representative of aquatic sports in this city, challenges Beach, who defeated Hanlan in Australia on Saturday, to row Jake Gandaur, of this city, for $5,000 a side and the championship of the world, the race to take place in the United States and St. John to allow Beach $500 for expenses.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 30.-- Legal proceedings were to-day instituted by John Whitehead, of South River, N.J., to recover $5,000 from J. Bayard Kirkpatrick, of this city. Last Fall Kirkpatrick acted as stakeholder in a bet in which Whitehead backed Blaine for $5,000, and William R. Jomee Cleveland for $2,000. Upon Cleveland's election the stakes were paid to Joinee, hence the suit by Whitehead.

CLEEVELAND, Ohio, March 30.--Sylvester J. Osborne, the skating "professor" who eloped with Miss Rebecca Kearsley, the Bucyrus (Ohio) heiress, some time ago, was sentenced at Upper Sandusky, Ohio, to-day to three years in the penitentiary for bigamy. He pleaded guilty.

HAVANA, March 26.--On the 31st of this month $1,500,000 in bank bills of the war issue will have been burned according to the law of amortization. No improvement, however, in the value of paper money has occurred. Spanish gold is now quoted at 2.33 , while at the corresponding time last year it was quoted at 2.36.

CHICAGO, March 31.--The leading produce markets were again quiet to-day, and at a lower range of prices. British Consols were quoted higher, and the weather here was Springlike, it being the first warm day of the season. The foreign advices were generally tending downward, and there was no home support except in the case of Wheat.

BATAVIA, N.Y., April 2.--Darius Scott Spring is a rich farmer in the town of Alexaner. His first wife died six years ago, and he married his second wife in Kansas in 1880. Estella was the eldest and was away attending school.

One must read between and beyond the lines of yesterday's official reports to get an idea of Gen. Grant's condition. As has been often said, the doctors omit reference to matters of infinitely greater interest to the lay reader than what they report. Saturday night was one of the worst the General has had. He slept but two hours.

Valentine Rutzel, a German musician 42 years of age, committed suicide yesterday by cutting his throat with a razor in his apartments at No. 329 East Eighth-street. He was a widower and lived with his three children-Ida, age 18; Andrew, ago 16, and Josephine, age 14 years. His wife died on the 7th of February from self-inflicted malpractice.

--The May Century will not be published until May. This is the beginning of an important change which the publishers have long had in contemplation. Hereafter all numbers will appear on the first day of the month, instead of 10 or 15 days earlier, as has been the case. Other magazines may see fit to follow this example.

WASHINGTON, April 27.--Judge Upton, Second Controller of the Treasury, has made a ruling that officers of the army who held brevet rank at the time of service in the Mexican war are entitled to three months' extra pay, allowed by Congress for such service, according to the brevet rank held by them at the close of their service.

PITTSBURG, April 27.--The meeting of the American Baseball Association in this city to-day was a lively affair from beginning to end. Representatives from all the clubs arrived several hours in advance of the time set for the meeting, all talked war to the knife, and the preliminary comparison of notes seemed to make every man more determined. The meeting began at noon, and an adjournment was not had until 8 o'clock.

LONDON, April 28.--The House of Commons on Monday evening had gone into Committee of Supply after having, at the Prime Minister's request, rejected, by a vote of 229 to 186, the motion made by the Opposition to separate the vote of credit. This motion called for a division into a vote of credit for the expenses of the Soudan enterprise and another for "the special preparations account."

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 28.--A special dispatch to the Pioneer Press from Clark's Crossing says there was no fighting yesterday. Gen. Middleton intended to advance to-day. It was stated yesterday by several persons interested in the matter that the lease will probably be signed in Boston to-day or to-morrow.

There is not the least doubt that when Mr. HAWKINS invented his Rink Protector he meant well. The testimony of those who know him is unanimous in declaring that he is an exceptionally benevolent man, and if the rink proprietor really persists in making Mr.HAWKINS pay for the chandeliers it will be an unjust and contemptible act.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--The resignation of First Lieut. Alexander L. Morton, Fifth Artillery, has been accepted by the President to take effect Oct. 31, and his leave of absence has been extended until that date.

Alexander R. Spencer, better known as "Sandy" Spencer, died yesterday at the International Hotel, in Park-row, from pneumonia. He was born in Old Bridge, N.J., in February, 1837, and started out in life in this city as a bartender. In a few years he was able to open a saloon at No. 8 Centre-street, and later, with his brother John, he conducted a saloon in the building next door to the old Theatre Comique.

ALBANT, April 28.--The Gas bill was pushed along another step in the Assembly today. It was ordered to a third reading by a vote of 105 to 1, the solitary negative vote being cast by Mr. Driess, a Democrat, of Niagara County. While the opposition to it was comparatively unimportant, confining itself principally to talk and the offering of amendments, it did develop some curious and even suggestive incidents.

NEWARK, N.Y., April 28--Half a mile south of Port Gibson, Ontario County, Monday, night, William Scott, aged 71, murdered his wife, Christiana, three years younger. Jealousy was the cause of the crime. Mrs. Scott was a remarkably well-preserved woman, of medium height and well built. She had black hair, slightly tinged with gray, a bright face, and a pleasing manner.

ALBANY, April 28.--The Senate after a long debate passed the Theatrical License bill. During the debate the field occupied when the Freedom of Worship bill was before the same body was gone over again. Senator Robb, in fact, criticised it as a tender to that bill, because it was aimed at the Randalls Island House of Refuge, and he attempted to have the enacting clause stricken out.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28.--Judges McKennan and Butler, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday rendered an important decision arising under the tariff act of March, 1883. The suit was that of John B. Ellison Sons against Collector Hartranft, and was brought to recover back duties paid on dress goods composed partly of wool, and weighing over four ounces to the square yard.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 28.--Charles Gibson, a noted horse thief and jail breaker, son-in-law of John Frankford, also a noted horse thief, who escaped from the Lancaster County Prison on Dec. 31, 1881, and Joseph Graff, a burglar and jail breaker, who escaped from prison on Oct. 10, 1883, were captured on the Welsh Mountains last night by Constable Bowman, of Salisbury Township.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--A Democrat who figured very prominently during the Electoral dispute of 1876, and who comes occasionally to the capital, was very emphatic to-day in expressing his dissatisfaction with the Administration. He thinks it ought to move more rapidly, and that 9 out of 10 of the men who voted for Mr. Cleveland believe as he does.

ST. LOUIS, April 28.--The Lindell Hotel, the largest hostelry in the city, was visited by fire this afternoon and so badly damaged by fire, smoke, and water that to-night its interior presents a sad appearance. It was nearly 5 o'clock when a passer-by noticed smoke coming from one of the basement windows and immediately turned on a fire alarm. In a second all St. Louis appeared to be moving in the direction of the hotel.

Gen. Grant showed no bad effects yesterday from the efforts and excitement attendant upon his birthday. Although the early part of Monday night was passed fitfully, he slept without waking, and, unaided by anodynes, from 3 o'clock until 8, and enjoyed the luxury of a second nap between 8 and 9 o'clock.

The village of Rahway, N.J., suffered considerably from the fire which raged there yesterday morning. Nearly the entire block fronting on Urban-street north of Elizabethavenue was consumed, and but for a heavy rainstorm the whole of the central portion of the village would undoubtedly have been destroyed.

"Bobby" Matthews like wine improves with age. He pitched one of the finest games of ball this season on the Polo Grounds yesterday, when the Metropolitans were defeated by the Athletic Club. For seven innings only one of the Metropolitans succeeded in reaching first base, and he never managed to get any further than that point.

PANAMA, April 29, via Galveston.--The final meeting of the consular corps, in conjunction with Admiral Jouett, Commander McCalla, and the contending powers, was held this afternoon, when the best possible solution of the present political difficulties was arranged. Aizpuru surrenders unconditionally and, together with his followers, will retire from the city.

The ninth and last game but one of the billiard tournament was played last night. The contestante were William Sexton and Maurice Daly. In the eight-inch balk-line tournament held in Chicago Sexton defeated Daly. When the present tournament had been agreed upon Daly offered to wager Sexton $500 that he couldn't repeat his Chicago success, and the "Rowery Boy" accepted the offer.
WASHINGTON, April 29, 1885. It is estimated that the statement of the public debt for the month of April will show a reduction of about $4,000,000.

A fire occurred Tuesday night on the farm of S. Preston Carpenter, about three miles from Salem, N.J., supposed to have been caused by lightning. The barns and all the outbuildings were burned, and the residence was only saved by a shower of rain which came at the critical moment. Four valuable horses and several fine imported cows were also burned. Loss, $10,000; insured.

ALBANY, April 29.--A remarkable change of sentiment has occurred among the members of the Assembly within 24 hours. Yesterday by a vote of 105 to 1 they ordered the Gas bill to a third reacing. To-day, when Walter Howe undertook to suspend certain rules in order to pass the bill, an opposition was developed of extraordinary strength. The country members especially were loth to advance tho bill.

Fourteen skilled competitors have been selected for the 142-hours' roller skating race, which will begin in Madison-Square Garden an hour after midnight on Sunday, May 10. Up to the close of business hours last ovening 52 applications for admission to the contest had been received, but the management wended out all but experienced long-distance skaters on wheels.

Miss Florence Pirsson, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Poole Pirsson, was married last evening to Mr. George Dashiell Bayard, of the Brooklyn Eagle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Cornelius Swope, of Trinity Chapel, at the residence of the bride, No. 10 Wost Sixteenthstreet.

Few days of March opened more disagreeably than did yesterday. Snow and sleet fell and the air was raw and piercing. Overcoats of the thickest kind proved quite comfortable. The sky cleared during the morning, but the wind increased in violence and blew a gale until after sunset.

WASHINGTON, April 29.--A story affecting Gen. Sheridan and Secretary of War Endicott got into the papers of this city last night and was afterward sent to the country wrong end foremost. The Second Artillery does not want to change its station. Gen. Sheridan has ordered a change. Efforts have been made unsuccessfully to secure a change of the orders removing the Second Artillery to the Gulf station.

Russia seems to be quite indifferent to the opinion of Europe, to which England is so urgently appealing. No moral advantage that might accrue from delay is considered at St. Petersburg to be an offset to the military advantage that may be secured by "pushing things."

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 29.--The wire has been down north of Fort Qu'Appelle since noon yesterday, and no information has been obtained regarding movements of troops. The insurgents are supposed to have moved north to Dumont's Crossing, and many believe there is not likely to be any fighting for a day or two.

The rumor is denied by Harrigan and Hart that behind their abandonment of the Fourteenth-Street Theatre there is a dissolution of partnership between themselves. There is however, a strong disposition to believe that something is being covered up in connection with this latest move.

ALBANY, April 29.--A test vote was reached on the Freedom of Worship bill in the Assembly to-day, the result of which indicates that the bill is extremely unlikely to reach Gov. Hill through the medium of this Legislature. Gov. Hill is committed to the bill by his message, and he would have to sign it, though it is intimated that he secretly hopes that he may never be called to act upon it.

King LEOPOLD of Belgium is now King of the Congo. There will be no attempt to unite the two kingdoms, and, as in the case of Sweden and Norway, the only connection between Belgium and the Congo will be the fact that the King of one is also the King of the other.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 29.--Louisiana's junior United States Senator, the Hon. James Biddle Eustis, left here for New-York last night, whence he will sail for Europe to join his family in Italy. In the few days that he was here he was quite free in his criticism of President Cleveland.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, April 30.--The result of the recent engagement with the rebels is beginning to show its effect.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 30.--Capt. Davis, of the steamer Nonowantuc, from Port Jefferson, reports this morning that during the gale yesterday a small sloop, hailing from Westport. Conn., went ashore near Oldfield Light, on the Long Island shore. The crew of three men were drowned. The name of the vessel or men could not be learned.

The cadets of the Berkeley School had their fifth annual prize drill and review at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory last evening. The galleries and a broad space around the large drill room were crowded with the enthusiastic friends of the boys.

In 1878 Julius Goldsmith applied for appointment to the police force. He gave his age at the time as 28 years.
The case against Ferdinand Mayer on the charge of perjury was concluded and the prisoner acquitted yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 30.--When Arthur Orton, the Tichborne-claimant, returned to England one year ago, he set about to renew the search for a missing witness he has always claimed would establish his identity.

CHICAGO, April 30.--The war between the Chicago Board of Trade and the Western Union Telegraph Company broke out afresh this morning. Six months ago the board excluded from the floor of the Exchange all reporters but the official ones of the board.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30.--Gen. Irvin McDowell has been suffering for some time past with an affection of the principal digestive organs which prevents him from retaining anything on his stomach. His physicians have given up all hope of his recovery and his death is expected to occur at any time. He is delirious most of the time, but was occasional lucid intervals.
The handsome new building erected by the Cotton Exchange at Beaver and Williams streets at a cost of nearly $500,000 was formally opened yesterday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 30.--The Spring meeting of the Nashville Blood Horse Association will begin to-morrow and continue until next Thursday.

Millocker's newest opera, called "Der Feldprediger"--anglice, "The Chaplain"--will be brought out at the Thalia Theatre this evening. It is to be produced in an English garb, under the title of "The Black Hussar," by the McCaull Opera Company, at Wallack's Theatre, Monday of next week.

ALBANY, April 30.--The Senate, on assembling to-day, began the consideration of the Supply bill. An animated discussion arose over the proposed appropriation of $10,000 to the State Board of Health for the administration of the laws against the adulteration of food, drugs, and oil.
LONDON, April 30.--The Guion Line steamer Abyssinia, Capt. Worrall, which left Queenstown April 27 for New-York, has passed South Kinsale, going toward Liverpool. Her main shaft is broken.
Charles F. Lyon, of No. 413 West Nineteenth-street, formerly bookkeeper of the Mutual Gaslight Company, pleaded guilty to grand larceny in the second degree before Judge Gildersleeve yesterday.
Atlanta is beginning to discover what pestiferous thing unnecessary litigation is.--Atlanta (Ga.) Constitution.

BBUSSELS, April 30.--The Independance Belge's St. Petersburg correspondent reiterates the statement that there has been a fresh engagement between the Afghans and Russians, and that the latter were repulsed.

When Grant Ward suspended Wallstreet was flooded with rumors to the effect that the Erie Railroad Company was badly hurt by the crash and that Bird W. Spencer, its Treasurer, had been guilty of some improper acts in the management of its finances.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 30.--Criminal carelessness is chargeable against Kentucky cattle men in not adopting vigorous measures against pleuro-pneumonia, which has again appeared among Frisbe Lake's Jerseys at Cynthiana. Their best bull displays active symptoms of the disease, and half a dozen animals in herds have the disease in the chronic stage.
TORONTO, April 30.--Martin Malone was found guilty here to-day of the murder of John Fair banks.
BUFFALO, April 30.--When word came today that Gov. Hill had signed the Niagara Falls Park Reservation bill the residents of Niagara Falls Village made many demonstrations of joy.
A contest over the will of Mrs. Winifred Austin was begun in the Surrogate's Court yesterday. The contestants are her sons, James, Robert, Richard, and Charles Austin. The estate is worth $900,000.

WASHINGTON, April 30.--The proclamation of Mr. Eustis, Senator from Louisiana, is laughed at here as simply an exhibition of disappointment on the part of one of the "ring" Democrats of one State.

George Franklin Slosson walked out of Irving Hall last night champion of the world at the 14-inch balk-line game of billiards. He was a happy man, but no happier than the hosts of friends he has won by his gentlemanly conduct and his brilliant billiard playing.

Mr.Boucicault's "Old Heads and Young Hearts," a clever specimen of that artificial comedy which Charles Lamb appreciated, but which long since went out of date, was presented at Wallack's last evening.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 30.--On this, the third day of Woodward's horse sale, $22,000 were realized for the 73 animals sold--an average of $301.
WASHINGTON, April 30.--The Secretary of the Treasury has directed the suspension of the following-named Assistant Appraisers at New-York: Merritt Wickham, William H. Gregg, and Ward S. Fowler.
The lines of the Lyceum Theatre do not appear to have been cast in pleasant places, and the creditors of the house are now engaged in looking upon it with rather anxious eyes.
The tournament which closed last night with the victory of SLOSSON was probably the most remarkable display of skill at billiards that has ever been made.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 30.--The annual sale of thoroughbred colts and fillies, the produce of Bramble, Luke Blackburn, Enquirer, and imported Great Tom, at the Belle Meade farm of Gen. W.G. Harding, to-day, was attended by 500 persons.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 30.--Fred Roth, aged 50 years, came here several months ago from Elberfeld, Rhenish Prussia, where he was Burgomeister. Becoming despondent over inaability to procure a situation, he to-day shot himself through the head in the presence of his wife and child. His body will be interred in Spring Grove Cometery, which he had visited and admired the day before his death.

MONTREAL, April 30.--The Grand Trunk workmen held a meeting to-day to discuss the proposed reduction of 10 per cent in their wages. A committee of 13 was appointed to wait upon Mr. Willis, the Mechanical Superintendent, but they failed to receive any satisfaction from him, although they threatened to strike. They will report to another meeting of the workmen on Saturday, when it is believed a strike will take place.

"Tom" Hoolahan, a well-known Brooklyn contractor and politician, died in 1878, leaving an estate of about $200,000, which was to be divided, according to his will, in parcels of $5,000 to each of his two sisters, and the large balance between his grandchildren.

Miss Estelle Easton, daughter of Mr. J. H. Easton, of Chicago, was married last evening to Mr. William B. Dowd, Jr., of this city. The ceremony was performed in the private parlors of the Windsor Hotel.
ALBANY, April 30.--The excitement among the employee on the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company's roads continues, but there is no material change in the situation.

WASHINGTON, April 30, 1885. John B. Wiiliams, of Indiana, who was ap pointed Third Auditor of the Treasury yesterday, held the office of Appointment Clerk of the Post Office Department 36 years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30.--At a meeting of the Eastern Nail Association, held here today, the card rate of $2.30 per keg was fixed, and it was agreed to stop production for two Weeks between May 1 and July 1.

WASHTNGTON, April 30.--The President to-day appointed Anthony M. Keiley, of Richmond, Va., to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary of the United States to Austria-Hungary.
LONDON, April 30.--The steamship Humber, which left New-York Feb. 15 with British mails, has not been heard from and is probably lost.

BOSTON, Mass., April 30.--The schooner Arthur Burton, Capt. Crockett, from New-York for Boston, came ashore on Green Hill Beach on Wednesday night, and went to pieces. She was owned by William Robinson and others, of Boston. She had a cargo of 341 tons of coal, which will also be a total loss. The vessel is partially insured.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 30.--The marriage to-day of Miss Daisy Breaux, daughter of the Hon. Gus A. Breaux, to air. Andrew Bimonds, Jr., of Charleston, S.C., was the most brilliant social event seen in New-Orleans for years.

PANAMA, April 30, via Galveston.--Aizpuru has surrendered, aocording to yesterday's arrangement, and given up his arms, and the Government troops occupy the city to-day. All is quiet, and business is everywhere resumed. This ends the revolution so far as present operations on the isthmus are concerned.

The outcome of the conference of the trunk line Presidents at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday was practically an official recognition of the death of the freight pool and an admission that the difficulties encompassing the railroad situation are too many to be overcome by the methods hitherto used to keep the pool alive. All the roads were represented.

SCHENTECTADY, N.Y., April 30.--It is now about a year since the Rev. Dr. E.N. Potter tendered his resignation of the Presidency of Union College, and the institution still remains without a head, Justice Judson S. Landon and Prof. Cady Staley dividing the duties of President.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 30.--Birmingham's religious circles are in a ferment. They are enjoying a sensation, reveling in the existence of a number of believers in faith cures in that town.

BALTIMORE, May 1.--The Baltimore Coffee Exchange died out to-day after a protracted struggle for life. Some time ago an effort was made to consolidate with the Corn and Flour Exchange, but torms could not be agreed upon and it failed.
BUFFALO, May 1.--Mr. Frank H. Goodyear, of this city, has bought 14,000 acres of timber lands in Potter County, Penn. The nearest railroad to the tract is the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia.

Patti sails for Europe this morning on the steamship Aurania, of the Cunard Line. The vessel leaves her dock at 7:30 o'clock. Mrs. Margaret Breslin, wife of James H. Breslin, of the Gilsey House, died last evening at the family residence, adjoining the hotel. The body will be temporarily entombed in this city, awaiting the recovery of Mr. Breslin's eldest daughter, who is confined to her room by illness. It will then be taken to Saratoga for interment.

PANAMA, May 1, via Galveston.--All is quiet here. The town has been in charge of the national troops since 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. During the armistice of 48 hours the greater portion of the rebels escaped, taking with them their arms.
PHILADELPHIA, May 1.--Ex-AttorneyGeneral Brewster sails for a three months' trip in Europe in June, and contemplates the immediate sale of his collection of law works, which cost him $50,000.

BOSTON, May 1.--The annual class races between the four Harvard crews representing their respective classes took place this afternoon on the Charles River course. The water was all that could be desired, but a drizzling rain prevented the spectators from enjoying the race.

FORTRESS MONROE, Va., May 1.--The British war ship Garnet sailed hence at 3 o'clock this morning. Her destination is supposed to be New-York, at which port the Russian corvette Strelok arrived on Thursday.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 1.--The conference committee of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers presented its scale propositions to the iron manufacturers' committee this afternoon. The proposition demands the payment of the same wages as are paid under ...
A petition has been sent to the Legislature urging the passage of concurrent resolutions proposing amendments to the State Constitution regarding State, municipal, and town elections.

PROVIDENCE, May 1.--The Executive Committee of the National Civil Service Reform Association has voted to hold the next annual meeting in Newport in August. Mr. George William Curtis will preside and deliver the address.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 1.--Woodard's sale of horses closed to-day. Prices rather fell off toward the end, as rain decreased the attendance and dampened the ardor of bidders.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 1.--The Hon. Samuel W. Tewksbury, an ex-Assemblyman, residing at Perry Centre, Wyoming County, N.Y., who last Summer in a heated discussion upon local politics struck J.C. Walker on the head with a chair, rendering him insensible for hours, was fined $500 for his brutality by a Circuit Court jury to-day.

Foster W. Wyatt, 72 years old, a wealthy resident of Islip, Long Island, went yesterday to his son's drug store, took down a bottle of morphine from a shelf, drank a wine glass full, and died a few minutes afterward. It is not known whether he intended to commit suicide or made a mistake, but it is said he has been acting strangely for some time.

A Sergeant of police, in citizen's clothes, called at the residence of Mr. Whitelaw Reid on Wednesday with a warrant for his arrest. Mr. Reid was in the dining room with his family partaking of a late morning meal, and when he was told that a stranger wished to see him he sent word for him to call again.

BALTIMORE, May 1.--The Grand Jury today found 23 presentments against Robert Butler, the negro burglar, who was arrested on the 23d ult. A like number of presentments were made against Isaac Sakolski and Harris Weinbaum, the parties who bought the stolen property from Butler. There is a prospect of 50 years' imprisonment for each of the accused.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1.--A competitive debate was held last night in the Cliosophic Society rooms to choose three Seniors who are to represent that hall in the Lynde prize debate at Commencement. Sherrord Depue, of New-Jersey; Charles Flint McClumpha, of New-York, and Clarence Walworth McIlvaine, of Vermont, were the three successful men.

Yesterday morning incendiaries fired the outbuildings of Manning Steele, at Plainfield, N. J., which were totally destroyed, with horses, cattle, poultry, and farm machinery. The loss is from $8,000 to $10,000; insured. This is the third incendiary fire in Plainfield this week.
The unofficial news concerning the relations of Russia and England is so contradictory that it will be well for readers to limit their credulity to the official dispatches.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1.--Mme. Barrios, widow of the late President of Guatemala, and party left for New-York to-day.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 1.--Eighty-five young English farmers arrived this morning and left by the Canadian Pacific Railroad to settle in the Northwest. They stated that many more of their friends are to follow immediately.

Now that Mr. A.M. Keiley has been sent to Austria instead of Italy, it is by no means certain that Secretary Bayard has done him a great favor. His nomination has yet to be confirmed. Democrats here are of the opinion that as soon as Congress meets he will be found to be offensive to the solid Republican majority.

ZANZIBAR, May 1.--Herr Bohm, the leader of the German exploring expedition to Lake Moero, in East Africa, was recently killed by natives. A confrere named Richard escaped and has arrived here.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1.--James Turpin, a life prisoner, pardoned yesterday by Gov. Hoadly, reached the city to-day. The facts upon which his pardon was secured disclose one of the most remarkable criminal conspiracies ever brought to light in this community.

WASHINGTON, May 1.--It is reported that the resignation of Judge Axtell, of the Supreme Court of New-Mexico, has been requested by the Attorney-General, with the understanding that should he not resign he will be removed; also that the Internal Revenue Collector for Mississippi, James Hill, will be asked to resign, to give place to E.O. Sykes, of Aberdeen, Miss.

Commodore C.K. Garrison died at his residence, No. 40 Park-avenue, about 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The partial paralysis with which he had been afflicted during the past eight years extended to his heart and struck him down suddenly.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1.--The Rev. Levi Boyer, an Episcopal minister, presiding over the Washburn Mission, at Ashtabula, has been suspended by Bishop Bedell. The order of suspension had hardly become known before Boyer fied from the city, leaving his wife and baby child behind.

A very elaborate service took place in the Polish Church of St. Stanislaus, in Stantonstreet, yesterday morning. Onderdonk, the latter of whom was recently horsewhipped by the wives of Policemen Shakespeare and Harris, held its annual meeting in Nyack to-day, and much interest was manifested by the people in the proceedings.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 4.--During last night Louis Henry and John Winch, short-term burglars, succeeded in breaking the bar across their cell window on the upper corrider of the county jail, and by means of ropes made from their bed clothing and hooks stolen from their carpet looms scaled the walls and escaped Winch is a one-armed man.

The new Board of Education of Jersey City organized last night, with Mial Mason President and Mark Curley Clerk. The old board surrendered quietly, but under protest, to await the result of quo warranto proceedings. George H. Barton was re-elected Superintendent for three years, at a yearly salary of $2,600.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 4.--An attempt was made early this morning to burn the Protestant Orphans' Home at Covington, Ky. Fifty inmates had a narrow escape from a horrible death. George Leudecke, a boy 10 years of age, discovered the fire in the kitchen, gave the alarm, and the flames were soon extinguished. This is the second attempt within ten days to fire the building.

William A. Darling, the President of the Murray Hill Bank, had a severe stroke of paralysis on Friday morning last. He had finished breakfast and was about to leave home for the bank when he was attacked. His entire left side was paralyzed, and his power of speech was also lost temporarily. Last evening he had recovered his speech, and he was so far improved as to justify the belief that he would get well.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 8.--Frederick Ray, a German, who came to Syracuse with his family a few months ago from New-York, committed suicide last night by hanging. He used a clothes line, and at daybreak his body was found suspended from a rafter in a shed. In the afternoon he had a quarrel with his wife, during which she advised him to take the line and put an end to himself. He acted on her suggestion.

Edmund Dorr was an oddity who lived in the suburbs of Hallowell, Me., half a century ago. On the 14th day of a February he jogged into town on his horse sled and was arrested for violating a city ordinance requiring all sleighs and sleds to have bells attached.

The Shaker brethren at Mount Lebanon, where the ministry and highest authority in the Shaker Church is situathd, have been notified that Elder Thomas Smith has been married since June last. The information was received with the greatest amazement.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 9.--The schooner Northern Star, of Gloucester, homeward bound from the Georges, was wrecked early this morning at Ipswich Beach.

HARRISBURG. Penn., May 9.--H.A.W. Walkemeyer, one of the most prominent business men of this city, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the heart. Judgments to the amount of $10,000 had been entered against him, and yesterday the Sheriff levied on his property. He had carried on an extensive ice business in this city, and was thought to be comparatively wealthy.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 9.--Cold winds and frequent rains for the past 10 days have had a tendency to prevent the renting of many cottages. A few of the cottage residents have arrived for the Summer.

Two cases of typhus fever were unearthed by the health officers yesterday. Michael Lukoebesky, a Russian tailor, who recently moved into the city from East New-York, and who lives at No. 138 Chrystie-street, was one of the victims. The other was John Callahan, a lad 14 years old, who lives at No. 108 Mulberrystreet. Both were taken to the Riverside Hospital.

WASHINGTON, May 9.--A number of Cubans have been in the city for several days, and it is stated that they have interested a number of Senators and Representatives in a scheme for the purchase of Cuba by the United States. The party left here for New-York last night to confer with a number of capitalists on the subject.

Herman Lessman, who frequently quarreled with his wife on the top floor of No. 195 Delancey-street, died suddenly yesterday morning. His brother sent word to Coroner Messemer that Herman had been poisoned.

BUFFALO, May 9.--Snow fell here for several hours to-day, and shortly before noon the temperature dropped to 30 . Snow has never been known to fall here so late in the year. The nearest approach to it was in 1875, when light snow fell May 2. The harbor and river are choked with ice, which extends lakeward for a long distance.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 9.--Miss Mary A. Macy, a teacher in the Fifth-Street Grammar School, was in the local court this morning on a charge of assault on one of her pupils, Antone Pines, a boy of 10 years. He would not sing in his class chorus on the plea of headache, and she struck him once with a ruler on the open hand.

The will of Mrs. Jane Holmes was recorded yesterday. She made a number of charitable bequests, the principal of which were to the Allegheny Orphan Asylum, $15,000; Homeopathic Hospital. $15,000; Home of the Friendless $1,000; Allegheny General Hospital, $5,000; Colored Orphans' Home, $2,000; Home for Incurables, 16 acres of ground and $100,000.
ALBANY, May 9.--Attorney-General O'Brien has rendered an important opinion relative to the right of savings banks in this State to invest their funds in bonds issued by the State of Indiana.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 9.--A dinner will be given next Thursday evening at the Globe Hotel in this city to Mr. Francis E. Leupp, the retiring editor of the Evening Herald. Mr. Leupp has been at the head of this journal for more than seven years.

Jeremiah M. Pelton, dealer in pianos at No. 28 East Fourteenth-street, made an assignment yesterday to Edson H. McEwen, giving preferences aggregating $18,241, the largest being to Thomas C. McEwen, $4,150; J.J. Burchell, $3,000, and Guy R. Pelton, $2,240.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 9.--George Robinson, the coachman of Mr. F. Spring, eloped with the waitress last Saturday. Mr. Spring paid both of them on Friday and the next day they left without warning. George had just passed his twenty-first birthday.

The steamship Hekla, of the Thingvalla Line, which sailed yesterday for Christiansand and Copenhagen, took out a party of about 500 Scandinavians, nearly all of whom are returning to their homes in the old country for a short visit. They filled the cabins and the steerage of the vessel.

MILWAUKEE, May 9.--A bold burglary was committed in this city at 1 o'clock this morning at the residence of G.H. Atwell, a wealthy shoe dealer. WASHINTON, May 9.--The third trial of the Snyder dynamite projectile took place today on the Potomac, above Georgetown. The object of the trial was mainly to demonstrate the safety of the system of firing, so that no particular attempt was made to exhibit the effect of the shell itself.

CHICAGO, May 9.--A special dispatch to the Daily News from Springfield, Ill., says: "Leeper, the defeated Democratic candidate for Representative in the Thirty-fourth District to succeed J. Henry Shaw, arrived in this city today, and has given out that he will contest the election of Weaver. WASHINGTON, May 9.--The returns from the recent census of this city taken by the Police Department are not yet complete, but from such portions as are complete and an estimate of the remainder the conclusion is arrived at by the police officials that Washington has now a population of 200,000. READING, Penn., May 9.--A well-known business man of this city named Amanda Kalbach committed suicide at an early hour this morning by taking a dose of arsenic. He was a man of powerful physique, in good health, and about 35 years of age.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 9.--Major B.G. Thomas's sale of Dixiana yearlings took place to-day. Nineteen colts brought $10,405, an average of $547 63. Eleven fillies brought $5,445, an average of $495.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 9.--The President yesterday appointed John E. Mason Postmaster at North Java, to fill the position left vacant by H.B. Rodgers's removal. Rodgers recently became insane and is now confined in the Buffalo Insane Asylum. Mason was formerly a Supervisor, is a prominent Cleveland Democrat, and an Irishman.

CHICAGO, May 9.--The freight rate wars to the Northwest and West are in a fair way to settlement. The representatives of the roads interested met to-day and agreed upon a proposition for peace.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, May 9.--The Newfoundland sealer Young Prince camp into collision with an iceberg in the Gulf of St. Lawrence on the 19th ult. She sank almost immediately, barely giving the crew time to save provisions and clothing.

TUSCUMBIA, Ala., May 9.--Last night a negro named Jordan, who had attempted a criminal assault upon Miss Davis, the daughter of a farmer, but who jumped from a window as Mr. Davis shot at him, was caught and lynched by a mob. It was found that Mr. Davis's shot had wounded him in the ear.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 10.--A desperate affray occurred at Georgetown, Ky., last night, at a colored festival. Officers George Cole and Jack Susby attempted to arrest two boys who were disorderly, when they wore knocked down with rocks by friends of the offenders. The officers fired into the crowd and killed George Strahan, the father of the boys. The officers were so badly beaten that it is thought they cannot recover.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10.--The trouble between the manufacturing potters and hollowware pressers in this city has been satisfactorily settled. Committees from the manufacturers and Knights of Labor met and arranged prices and wages to the mutual satisfaction of all. The hollow-ware pressers, who have been out of work for two weeks, will resume to-morrow.

Wednesday night a grand banquet will be tendered the Knights by citizens and local lodges. The city is beautifully decorates with the Stars and Stripes and flags of the order.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., MaY 11.--Thomas Hamblin, a wealthy farmer living at Clay, was found dead this morning hanging by a rope from a beam in his barn. His estate is valued at $50,000. He frequently told his wife that he soon expected to lose all his money and die poor. Mr. Hamblin was 62 years old and one of the first of the English settlers in this county.
There was a large attendance at the boxing tournament in Turn Hall, in East Fourthstreet, last evening, under the auspices of William Madden. Only one professional bout took place.

NEE-ORLEANS, May 11.--This was the Veteran and National Guard Day at the Exposition. The line of march was formed on Canal-street at 9 o'clock, consisting of the Louisiana State Militia, Grand Army veterans, Confederate veterans, and visiting militia.

SELMA, Ala., May 11.--Yesterday in the woods near Dixie Station, on-the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad, 30 miles above here, the dead body of Scipio Atchison, colored, was found riddled with buckshot.
George Ripley keeps a saloon at No. 582 Seventh-avenue. He was arrested a few months ago for disorderly conduct, and soon after his license was revoked. He did not close his saloon.

A circular will be issued to-day by-the Canda Reorganization Committee of the Ohio Central Railroad, main line, outlining a plan for exchanging the stock of the Ohio Central for stock of the Hocking Valley Company. Such an exchange, it is said, was proposed by the Hocking Valley Company, and has been practically agreed upon.

At the meeting of the Game Association last evening a resolution was offered by ex-Senator Wagstaff approving the bill, now in Gov. Hill's hands, against hunting deer with hounds. Mr. Meyer wanted to know how deer were to be hunted, if not with hounds.

Los ANGELES, Cal., May 11.--While Gen. Sheridan and his wife, who arrived here yesterterday, were out driving to-day their horses ran away. The carriage was upset and both were thrown out, but although considerably shaken up they were not seriously injured.

ALBANY, May 11.--The special order in the Senate to-night was the Capitol Appropriation bill. An amendment proposed by Mr. Lansing for raising the main tower 30 feet was adopted.
PITTSBURG, May 11.--Another 10 per cent. of the ovens controlled by the Connellsvilie coke syndicate were closed this morning.

Collins, who keeps a hotel at Batavia, and who has been here with State Treasurer Maxwell, was picked out by the same reporters to be the successor of Mr. E.O. Graves as Assistant Treasurer. He does not expect to be Assistant Treasurer.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 11.--Some comment was caused to-day by a duel between two creole young men of good social and business standing. The quarrel arose over a game of cards and blows passed.

Mr. Edward Harrigan's new farce, presented for the first time at the FourteenthStreet Theatre last evening, does not picture line in this metropolis; in fact, it cannot be said to picture life at all.

William Braun, of Philadelphia, made a contract abroad for the importation of a band of 40 German musicians, and the Musical Mutual Protective Association began an action in the Supreme Court for the purposes of restraining them from landing and of compelling the North German Lloyd Steamship Company to take them back to Europe.

There was just the faintest flutter of excitement yesterday in theatrical circles over the announcement of the wedding of Harold B. Wallack, youngest son of Lester Wallack.

For the first time since the Park Commissioners asked that the American Museum of Natural History be opened to the public on Sundays the Trustees of that institution met yesterday and talked about the request.
HAVANA, May 7.--The celebrated bandit, Manuel Guzman, was killed on the 3d inst. by two civil-guards.

WASHINGTON, May 11, 1885. Charles M. Shelley, of Alabama, has been ap pointed Fourth Auditor of the Treasury, vice Charles Beardsley, resigned. He qualified to-day and will assume charge of the office to-morrow morning.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 11.--A gang of Italians was at work blasting stone on the property of the Belle Haven Land Company to-day, using dynamite as the explosive power. After loading a blast it did not go off, when one of the gang approached the cartridge and struck the cap. The load went off, blowing away part of the man's face. When picked up he showed signs of life, but cannot recover.

PANAMA, via Galveston, May 11.--Five hundred men arrived from Buenaventura yesterday, and 300 more are on the way. The Colombian Guard, which fought Prestan at Colon, have also arrived here, with about 100 prisoners, who were falsely reported as drowned. Prestan is besieging Cartagena, and was received in the rebel camp, which was illuminated in his honor, with cries of "Viva Prestan."

NAPLES, May 11.--The city has given itself up to festivity for the day, celebrating the opening of the new waterworks. The supply from the new source was turned on by King Humbert.
John Lockwood, driver of a mail wagon, was run over, trampled on, and kicked by his runaway horse yesterday, yet apparently escaped without a scratch.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--A board of medical officers, to consist of Lieut-Col. Andrew K. Smith. Surgeon; Major John C.G. Happersett, Surgeon, and Capt. James P. Kimball, Assistant Surgeon, will assemble at the Military Academy, West Point, on June 1, to examine into the physical qualifications of the members of the graduating class and the candidates for admission to the Academy.

RICHMOND, Va., May 11.--The trial of T. J. Cluverius for the murder of Fannie LillianMadison was resumed this morning.

Real Estate Broker William Van Antwerp is in Ludlow-Street Jail. His wife had him put there on a charge of fraud, made in the course of a suit which she has brought in the Superior Court to compel him to account to her for her marriage portion which was invested in bonds and stock representing over $100,000.
SUAKIN, May 11.--The Egyptian troops at Kasaala are compelled to eat donkeys to relieve their hunger. The Governor of Kassala rejects all appeals of the garrison to attempt to escape from the town.
The Princeton College Glee Club give a concert at Chickering Hall this evening.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 11.--A general white frost prevailed all through South Carolina and Georgia this morning, doing much damage in low lands. In many places corn is seriously injured, cotton is wilted, and young fruit is nipped. Reports from the middle section of Alabama show a like state of affairs.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 11.--The new hospital at Plymouth for the reception of patients afflicted with the fever was formally opened this morning. Only those who have no homes will be admitted.

BOSTON, May 11.--The first annnal meeting of the Temperance National League opened at Tremont Temple at noon to-day, with 600 in attendance.
The contestants in the six days' roller skating race at the Madison-Square Garden flew around the track all day yesterday in a ceaseless whirl.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 11.--D. Martin Co., one of the heaviest commission houses in the city, made an assignment to-day to A.H. Leece. The annouucemont caused the most profound surprise in business circles.
The Assembly yesterday took up the Earl bill exempting honorably discharged Union soldiers and sailors from the operation of the civil service regulations.

The annual election of the New-York Stock Exchange yesterday was not sufficiently exciting to disturb the usual order of business, yet it was not lecking in interest.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 11.--A house occapied by Lizzie Blunt and Minnie Bell was blown up by dynamite at 5 o'clock Sunday morning. An eight-inch cartridge, packed in a piece of gas pipe, was laid on the porch and exploded.
Mrs. Kate McMahon occupies a small frame house in Sixty-eighth-street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues. She is the mother of a bright-eyed little girl named Kate, who is between 2 and 3 years old.
LEAVENWORTH, Kan., May 11.--The antiProhibitionists have won the first point in court to-day against the Prohibition crusade began here 10 days ago.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., May 11.--Judge Davis, upon application of Charles Bliss, of NewYork, has appointed J.E. Somes, of this city, Receiver of the United Order of Foresters. The liabilities are $40,000, of which $37,000 is from death losses. The assets are very small. The insolvency is due to loss of membership, and not to any shortage of the officers.

FRANKFORT, N.Y., May 11.--Some places, like some men, have greatness thrust upon them. In a limited sense Frankfort is one of these, Until the West Shore Railway shops were erected here-the-place-was a slow-going country hamlet, whose chief industry was matchmaking, one-of-the Diamond combination's factories being situated here.

Archeological discoveries of importance are rapidly succeeding each other here. READING, Penn., May 12.--Mrs. Hiram Pfautz, 42 years old, residing near Litiz, late this afternoon committed the unmotherly act of attempting the destruction of herself and five small children. She was successful in making away with herself and two of the little ones.
HAVANA, May 12.--The municipal elections resulted in favor of the Conservatives.
CHICAGO, May 12.-- Joseph Vincent's two wives confronted him when the case against him was called in Justice J.C. White's Court to-day. The prisoner had neither lawyers nor witnesses.
PARIS, May 12.--Minister McLane will present his credentials to President Grevy on Thursday of this week.
WASHINGTON, May 12.--The opening day of the Spring meeting of the National Jockey Club was one of the most successful in the history of the organization.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 12.--A special to the News from Longview says: "Swarms of grasshoppers have appeared in Panola County, which borders on the Louisiana line. While Police Captain Farrier was walking along Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, at 12 o'clock last night he was attacked by a gang of ruffians. He was beaten and kicked until he was rendered unconscious. His injuries are considered dangerous. A citizen who tried to aid the Captain was badly beaten.
BUFFALO, May 12.--The inventory and schedule of the bankrupt dry goods firm of McLean Rodenbach was filed this morning. Ninety-three out-of-town creditors possess claims amounting to $28,772 88.

The Rev. Malick A. Cunnion, of St. James's Church, will sail for Europe on Thursday by the steamship City of Chicago. His parishioners last night presented him with a purse of $1,250. Father Cunnion will be present at the ordination of his brother Daniel, which will take place on May 30 at the Basilica of St. John Lateran, in Rome.

McPhee and Nelson did some pretty fielding.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 13.--The Kentucky Association races closed to-day with four events. The first race was for a purse of $350 for all ages; one and a quarter miles. The starters and pools were: Kilmeny, (107 pounds,) $20; Ed Butts, (108 pounds,) and Greyhound, (109 pounds.) in the field, $6. Kilmeny won easily; Ed Butt second, and Greyhound third. Time-- 2:11 .

The unknown man who has been causing the Brooklyn police a good deal of trouble lately broke into the Cook-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, Eastern District, some time yesterday afternoon and ruined the organ, demolished a lot of books and cushions, and left without stealing anything. This is the fifth church the fellow has visited to destroy furniture within three weeks.

SEWARD, N.Y., May 13.--A fatal malady prevails all through the Seward Valley. It first attacked Samuel McRoberts, who died, and since then funerals occur daily about here. LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 15.--Sergt. Louis Leppman, who was the oldest veteran in the United States Army in point of service, having served 54 years continuously until relieved by special act of Congress, on a pension of $50 a month, died at Fort Niagara last night, aged 88. PHILADELPHIA, May 17.--The Roading Railroad Company scored a point to-day against the Pennsylvania Railroad in securing an outlet for their road--the Philadelphia and Atlantic City--at the Kaighn's Point Ferry, in Camden.

TUCSON, Arizona, May 17.--Private advices from Hermosillo, Mexico, state that the Mexican troops attacked the Yaquis on Wednesday near Misa. Three hundred of the Yaquis are reported to have been killed. The Mexican loss is 80 killed and wounded. Four Americans were with the Mexicans. Two were killed and one, named McKenzie, was wounded. The report of the battle is not yet officially confirmed. The Government prohibits reports from being telegraphed.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., May 17.--Jennie Yarnell, a young lady of 19, committed suicide here at noon to-day by shooting herself through the heart. The cause assigned for the act is that her father had been drinking heavily, and to avoid the disgrace which she imagined it brought upon her she decided to take her own life. She was young, handsome, and vivacious, and her rash act surprised those who knew her.

DES MOINES, May 17.--A tinner named Newport and a barkeeper named Alexander Stavast, while in a boat above the milldam this afternoon, undertook to go down the fishway. The boat remained upright, but both men fell out and were drowned. Newport's body has been recovered, but not that of Stavast. A waterman saw them fall, but was too far off to save them. It is thought the men had been drinking.

ITHACA, May 17.--The Rev. Robert Collyer, of New-York, preached in Sage Chapel today. CHICAGO, May 17.--A body found floating at the mouth of the Chicago River last evening was identified as that of Capt. Ben Eyster, a resident of Chicago for 30 years and prominently identified with the lake marine. He was last seen alive yesterday. It is supposed he committed suicide. He had been in ill-health all Winter. Eyster's life was an eventful one. Ha had killed two men, but in each case avoided conviction.
BALTIMORE, May 17.--The Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club will begin atPimlico on Tuesday, and the indications are that it will be more than ordinarily attractive.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 17.--The body of an unknown man, about 50 years old, was washed ashore at Rye Beach yesterday, and it is believed that the man had been murdered. An examination of the body revealed a large bullet hole just above the right ear, slanting downward, five inches in depth, but no other injuries were discovered.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 17.--John Duffie, a Parry safe burglar, with William Woods and Alonzo Powell, two house thieves, escaped from jail here this evening. This was easily effected, the jail being an ancient affair, and a disgrace to the county. Officers were in pursuit in 20 minutes, the court house bell being sounded as an alarm. The evidence against the convicts was certain to send them to State prison.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, May 17.--Norman H. Camp, ex-Assayer of the Boise City Assay Office, was arrested yesterday, charged with embezzling $12,816 of United States funds while he was Assayer. His examination will come off to-morrow. Spenille Braden, the newly appointed Assayer, arrived yesterday and took charge of the Assay Office.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 17.--J.B. Russell, of Cuthbert, killed his two sons to-day and then shot himself threo times. The trouble was caused by financial difficulties.

LONDON, May 17.--The final installment of the Granville-de Giers dispatches on the Afghan dispute will be issued during the Whitsuntide recess of Parliament. The Conservatives will postpone Parliamentary action until all the papers are presented. The publication of the first dispatches engrosses the attention of the political clubs.

MONTREAL, May 17.--The steamer Lake Huron still has on board the little boy of Mrs. Spooner, who, together with her child of 2, was lost overboard. The boy, who is a bright little fellow, will be sent to some institution unless claimed by relatives.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., May 17.--One of the most heavy and severe rainstorms that has ever visited Southern Kansas occurred last Friday, flooding Elk and Verdigris Rivers, and drowning a great number of cattle. Great damage has been done to railroad and other bridges.

BRIDGEPORT, Ill., May 18.--The 17-year locusts, which Prof. Reilly predicted, as mentioned in recent Washington dispatches, seem to have made their first appearance here. COS COB, Conn., May 19.--Samuel Stewart, of New-York, owns a fine country residence here. A few days ago he took possession for the Summer. His chief pleasure is in raising and training thoroughbred horses. While exercising a colt to-day the animal took fright and ran away, throwing Mr. Stewart out and breaking three of his ribs and bruising him severely. When picked up he was unconscious, but recovered under medical treatment.

BALTIMORE, May 19.--The bigamy case against Carrie Ward, the New-York actress, was discontinued to-day on account of lack of testimony. According to the indictment Miss Carrie married Ward Feb. 15, 1884, and Loomis on Oct. 24 last.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 19.--Frank Landers, the famous forger with many aliases, was to day sentenced to 24 years in the genitentiary. He had six indictments hanging over him. Landers swindled many jewelry firms throughout the country. The Jewelers' Protective Association finally secured his arrest and brought him here for trial.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 19.--The hurricane which occurred in the little town of Taylor, Texas, on Saturday evening, demolished the Missouri Pacific Railroad freighthouse, unroofed the roundhouse, wrecked the City Hall, and damaged about a dozen other, buildings. The railroad company's loss is $5,000, and the damage to the other buildings is from $12,000 to $15,000. No lives were lost.
The Legislature of Illinois yesterday reelected the Hon. JOHN A. LOGAN to the United States Senate for a term of six years from the 4th of March last.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 19.--The Board of Aldermen have challenged the members of the City Council to play a game of baseball at the Barnum Grounds on Memorial Day for the benefit of the Bartholdi statue fund. The challenge has been accepted, and a committee from each body has been appointed to arrange the preliminaries. The Mayor will act as umpire.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 19.--Several important meetings in connection with the epidemic have been held at Plymouth since last night. The ward committees reported this afternoon...

ELMIRA, N.Y., May 19.--The annual May musical festival opened to-day in the First Methodist Church. Fifty villages are represented. Dr. George F. Root, of Chicago, is the instructor. The management is under the direction of Prof. Howard B. Hamer, of Elmira. The attendance to-day was unusually large, and great success is promised. The festival closes on Friday, with concerts at the Opera House afternoon and evening.

A circular authorized by the Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company was issued yesterday, soliciting proxies for the annual election, which will occur next Wednesday.

PARIS, May 19.--Victor Hugo continues very weak. He had a fainting fit this morning, but subsequently recovered his senses. At noon he was in full possession of consciousness, and was talking calmly of death.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 19.--The Hon. L.W's Northrup, of Sandy Hill, presiding Judge of the new Court of Claims, this State, was married here at 3 P.M. to-day to Mrs. Lydia A.M. Lewis, of Binghamton.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 19.--Extensive forest fires are raging at Harvey's Lake, a well-known Summer resort 12 miles from here. Several thousand dollars' worth of valuable timber has been destroyed since Sunday. The burning area is about a mile square.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., May 19.--W.R. Jackson, who shot and killed James Parr, a farmer, and wounded his son, near Danvers, last Winter, was found guilty of murder this afternoon and the death penalty adjudged by the jury.

BUFFALO, May 19.--Three dwelling houses on West-avenue, this city, were burned last night, the total loss being $10,500, which is covered by insurance. The fire was caused by an explosion of gasoline in the residence of Capt. Daniel Hogers, of the firm of Rogers Brown, vessel agents. Capt. Rogers was burned to a crisp, his body being found in the ruins. His wife was seriously burned.

Terrace Garden blazed with light and blossomed with flowers last evening. The scene was line a fairy picture.

Nothing seems so welcome to the people just now as reminiscences of the late war. The passion and ill-feeling of the contest have passed away, never to return, but every one listens with increased interest to the authentic relation of incidents and events of the long struggle.

Ellen J. Kleem, a married woman, living at One Hundred and Thirty-sixth-street and the Boulevard, during her husband's absence from home on Monday, went to the trunk, took out a small bottle of laudanum, and drank the contents. When her husband returned home he found her partly unconscious. She said to him, "George, I could not help it," and died before an ambulance arrived. No cause is known for the suicide.

James Spellman, a peddler, 27 years old, visited Edward Wilson, a one-armed man, at No. 4 Birmingham-street, on the night of March 29 last. Besides these two men a man named Kelly and two women were in the room.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 19.--A large force of bricklayers employed by ex-Representative H.C. Frey struck this morning on account of his refusal to discharge non-union men in his employ. The strikers are members of Union No. 1 of Pennsylvania. The contractor is firm and will not yield, to their demand.

PITTSBURG, May 19.--During funeral services at the residence of John Haller, on wilkins-avenue, in the east end, this afternoon, a porch in front of the house gave way, precipitating 65 people to the cellar, 10 feet below. Mena Leptselter, aged 20 years, and an old lady named Culbertson were badly inured, and it is thought will die. A number of others sustained severe bruises, but were not seriously hurt.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 19.--For several days the church people of this city have been greatly exercised over the posters of a burlesque company, put up preliminary to the troupe's appearance.
OTTAWA, May 19.--The Government is enforcing the law passed early this session respecting the importation of articles manufactured in the United States by prison labor.
LONDON, May 19.--The second Spring meeting at Newmarket opened to-day. The race for the Newmarket Spring Handicap Plate of 200 sovereigns was won by Gen. Owen Williams's 5-year-old b. h. Nautilus...
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20.--The Louisvilles put their reserve pitcher, Mays, in the box today, and the Brooklyns enjoyed what the boys call a "picnic."
PITTSBURG, May 20.--The annual statement of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad was presented to-day at the meeting of the stockholders.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 20.--The Commercial Gazette to-day, referring to Gen. Beatty's statement that Senator Sherman's candidacy for the United States Senatorship was an amiable fiction and that he would not serve if elected, says: "Senator Sherman says, in a letter before us, dated March 22. 'I have concluded to allow my name to be canvassed with the rest and to accept if elected.'"
The general meeting of the AmericanInstitute of Electrical Engineers was held yesterday at the house of the American Society of Civil Engineers, at No. 127 East Twenty-thirdstreet.

LONDON, May 21.--The papers are unanimous in the opinion that the holding of the Guards at Alexandria on their way home from Suakin is due to a hitch in the negotiations with Russia. The Colonial troops en route via the Red Sea have also been ordered to stop at Aden.

Chief Purroy, of the Second Battalion, yesterday called the attention of the Fire Commissioners to the gallant conduct of Fireman Gustave Fuhrmann, of Hook and Ladder Company No. 6, in saving from injury and probable death Maria Sullivan, at a fire at No. 82 Mulberrystreet on the night of the 12th last.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 9.--The reporters for several days have been trying to get at the real causes which have led to the retirement of Senator Fair from the Nevada Bank.
Mr. Daly is not yet through with the Chicago play pirates who have been trying to capture the privilege of playing another adaptation of the German farce from which "A Night Off" was made.
MONTREAL, May 20.--The preliminary examination of the two men, Hall and Fox, who attempted to negotiate forged circular notes with the banks here, was begun to-day.

OTTAWA, May 20.--The Government has decided to hand Riel over to the civil authorities to be dealt with. The Minister of Militia says to-night that Gen. Middleton will hold him prisoner pending instructions from Ottawa, which will be sent this week. The Government do not appear to have decided yet when the trial shall take place.

PARIS, Texas, May 20.--S.P. Holmes, who fatally stabbed his wife and killed his sisterin-law, Mrs. Tighe, and Prof. Youmans on the night of the 18th inst., was captured in Delta County last night and was lodged in jail here.

The new Administration has acquitted itself well in two important international tasks which it was suddenly called upon to perform. Hardly had it come into power when the revolution on the isthmus and the rebellion in the Northwest demanded prompt military measures on its part.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 20.--The steamer Alert is being prepared for a Hudson's Bay voyage. Lieut. Gordon, R.N., who will command her, expects to get off early next week. Stores sufficient for more than a year will be taken to provide against any emergency.
The terms of office of District Attorney Tenney, of Brooklyn, expired to-day. It is expected that his successor will be appointed during the present week.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 20.--Clarence H. Carpenter has made a personal assignment to Horatio A. Hunt, Cashier of the American National Bank. Mr. Carpenter was lately in company with Edmund Carpenter in the lumber business, and the present embarrassment is in his individual affairs before entering this partnership. The liabilities are reported to amount to $75,000. The assets are small.
ALBANY, May 20.--The Governor has appointed the following days for hearings on the bills now before him:

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 20.--A peculiar and fatal malady is reported at Langworthy, Jones County. It begins with a slight sore throat, the inflammation spreading to the lungs and thence to the spine, when death soon ensues. The local doctors are much perplexed.
The opening day of the season was celebrated on the Williamsburg Athletic Club Grounds yesterday.

Assistant Bishop H.C. Potter has written a letter to the committee having in charge the preparations for a church mission to be held in this city during the coming Autumn, expressing his deep interest in and approbation of the the proposed mission.
WASHINGTON, May 20.--The term of Collector Robertson will have been finished in about a month.

CHICAGO, May 20.--An Englishman calling himself H.S. Strong, well dressed and apparently about 50 years old, presented himself this morning at the Canadian Bank of Commerce, and asked that letters of credit or the National Bank of Scotland, Glasgow, calling for $7,000 be cashed for him.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 20.--The police have not yet identified the jewelry found upon the person of the negro who was arrested in a pawnshop this morning after a hard fight.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 20.--An injunction was yesterday asked by Lehnen Bateman, of New-York, who claim to own the play of "The Romany Rye," to restrain W.H. Lytell and W.S. Hawkins from producing the play here.
Margaret Moen, 19 years of age, was found sick yesterday with typhus fever at her home, No. 231 Mulberry-street. She was taken to the Riverside Hospital.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 20.--The Second Reformed Church in this city was well filled this evening with many friends of the Theological Seminary of the Reformed Church of America, who listened to the graduating exercises of the Class of '85.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 20.--The Hon. John Arnot, of Elmira, has telegraphed to Superintendent Foster, in this place, that Charles B. Hagadorn, of Elmira, a former Cornellian, will receive the appointment to West Point from this Congressional district. This decision is on the ground of the ineligibility of Kelsey on account of non-residence. Edward E. Clark will be alternate.

ALBANY, May 20.--The point has been raised that the Brooklyn Bridge bill, which was passed in such a hurry on the last day of the last session, is so defective that the Governor cannot sign it, even if he was disposed to. The bill could not be passed so long as it contained the fifth section, allowing the Brooklyn extension to be built.

A substantial three-story mansion with a front of brownstone is situated at No. 49 South Oxford-street, Brooklyn, and surrounded by residences of men of wealth. Until yesterday it was occupied by Arthur E. Marsh, who on Tuesday left New-York so suddenly and unexpected ly for Europe on the steamship Nevada. About 1 P.M yesterday a Sheriff's Deputy took charge ...
The usual semi-weekly conference between Drs. Douglas and Shrady took place yesterday afternoon at Gen. Grant's house. The throat of the General was examined. The doctors found no marked change.

A representative of the Harpers said yesterday that cases of the Old Testament would be received by the firm at one minute past midnight this morning from the Custom House, and would probably reach the publication office in a quarter of an hour.

A scheme for the reorganization of the Postal Telegraph Company has been prepared, and invitations to a conference have been sent to the holders of bonds that have been in default since Feb. 1.
The members of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church resolved last night, without a dissenting vote, to invite the Rev. William F. Price, of Lynn, Mass., to become their Pastor.

Fifty years ago the present Lord Houghton went with Arthur Hallam, as all other inquiring young men went at that time, to visit the seer on the brow of Highgate Hill. "Go to America," Coleridge said to them; "you will hear of me there.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 20.--Frank L. Akerley, a former Poughkeepsie lawyer, who has been a fugitive from justice for some time, was arrested at Oswego last night by Deputy Sheriff Shields, brought here, and lodged in jail on an indictment charging him with forgery in the second degree, the complainant being his aunt.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 20.--The programme of the Commercial Convention has been carried out as outlined in THE TIMES, although it must be confessed that the delegates are not the foremost men of the States represented.

DENVER, Col., May 20.--A special to the Tribune Republican from Santa Fe says: "Geronimo and 50 Chiricahua bucks broke away from the San Carlos Reservation Sunday night and headed for the Sierra Madre Mountains, in Mexico.
ALBANY, May 20.--There are no essential points of difference between the Census bill vetoed by Gov. Hill and the one which Gov. Tilden signed 10 years ago.

QUEBEC, May 20.--An interesting case has just been passed upon by the Court of Appeals here and now goes to the Privy Council. In 1788 Alexander Fraser, of the Hudson Bay Company, married an Indian maiden named Angelique Meadows.
The Norwegian bark Aurora, Capt. Koss, which arrived late Tuesday night, brought the crew of the bark R.W. Merriam, which was abandoned off the Banks of Newfoundland after having run into an iceberg.

The Life-saving Service of the Fire Department is to be extended to the engine companies in view of the fact that they are ahead of the hook and ladder trucks at all fires, and lives are generally lost, if lost at all, very soon after the first alarm is received.

RICHMOND, Va., May 20.--In the Cluverius trial this morning the court ruled that it would exclude the evidence of Mrs. Dickinson and little Willie Dickinson as to the superscription on the envelope containing the letter received by Lillian, in which she was asked to come to Richmond, on the ground that the witnesses were not experts.
ST. LOUIS, May 20.--There was a terrific explosion of a gasometer at the St. Louis Gas Works to-day, two men being instantly killed and another badly injured.

It has recently been proposed that the police should be provided with roller skates, to be worn when on duty. The advocates of this scheme maintain that a policeman could skate over the sidewalk much faster than a burglar or cashier could run, and could thus easily overtake a flying criminal.

For several hours yesterday the special committee of the United States Senate who are investigating the subject of the regulation of inter-State commerce listened to members of the Railroad Commission of this State.
MONTREAL, May 20.--Wong Chin Foo, the Chinese editor, had quite an exciting adventure here last evening.
The Trustees of the John F. Slater Fund for the Education of Freedmen held their annual meeting yesterday.

Peter Watson, a carpenter, at the Coroner's inquest in the State-street factory disaster, in Brooklyn, testified yesterday that he had been employed by Agent Abbott on April 20 to take the flooring up on the first floor and to do any other carpenter work which might be found necessary in the repairing.
The revised version of the Old Testament appears this morning. It is here proposed to give an account of its general character.

The committee appointed at the last Republican State Convention to prepare a new plan of representation for future conventions met at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday to consider the plan proposed by Senator MILLER.
Ex-Secretary of State Frederick T. Frelinghuysen died at his residence, on Park Place, Newark, at 5:30 yesterday afternoon. All his family were present with the exception of Mrs. Davis.
PARIS, May 20.--Victor Hugo is worse this evening. His right lung is congested. Morphia is being injected to alleviate his sufferings.

A meeting was held on Tuesday evening at the residence of Henry M. Le-Count, at NewRochelle, by the resident members of the Huguenot Society of America to make arrangements for a public meeting of all the Huguenot descendants of the town.

AMSTERDAM, N. Y., May 20.--James Adams, a prominent young man of Fort Plain, plunged into the Erie Canal last evening and drowned himself. He first plunged in with all his clothes on but was rescued. A few minutes later when unobserved he plunged in a second time, and before he could be rescued he was drowned. He was 29 years old and is believed to have been insane.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 20.--At a meeting of the Yale Corporation to-day the Executors of the late Pelatieh Perit, of New-Haven, who died in 1864, paid over the sum of $15,000, being a bequest by Mr. Perit, which has just become payable, and which is devoted by his will to the endowment of some academical Professorship. The corporation has applied the gift to the endowment of the Professorship of Political and Social Science.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--In the races at Belmont Park to-day Balanche won the 2:34 class race, taking the second, fourth, and fifth heats in 2:27 , 2:25 , and 2:26 . Effie won the first and third heats in 2:28 and 2:27 . Four horses were distanced, and Neill Girl won third money. In the 2:24 class race Dick Organ won in three straight heats in 2:26, ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., May 20.--Capt. John Gonsalves, of this city, was arrested this afternoon by Deputy Marshal F. Galloupe, of Boston, on a charge of violation of the United States transportation laws.
