PITTSBURG, Penn., May 20.--Every morning for the past two years Robert Miller, a ragpicker, has compelled his son Charles to search the streets and ash dumps for rags, and if the boy failed to return with the bag filled he received a beating.

BRADFORD, Penn., May 20.--A shooting affray in the notorious Pig Island neighborhood occurred early this morning. A feud of long standing existed between George Nature and Bob Lane, due to trouble over some woman. Lane called on Nature, and on being admitted fired two shots which took offect in Nature's abdomen. He fell to the floor and died a few minutes later. Lane surrendered himself.
Loder Rose, a commission merchant doing business in New-York and residing with his wife and four children on Garden-street, in Hoboken, hanged himself from the rear balcony of his house yesterday.

A shelf on the first floor of Nelson's torpedo factory, Eldert and Baltic avenues, East New-York, on which was stored a lot of torpedoes, gave way shortly before 9 o'clock last night, and the explosives were dropped with a good deal of force upon the stone flooring underneath.
Five or six hundred delegates were in their seats when President Scharmann called the United States Brewers' Association to order in Terrace Garden yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, May 20.--The leave of absence granted Second Lieut. William H. Sage, Fifth Infantry, has been extended seven days. The Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service will cause 50 recruits to be prepared and forwarded to Fort Sidney, Nebraska, for assignment to the Twenty-first Infantry.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 20.--J.W. Higgins, Postmaster at Ryerson, Greene County, took poison this morning, from the affects of which he died in a few moments. He was a prominent citizen and financially in good shape. His rash act is a mystery.
The Harlem Choral Club will give its third private concert of the season at Association Hall, in Harlem, this evening.

ALBANY, May 20.--Both branches of the Legislature adjourned almost immediately after the reading of their journals. The Assembly adopted Gen. Husted's motion to adjourn until 10:30 o'clock in the morning by a strict party vote.
LONDON, May 20.--The Marquis of Salisbury, speaking this evening at a dinner of Middlesex Tories, said it was now quite evident that diplomacy was useless to stop the ad vance of Russia toward India.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 20.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day, upon application of Edward W. Kinsley, of Massachusetts, Judge Acheson appointed G. Clinton Gardner, of NewYork, Receiver in the suit of Kinsley against the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad Company and the Fidelity Insurance, Trust, and Safe Deposit Company, of Philadelphia. Sussex G. Davis, of Philadelphia, was appointed special Master. The Receiver's bond was fixed at $200,000.
TROY, N.Y., May 20.--On Aug. 31, 1882, James Dennin, a well-known merchant of this city, died leaving real and personal property worth more than $100,000.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., May 20.--The Salvation Army had a grand gathering last night, delegates being present from different counties of the State.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 20.--Announcement was made to-day of the secret marriage of Miss Carrie L. Cook and Albert S. Thayer, of this city, which was solemnized in the village of Geddes Monday last. The bride and groom are quite prominent in society. The groom is a son of Mr. Thayer, a portrait painter.

LONDON, May 20.--Gen. Sir Charles Wilson, who succeeded Gen. Sir Herbert Stewart in the command of the advance corps of the Khartoum relief expedition after the latter was wounded at the zereba battle, has sent in his ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 20.--The greatest race ever run on the Jockey Club course was run to-day for the Clark Stakes, in which Joe Cotton, the winner of the Derby; Biersan, who finished second in the same race, and Troubadour, the crack of Milton Young's stable, came to the post out of the 62 entries.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 20.--The Executive Relief Committee at Plymouth submitted their official report to a meeting of citizens this morning, of which the following is a summary:

TORONTO, May 20.--Mitchell, the man who shot and killed McIntosh at St. Thomas, was sentenced to-day to 10 years' imprisonment. Mitchell caught McIntosh in a compromising position with his wife in her bedroom, and the deed was done at that time. It was proved, however, at the trial, that Mitchell was quite cognizant of the relations between his wife and McIntosh.
A letter from some Sunday school teachers in Yorkville protesting against the Sunday concerts in Central Park was read at the meeting of the Park Commissioners yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--A special dispatch to the Times from Atlantic City says: "Gerald W. Dunne and his handsome wife are wanted at Atlantic City for swindling the Hotel Denis, one of the large Winter hotels, out of $400 for board, and the hackmen, florists, and ...
CHICAGO, May 20.--The Republicans of this city continue to be very jubilant over the re-election of Senator John A. Logan.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 20.--C.W. Hazzard, proprietor of the Daily Republican, at Monongahela City, has resigned his position as Postmaster there after a faithful service of 20 years. His term would not expire until January.

BALTIMORE, May 20.--There was a larger attendance at the races at Pimlico to-day than yesterday. The track was in splendid condition and fast and the races well contested, Biggonnette's victory being especially well received.

The committee appointed to consider Senator Warner Miller's new plan for the election of delegates to future Republican State Conventions met in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. Senator Miller presided.
The indications on the Street yesterday pointed to an early settlement of the question of the Pacific Mail subsidy, the extended contract for which will expire on June 1.
Bondholders representing more than one-third of the first mortgage bonds of the Scioto Valley Railroad Company met yesterday at the office of S. Chittenden, No. 176 Broadway, ...

The jurors that are trying Justus H. Schwab for inciting a riot is Concordia Hall did not go home to their families last night. After eight hours of deliberation and discussion, in which ballot after ballot was taken without reaching an agreement, the key was turned on ...

The regular quarterly meeting of the Association of Collegiate Alumnae was held at Wellesley, Mass., on Saturday afternoon, May 16. This association is composed of the women graduates of different colleges.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20.--George W. Geiles, 35 years of age, employed as a painter in the City Hall, to-day fell from a scaffold in the southern dome, striking his head on the wooden floor 45 feet below. He was instantly killed. He is the fourteenth man who has been killed in the building.

BERLIN, May 20.--It is announced to-day that Emperor William is again indisposed and that owing to his illness King Leopold of Belgium has postponed the visit he intended making on the 21st inst. to thank the Emperor and Prince Bismarck for their assistance in the foundation of the Congo State.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 20.--The advance in the charge for licenses from $40 to $186 for saloons and from $50 to $150 for hotels, which was made by the new Excise Board last Tuesday night, appears likely to cause a desperate fight.
VICKSBURG, Miss., May 20.--The Young Men's Democratic Club of this city, numbering 340 members, held a meeting to-night. The following resolutions were unanimously adopted...
It is the sinners who find the least satisfaction in the revised version.--Philadelphia North American.
The body of Robert E. Odlum, the swimmer, who lost his life by jumping from the East River bridge, lay in Coroner Kennedy's morgue in Pearl-street yesterday.
Mayor Grace is opposed to the Arcade Railroad bill as it passed the Legislature, and has asked Gov. Hill to give him a hearing on the bill before signing it. The Governor has fixed June 5 as the day.
Ship Vanduara, (of Yarmouth, N.S.,) Allen, from London April 20. Bark D.H. Watjen, (Ger.,) Moll, from Liverpool April 9.
HARTFORD, Conn., May 20.--The new 3 per cent. 25-year loan of the State, amounting to $1,749,000, has been awarded to George K. Sistares Sons and Vermilye Co., of New-York, who did par and 876-1000.

A meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last night, but no action was taken concerning the coming international races for the America cup. There are some matters of detail yet to be settled in regard to the terms of the match, about which cable dispatches have been exchanged during the past three of four days.
BOSTON, May 21.--In the State Senate today the bill exempting soldiers from the operation of the Civil Service act was passed to be engrossed by a vote of 19 to 16.
The Assistant Treasurer's office was closed to-day. Mr. E.O. Graves, who was its occupant yesterday, having gone to the Bureau of Engraving and Printing to take charge as chief.

WARSAW, N.Y., May 21.--The citizens of Warsaw are indignant at the Erie Railroad's new management. By that road's new schedule, which took effect May 18, the popular through eastern train, No, 2. which leaves Buffalo for New-York at 5 P.M., reaching the metropolis...
Yesterday the Greek Church celebrated St. Nicholas's Day, and as the officers and men on, board the Russian corvette Strelok are all members of the Orthodox Greek Church they had a gala day.

One of the saddest features in regard to ODLUM'S death is that the man was wasted. Few people had ever heard of him before he made his fatal leap. He had occasionally jumped from various heights into the water, but his jumps were unostentatious and the public was never made to suffer from them.

Although the Mayor's amendment to the new Park bill of 1884 failed to pass the Legislature, a new law, which may affect the payment for the lands to be taken for these parks, has received the sanction of the Governor.
Joseph Munch, 14 years of age, of No. 508 West Forty-fourth-street, fell from the fifth story window of No.75 is Greene-street yesterday afternoon and was killed.
Yale Professors occupy a prominent place in New-Haven's grand list of taxpayers, Some of the figures are: President Noah Porter $31,025:

GUAYMAS, Mexico, May 21.--Gen. Carbo had a bloody engagement with the Yaquis yesterday. Fifty-seven Mexicans were killed and many wounded. The stronghold of the Yaquis was captured. Their loss has not been ascertained.

Justice Walsh's court room, under the City Hall, Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday morning with indignant and excited people when the case of Hugh McCabe, who is charged with having brutally assaulted Dannella Maxwell, a young deaf and dumb girl, was called for examination.
Foster, Livingstone Co., proprietors of an open stock board at No. 69 New-street, suspended yesterday in consequence of their inability to meet certain pressing claims upon them.

The Harlem Choral Club, an organization composed of wealthy residents of upper New-York, gave its third and last private concert for the season last evening in Association Hall, One Hundred and Twenty-ninth-street and Fourth-avenue.
The case of John W. Dolbier, who has been on trial in judge Depue's court at Newark for the last two or three days for killing Policeman Thomas Lyons, was given to the jury yesterday morning.

Charles Busch, at whose hotel, bearing his name, in Hoboken, many persons put up because of its convenience to the wharf of the Hamburg Lino of steamers, is anxious to know what has become of Mrs. G.V. Black. She disappeared on April 23, leaving a trunk and rich wardrobe, which are now packed in the hotel storeroom.
The following letter calling for an investigation into the methods of business at the Mare Island Navy Yard was sent to Commodore Russell on May 11, and is now permitted to be given to the public.

E.W. Goddard, the farmer clerk of Austin Corbin Co., who absconded 13 years ago after having been given a package to register containing $15,000, and who was recently arrested in Minneapolis, was surrendered to the District Attorney yesterday and committed to the Tombs under an indictment 12 years old.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 21.--Nathaniel Sands, held in default of $150,000 bail for judgment against him by the city of New-York for $145,000, and who has been in charge of Sheriff Dann at Norwalk since Thursday, was brought before Judge Phelps, of the Superior Court, in this city, this afternoon, on a writ of habeas corpus to show why bail should not be reduced.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 21.--A heavy cyclone passed over the northwestern outskirts of the city this afternoon travelling eastward. It caused a great waterspout where it struck the river. Roofs were blown off of several houses, and a few people were injured.

BOSTON, Mass., May 21.--The test cases of parties who were arrested yesterday for preaching or holding religious exercises on the Common came up in the Municipal Court to-day and attracted a large crowd.

CAMBRIDGE, May 21.--A great deal has been written and said about the production of "Julius Caesar" by the Shakespeare Club and as is often the case, much of this has been founded on exaggerated rumors and reports. Last Fall the Shakespeare Club was founded for the study of the drama and elocution, under the Presidency of Mr. Jones, the instructor in elocution.

At a meeting of the Brooklyn Excise League in the Lee-Avenue Congregational Church last night the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby, of this city, briefly outlines the provisions of a new law governing the liquor traffic, which, he said, would be printed and hundreds of thousands of copies distributed throughout this State during the coming Summer.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 21.--The steam canal boat Popis, which left this place yesterday on Cayuga Lake, bound for Rochester, sank in 50 fathoms of water, last night, when near Kidder's Ferry.

Louis Francois, who is held for killing his wife at No. 307 Tenth-avenue, was taken from the Twentieth Precinct Station to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning and was remanded for examination to-day.

PRINCETON, May 21.--The annual mass meeting for the election of officers of the College Baseball Association for the ensuing year was held this afternoon. There was no opposition to the following ticket:
The estimable and industrious wife of Orlando E. Jones, the editor of that sprightly Democratic paper the Bodie Evening Miner, is an applicant for Postmistress of Bodie.

In one of last evening's newspapers the author of the report that Judge Barrett's wife had instituted a suit for divorce was quoted as saying that the Graphic had neglected or abandoned him. He is in error.
Mayor Grace, in company with Park Commissioners Crimmins and Beekman, made an extensive tour over the annexed district yesterday.

There are many persons in the State who remember Max Hoffman. He was Secretary of State from 1869 to 1871. He was wrecked by dissipation, and it was not long after the expiration of his term of office that he sank into oblivion. Four of five years ago he died of smallpox in the Evansville Hospital.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 21.--The people of the little town of Paris Roads, near Colliers, on the Pan Handle Railroad, in this county, are excited over a strange epidemic which has broken out among them.
A score of electricians attended the meeting of the Polytechnic Association at Cooper Union last evening and listened to a lecture from A.M.A. Beale on the long distance telephone.

New signs were put in bookstore windows all over the city yesterday announcing that the revised Bible, in 29 different styles of binding, was for sale within. Generally speaking, there was nothing like the demand for the complete book that followed the publication of the revised New Testament.

SAN ANTONIO, Tesas, May 21.--In the Federal court yesterday Potter and McDaniels, the mail robbers and highwaymen, were sentenced to confinement in the chester. (Ill.,) Penitentiary for life. The prisoners received their sentence with smiling bravade.

"I am a trifle afraid of that club," said Manager Mutrie, of the New-Yorks, yesterday, before his men began their first name with the Buffalo players. The New-Yorks are by long odds the stronger players, but in baseball, like other things, history repeats itself. Don't you remember, the Buffalos beat us in our first game last year."

The office of Referee Hamilton Cole was filled yesterday afternoon with the parties to the suit of Freling H. Smith, the Receiver of the Atlantic State Bank, of Brooklyn, for the recovery of $235,000 loaned for account of the Brooklyn bank, Mr. Smith claims, by the Metropolitan National Bank, of this city.

One of the features of college life at Vassar College is the annual excursion on the Hudson tendered by the Junior Class to the Seniors. The destination is always kept a secret until the trip is begun. Yesterday the Mary Powell was chartered for the excursion, and soon ...

LOCKPORT, May 21.--A gang of 100 workmen is engaged in breaking ground on the public square in this city preparatory to the erection of a handsome and spacious Court House and Public Building. It will contain all of the county offices, and will replace the present old and ill-appointed structure on the north side of the square.
Ten days ago the Secretary of the Navy sent to the Commandant of the Mare Island Navy Yard an important letter, which we publish this morning in another column.
MONTREAL, May 21.--The Health Officer of this city has just made the startling discovery that glanders is widespread among the horses in this district and even as far as Quebec.
BOSTON, May 21.--John L. Sullivan and Patsy Shepherd have signed, articles for a four-round glove fight between sullivan and Jack Burke, Marquis of Queensberry rules, scientific points to count.

MADISON, Wis., May 21.--In the Municipal Court yesterday Mrs. Rebecca Merraot, of Baraboo, and Mrs. Margaret M. Cooley, of Mitchell, Dakota, sisters, pleaded guilty to the charge of perjury. They have now each been sentenced to two years in State prison. Each woman when sentenced had an infant in her arms.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., May 21.--A hay famine exists through the Mohawk Valley. Farmers have been obliged to turn out cows to grub the earth for lack of hay. Good hay sells readily at from $17 to $20 per ton. A dealer predicts that $30 will be paid by August.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 21.--The steamed Zealandia, which arrived at noon to-day, brings Sydney advices to April 26 and Auckland advices to May 1. Edward Hanlan, the oarsman, was one of her passengers.

ALBANY, May 21.--The Republicans of the Legislature only partially carried out their programme to-day. Instead of passing the vetoed Census bill and adjourning sine die they only succeeded in ordering the bill to a third reading in the Senate. Then they were compelled because of their want of forethought last Friday to adjourn until to-morrow in order to complete their work.

William Henry Willis and Edward C. Perkins, representing the Calvary (Protestant Episcopal) Church branch of the Church Temperance Society, have sent to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a communication in reference to the following statement in the estimate of the Excise Commissioners of their expenses for the coming year:

Yesterday a deed, by which Mrs. A.T., Stewart Converys the cathedral, See house, and the St. Paul's school, at Garden City, to the corporation of the Cathedral of the Incarnation for $1 and other good reasons, was placed on record in the Queen's County Clerk's office at Jamaica.
BERLIN, May 21.--Emperor William was confined to his apartments to-day with a cold. The Crown Prince will represent the Emperor in the Spring parades at Berlin and Potsdam.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 21.--The following statement in regard to Riel's citizenship is made on the best authority: "Riel took an active part late in 1882 or early in 1883 in the Montana Territorial elections, having become an American citizen there.

The steamship Moruca, Capt. Bradford, from Trinidad, arrived at the bar at 6:15 last night. She had on board the Captain and seven of the crew of the German brig S. Suppicich, which foundered on May 7 off Sable Island. The Suppicich was loaded with pitch, and was bound from Trinidad for Bremerhaven. One of the shipwrecked crew was left at St. Kitts.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21.--Marshal Henry Auer, of New-Straitsville, Ohio, in a quarrel with Albert Guest at that place to-day, was shot by the latter several times in different parts of the body and he cannot re cover. One shot missed Mr. Auer and hit a boy, aged 11 years, 50 yards away, passing through his body and injuring the spine. He cannot recover.

ROUEN, May 21.--The steamship Isere, with Bartholdi's statue of "Liberty Eulightening the World" on board, started to-day for New-York. The departure of the vessel with its valuable cargo was made the occasion of quite a demonstration, all the civil and military authorities of the city assembling at the pier to witness the event.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 21.--Allen Herbert, (colored.) who stabbed Henry Everett (colored) to death two months ago, was to-day sentenced to be hanged on June 26. Herbert appealed to the Supreme Court.
The Rev. Dr. James McCosh, President of Princeton College, gave entertainment and instruction to a company of ladies and gentlemen by a talk on "Higher Education" at No. 578 Fifth-avenue last night.
MONTREAL, May 21.--The right of a father to kiss his daughter is not often disputed, but for that very offense a man named Morgan was to-day fined $2 and costs.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., May 21.--A Hungarian named Thomas Kiofck, also known as Krafteck, employed as a loborer at the Powell furnaces, near Saxton, was yesterday afternoon shooting off a toy cannon, improvised from a piece of gaspipe.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 21.--The will of William W. Smith, filed in the probate office yesterday, gives his whole estate, valued at $25,000, to the American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions for the education of colored men in Africa.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., May 21.--Great excitement was created to-day in oil circles by the Emsworth well, reports of which broke the advance.

BALTIMORE, May 21.--Three weeks ago a theatrical firm of this city went to New-York to engage an actress for the leading role in a production of the "Naiad Queen." Miss Eily Coghlan was selected, and contracted for the Summer season at $30 a week.

It is pretty plain that Gov. HILL will have to sign a census bill substantially like that which he vetoed at the regular session or accept the responsibility of defeating the enumeration required by the Constitution for the present year.

PITTSBURG, May 21.--The house No. 69 Webster-avenue was the scene of a double tragedy this afternoon. Frank Bobbert, a young tailor, aged 16 years, shot and killed , Lizzie Lippech, a 4-year-old girl, and then committed suicide.

There are about 2,000 young boys and girls in the New-York Catholic Protectory in West Chester, and the attention of the management has recently been called to the question of relief in case of fire breaking out there.

At the last weekly meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, held in the theatre of the University of London, under the Presidency of Lord Aberdare, a letter was read announcing the ascent of Mount Roraima, in British Guiana, by Mr. Everard im Thurn, and some notes on the journey were subsequently communicated by Mr. H.J. Perkins.
WASHINGTON, May 21.--A delegation representing the Grand Army of the Republic of the Department of Pennsylvania and the Veterans' Rights Union called on the President to-day.

James McQuade was convicted of robbery in the second degree, yesterday, in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions. An old Irishman named Michael Lyons, who lives at No. 97 Madison-street, testified that on Sunday morning, May 10, he met a man whose name he did not know, who asked him to go and get a drink.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-day for the first time disclosed the route by which it purposes to get into this city and make a through connection to New-York by way of the Reading Railway.
FREDONIA, Ohio. May 21.--The gang of thieves who have for some time infested Central Ohio broke into the country store of James Connor at Burton.

A match between August Schmidt, the Swiss wrestler, and John McMahon was announced to take place at the Germania Assembly Rooms last night. About 50 people assembled before 8:30 o'clock to see the contest, and waited till after 10 before anything happened.

LANSING, Mich., May 21.--The bill to allow the minority of stockholders in joint stock companies to have a representation on the Boards of Directors passed the Senate this morning over the Governor's veto. The bill had already passed the House over the veto.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 21.--An attempt to escape from the parish prison and release 300 prisoners was betrayed last night by Pat Ford, who is under death sentence for the Murphy murder.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--Secretary Whitney had a long talk with Mr. John Roach to-day over the last trip of the Dolphin, when Mr. Roach repeated the explanations he has hitherto given to the press for the heated crankpin and the failure to comply with the contract.
LONDON, May 21.--At the York Spring meeting, which opened to-day, the Great Northern Handicap was won by W.I. Anson's 5-yearold b.h. Chiselhurst.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 21.--Charles F. McDermott, a wealthy mining operator and former President of the California Safe Deposit and Trust Company, in this city, is charged with having swindled John T. Bradley and other late shareholders of the Caborca Mine, in Sonora, Mexico, out of a large sum of money.

When anything goes wrong in the government of the District of Columbia the disposition almost invariably is to get rid of complaint by concealing the cause of it. An instance of the sort was brought to light to-day.

PARIS, May 2.--This is the time for the familiar and spontaneous charitable eruption to appear in high life circles. On Wednesday all those who were willing to spend a few louis to see the grandes dames of the day were privileged to do so, and they could with very little ingenuity find means of conversing with these fashion ...

PORT JERVIS, May 21.--Last Sunday morning a party of three young men, W.P. Hall and two brothers named Westfall, had a lively encounter with a lot of rattlesnakes and blacksnakes at Rose's Switch, about six miles west of this village. The locality is wild and romantic.

The St. George's Glee Club, a recently organized quartet of male singers, gave its first concert at Chickering Hall last evening. The club includes an alto, a first and second tenor, and a bass, and its members are by name Messrs. W. Mahoney, H.R. Humphries, E.H. Dexter, and E. Cholmeley-Jones.

James O'Neil, of No. 40 Congress-street, Brooklyn, was arrested about three weeks ago for the betrayal of Sarah Lawler, a girl 19 years old, of No. 102 Warren-street. O'Neil, who is 19 years old, was acquitted. John M. Graham, of No. 162 Columbia-street, her brother-in-law, believed in O'Neil'a guilt and swore that he would have revenge.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 21.--Cattle owners in this county are all alarmed over a fresh outbreak of contagious pieuro-pneumonia in, two large herds in Brandywine and Christiana Hundreds.
PARIS, May 21.--Prince Jerome Napoleon (Plon Plon) is ill. Victor Hugo passed the night fairly well. His condition is unchanged.
The men most willing to take risks are those who have nothing to lose.--New-Orleans Picayune.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 21.--An unexpected action of the National Commercial Convention before its adjournment to-day was the adoption of a resolution calling for the temporary suspension of silver coinage.
A large audience attended, at Chickerering Hall, yesterday afternoon, the annual entertainment given by the pupils of St. Mary's Academy, Nos. 229 and 231 East Broadway.

CHANDLER, more generally known as "BILL;" nor will this depression be relieved by the circumstance that ex-Senator ...
MONTREAL, May 21.--Mr. Edmund Shephard, proprietor of the Toronto News, arrived here yesterday to answer to a charge of criminal libel brought against him by Major Dugas, of the Sixty-fifth Regiment.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 21, via Galveston.-- The Diario, the official Government journal, this evening contains a letter from James Sullivan, special agent here of the Mexican National Railroad Company, addressed to the Minister of Public Works, in which it is said that ...
A petition was posted in the Cotton Exchange yesterday asking the managers to dispense with one of the two daily calls for print cloths.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 21.--The iron workers to-day changed their base of operations and decided on a move which will likely cause a speedy settlement and prevent a general strike, which would throw out of work at least 300,000 men.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 21.--The anniversary exercises of the Yale Theological Seminary were held in Battell Chapel this morning. President Porter presided.

LONDON, May 22.--The Morning Post claims to have learned that the stoppage of the Guards at Alexandria was not due to a hitch in the negotiations with Russia, but to the discovery by Sir Evelyn Baring that there was to be an outbreak of the natives at Cairo, fomented ...

Just before the close of business yesterday a rumor was sprung on Wall-street to the effect that the Pennsylvania, Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, ana West Shore Railroads had mutually agreed to restore rates to a paying basis, and that the New-York Central,which had ...

CHICAGO, May 21.--The celebrated Mackin-Gallagher case entered upon a new phase to-day, and it now depends upon the action of the Supreme Court of the United States whether the verdict found against these fine workers several months ago will stand.

At the annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters yesterday, at No. 156 Broadway, the following officers for the current year were elected: D.A. Heald, of the Home Company, of New-York.

Car No. 204 of the Third-avenue line and car No. 77 of the Belt line came into collision yesterday afternoon at the crossing at Third-avenue and Fifty-ninth-street. Both cars were filied with passengers, who were considerably shaken by the collision.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 21.--The State Department of Agriculture has received reports covering every county in the State. The weather during the month of April was very favorable for farming operations and work progressed satisfactorily. Lands have been better prepared than usual, and the growing crops are in proper condition to be fully benefited by a favorable season.

The seventh game of lacrosse this season in the tournament for the Oelrichs Cup was played on the St. George's Cricket Ground, at Hoboken, yesterday. The contestants were the teams of the New-York Club and Stevens Institute.
WASHINGTON, May 21.--Important action has been taken by the Department of State, modifying, in the following respects, the instructions sent by it to its diplomatic representatives abroad:
WASHINGTON, May 21, 1885. The President this afternoon appointed D.V. O'Leary to be Postmaster at Albany. N.Y., vice W. H. Craig, commission expired.

Mrs. S.B. Nelson, a wealthy widow, who lives at No.47 West Twenty-fifth-street, has for years been in the habit of visiting private and public charitable institutions, as well as of spending much of her income in charity. About two months ago she visited the almshouse on Blackwell's Island, in company with the Rev. Mr. French.

At about 7 o'clock last evening attendants at Yates's Hotel, No.105 South-street, heard a pistol shot, fired apparently in a room on the second floor occupied by John Brennan, a laborer employed about the fish market opposite.
This is said to be a capital year for trout in Connecticut waters, and sundry folks are citing this as evidence of the wisdom of trout culture by the State.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 21.--The seventh day's meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club was interfered with by rain which fell just before the "Merchants' Stake" was run, making a heavy track and causing the defeat of the favorite, Modesty, by Favor, a result that was disastrous to the "plungers," who were sure the mare would win.

RICHMOND, Va., May 21.--The first witness examined this morning in the Cluverius murder trial was D.V. Morton, Paying Teller at the Planters' National Bank. He testified that the prisoner presented a check at his bank on March 13.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 21.--The Rev. Thomas O'Flaherty has lived at his country residence, a few miles from here, on the shore of Skaneatales Lake, for the last 12 years. His nephews, Vincent O'Flaherty, aged 16, and Fred W. O'Flaherty, aged 14, have lived with him for about five years preparing for the priesthood.

LONDON, May 21.--In the lobbies of Parliament to-night there are renewed rumors of dissensions in the Cabinet, chiefly in connection with the renewal of the Irish Crimes act and modifications of the budget.

Jacob Kemp, an old man who lived at No. 124 Siegel-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, early last evening took a dose of Paris green. He was removed to St. Catherine's Hospital, where he died soon after his reception. Business troubles are supposed to be the cause of his suicide.

Dr. James S. Sherman, whose office is at No.251 Broadway, was arrested yesterday by United States Deputy Marshal Bible, on a charge of sending obscene matter through the mails. Dr. Sherman advertises to cure hernia and sends out a pamphlet with illustrations which are not thought proper for general circulation by Anthony Comstock.

The Directors of the Northern Pacific Railroad discussed the matter of the Oregon Railway and Navigation lease yesterday, but took no definite action upon it. Persons prominently connected with the Union Pacific Road and others connected with the Northern Pacific say that those two companies are in perfect harmony regarding the Railway and Navigation lease.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 21.--To-day witnessed the interment in the tomb of the order, at the old St. Louis Cemetery, of a distinguished colored woman--Mother Josephine Charles, founder of the Roman Catholic order of the Sisters of the Holy Family. Josephine was the daughter of a German father and a free mulatto woman, born in this city in 1816.
The will of Frederick E. Unbekant, the Colonel of the Eleventh Regiment, was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The instrument is dated Feb. 25, 1885.

BALTIMORE, May 21.--Heward Cooper, the negro convicted yesterday of an assault on Miss Katic Gray, of Baltimore County, was this morning sentenced by Judge Stewart to be hanged at such time as the Governor may appoint.

ALBANY, N.Y., May 21.--A granddaughter of De Witt Clinton to-day made application for pecuniary aid to the State Department. In a letter to Controller Chapin Miss Julia Clinton Jones, who is living with her brother in Lathrop,

Mr. Joseph Ramsden, a wealthy manufacturer of Manchester, England, arrived in this city on last Monday on the Cunard steamer Gallia, which is commanded by Capt. Murphy. He came to this country for the benefit of his health, and put up at a hotel on Broadway.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 21.--The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church began its session this morning in the First Presbyterian Church.
WASHINGTON, May 21.--The following is a synopsis of sundry decisions rendered by the Treasury Department in customs cases during the past week:

PHILADELPHIA, May 21.--The annual report of Secretary George W. Cope, of the American Iron and Steel Association, has just been completed, and contains important statistics in regard to the material interests of the country during the past year.

COLLINSVILLE, Ill., May 21.--The Rev. J. R. Reasoner, Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, committed suicide this morning by shooting himself through the temple. The act was doubtless committed while Mr. Reasoner was laboring under a temporary fit of insanity. Mrs. Reasoner, who had been visiting in Ohio, arrived 15 minutes after her husband died.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 21.--During a heavy thunderstorm which prevailed yesterday afternoon near Cecilton, Md., lightning struck a two-horse wagon in which Messrs. Coston and Foulkner, well-known citizens of the First District of Cecil County, were riding. Mr. Coston and both of the horses were killed.

Many new delegates who had just arrived from the South and West attended the Brewers' Convention at Terrace Garden yesterday. President Scharmann called the body to order an hour earlier than on the previous day, and the business was promptly taken up and finished before 1 o'clock.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 21.--The Bennett-Douglass iron sloop yacht Priscilla was successfully launched from the yard of the Harlan Hollingsworth Company to-day.

An article is going the rounds of the press to the effect that Mr. Edward Parsons, of New-York, recently lost a package of bonds valued at $9,000, and that on its being found and restored to him paid the finder $20. Mr. Parsons is quite well known in Savannah.

The General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen has entered on its centennial year in a flourishing condition. The ninety-ninth annual report of the society, which has just been issued, shows an excess of assets over liabilities of $669,847 97.

CHICAGO, Ill., May 21.--The verdict in a peculiar lawsuit was announced this morning. The will of John Trinler, a suicide and attempted wife murderer, bequeathed to the children of George Trinler, a brother, living in New-Albany, Ind., $13,000 in bonds, a mortgage for $1,000, and notes upon property in New-Albany, and also four shares of stock of the Merchants' National Bank of Louisville.

Miss Clara Louise Kellogg will enter upon a concert tour under the management of Major J.B. Pond in early June. He company is to include Mr. Whitney Mockridge, tenor: Mr. F. Morawski, basso: Miss Ollie Torbett, violinist, and one or two other artists.

When the jury in the case of Justus Schwab left the Court of Oyer and Terminer Wednesday afternoon seven of them were convinced that he was guilty. Four were certain that he incited the Concordia Hall riot. Three had made up their minds that he was guilty merely of having unlawfully disturbed the progress of the Socialistic meeting held there Feb. 2 last.

CHICAGO, May 21.--The tracks of the Chicago and Evanston Railroad are now laid from Kinzie-street, just north of the tracks of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company, to Calvary Cemetery, a distance of nearly 10 miles, and were formally opened to general passenger business to-day.

On Wednesday the Commercial Convention at Atlanta listened to a careful argument from one of the most able bimetallists in the United States, Mr. S. DANA HORTON, of Ohio, in favor of the suspension of silver coinage.
Although only 15 years old, Philip Geis, of No. 1,023 Flushing-avenue, Brooklyn, served as bartender in the saloon of George Durst in Evergreen-avenue.

Gen. Grant felt better yesterday morning and he took a drive in the Park. This did not have a beneficial effect, however, and he spent a very restless afternoon. His throat felt so badly that he discontinued, after a short time, an attempt at dictation.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., May 21.--Homer E. Smith, a prominent and well-to-do former of Middleport, Niagara County, agen 67, committed suicide yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21.--The body of Prof. Odium, who was killed by jumping from the Brooklyn bridge, arrived in this city to-day and will be buried to-morrow afternoon in Mount Olivet Cemetery.

Simon Sterne spoke at length yesterday before the special committee of the United States Senate on inter-State commerce in regard to what he thought should be done to insure the public fair dealing from the railroads.
The Harrall Asheroft Manufacturing Company, dealers in mechanics' tools, of No. 20 Warren-street, has failed. The factory is at Arlington. N.J., and the property there is mortgaged for over $13,000.
The creditors of the American Theatre Building and Managing Company met yesterday morning at the Lyceum Theatre, Mr. Brent Good, President of the company, presented two propositions to the creditors.

As illustrating the diversity of opinion among critics as to proper methods of punctuation, the story has often been told of an author who wrote his book and had it printed without punctuation, and then supplied a page at the close with punctuation marks for each reader to use according to his own taste. A few particulars about this rare book may interest our readers.

LONDON, May 21.--In the House of Commons this afternoon the Marquis of Hartington, Secretary for War, in reply to a question by Sir Stafford Northcote, stated that it was not thought by the Government desirable to give the reasons for the detention of the Guards at Alexandria.

TROY, N.Y., May 21.--The jury in the Dennin will case this afternoon answered the interrogatories submitted to them by finding that the testator was of sound mind and memory, was not unduly influenced, and that the will was legally made. This verdict gives the estate of $75,000, except $1,000, to the widow.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 21.--The Grand Jury to-day indicted the Boston and Albany Railroad for running Sunday trains.
Ex-County Auditor Francis A. Biggs, of Brooklyn, is contesting the will of his mother, Mrs. Charlotte Angus, who died last April, leaving an estate of $50,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 21.--As the time for the holding of the Republican State Convention approaches the choice that will be made of the nominee for Governor becomes more and more uncertain. Two weeks ago-Gen. John Beatty, of this city, was reasonably-sure of the nomination.

Curator Zachos, of the Cooper Union, announces that the number of pupils this year entering every department has been 4,208. Of this number 531 have attended the day industrial art classes for young women.

CINCINNATI, May 21.--A boy carrying a large can of benzine up a rickety elevator in Sullivan's printing establishment let the can strike the floor heavily. Whether the shock caused the can to explode, or some part of it gave way, allowing the contents to run out, is not known, but in a moment there was nearly a Square rod of the leaping up from the floor ...
The Seventh-Street (formerly "Bowery Village") Methodist Episcopal Church, of which the Rev. A.C. Morehouse is Pastor, will hold reunion services on Sunday.

VICKSBURG, Miss., May 21.--At a meeting of the City Council held last night the proposition submitted by the Louisville, New-Orleans and Texas Railway Company to locate its machine shops at this place was considered and unanimously adopted.

WASHINGTON, May 21.--Secretary Whitney is considering the advisability of changing the color of the helmets of the marines and the leggins used by sailors when on shore duty. The white helmets and leggins now used would have been good targets for the insurgents during the recent Panama expedition.

The Lyceum Theatre is having a brisk week. On Wednesday night Miss Kate Forsythe had her benefit there, when, in addition to Mr. Mackaye's "Dakolar," some scenes from "The Hunchback" were presented, with Miss Forsythe as Helen and Mr. N.C. Goodwin as Modus.

John Joyce, who on Tuesday last pleaded guilty, in Part II, of the Court of General Sessions, before Judge Cowing, to an indictment for robbery in the first degree, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in the state prison.
A special representation for the benefit of Miss Rose Coghlan was given at Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon in presence of a fairly numerous and very friendly audience.

BATIMORE, May 21.--This was the third day of the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club at Pimlico. There was a much larger attendance and greater interest in the events than on either of the preceding day's. The grand stand was much better filled and the pool lawn was thronged. There were five very good races, and the winners were Eva K., Thomasia, Telie Doe, Colonel Sprague, and Emerson.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., May 22.--The family of Frederick D. Gritman, of this city, consisting of himself, wife, and two daughters, were taken suddenly ill after eating a dinner of corned beef and spinach.

TUCSON, Arizona, May 22.--News from Clifton states that the Apaches who left their reservation have gone in the direction of the Mogollon Mountains. As the settlers along that route have not been warned it is feared that many murders and outrages will be committed.

The second annual report of the NewYork Skin and Cancer Hospital, situated in East Thirty-Fourth-street, with a branch on Fordham Heights, indicates that the institution is in a flourishing condition.
WASHINGTON, May 22, 1885. The Hon S.S. Cox, recently appointed Minis ter to Turkey, qualified at the Department of State to-day. He will leave New-York for his new post of duty about June 17.
Among the passengers of the White Star steamship Adriatic, which sails to-day for Liverpool, are Mrs. G.W. Appleton, Col. W.L. Scott, and the Rev. W. R. Alger.

The morning session of the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce yesterday was devoted to hearing Mr. George R. Blanchard, the former Vice-President of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company, who in a talk extending over two hours gave the committee the results of his long experience as a railroad official.
There has been some correspondence during the last few days between representatives of the Pennsylvania Railroad, the West Shore, the Lackawanna, and the Erie-regarding the restoration of rates.

The unusual scarcity of hay this Spring is attributed to the unusually large consumption during the long and severe Winter. The price of hay is steadily advancing, and all that comes into the market finds ready purchasers.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The funeral of Prof. Odlum took place this afternoon, and was attended by many friends of the dead athlete. The house at which the funeral services were held was thronged with people who came to view the body, and a thousand persons blocked the street in the vicinity.

The life of Victor Hugo is as romantic as any story he has told. The early years were eminently so, and there can be no doubt that the peculiar circumstances which surrounded his youth produced great and lasting impressions on his mind.

NEWPORT, R. I., May 22.--Mr. George Peabody Wetmore will be inaugurated Governor of Rhode Island on Tuesday next. The event is looked forward to with a great deal of interest, and it promises to be a red letter day in Newport's history.

The closing concerts of the Church Choral Union were inaugurated by a public rehearsal of "The Creation" yesterday afternoon, the soloists, chorus, orchestra, and audience assembling in the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church, at Forty-fifth-street and Madisonavenue, where the evening concert also took place.

Capt. Charles Drake of the tug Grape shot, found the body of an unknown man in the river off Governor's Island last evening. He towed it to pier No. 1 East River, whence it was taken to the Morgue. The body is that of a man about 35 years old, 5 feet 6 inches in height, dark complexion, and dressed like a workingman.

The first annual report of the Industrial Education Association shows, as an important result of its year's work, a complete organization, composed of practical men and women who are thoroughly in earnest in their efforts to further the cause of industrial education.

While Mrs. Henry B. Taylor, of Highstreet, Newark, was absent on a visit to Mrs. George B. Jenkinson, her mother, Thursday evening, her residence was entered by burglars, who carried away silverware and jewelry valued at $500.
Signor DEPRETIS, the Italian Prime Minister, who is about to withdraw from public life because of his advanced age, will take with him an enviable reputation.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 22.--Up in North Haven Mrs. Beda Button is celebrating her one hundredth birthday. She is the oldest inhabitant of the town, and was born at what is known as the old Bazel Dayton place in 1785.
The crew of the lost German brig S. Suppicich, who arrived late Thursday evening on the steamship Moruca from St. Kitts, landed yesterday and went to the German Consulate.

Richard M. Collins, the commercial note broker, of No. 48 Broad-street, was in the Jefferson Market Police Court again yesterday. Collins is already under $11,000 bail on charges of retaining notes given to him to negotiate.

After talking about Christian duty in the Plymouth Church prayer meeting last evening, the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher told the congregation why he broke off his connection with the New-York and Brooklyn Congregational Association. He left that association, he said,for two reasons.
The "Letters on Society in London, by Count Paul Vasili," will greatly disappoint those readers who looked for something as sparkling and malicious as the diatribes on Berlin society.
WEST CHESTER, Penn., May 22.--The following is a copy of a letter written by George Washington to his nephew, George Steptoe Washington, son of his brother, Col. Samuel Washington.
Mr. John A. McCaull, manager, was under the impression last evening that Mr. Sydney Rosenfeld, author and adapter, was suffering from evaporation of brain.
ALBANY, May 22.--The following address has been issued by the Democratic members of the Legislature to the people of the State:

A magnificent gift has been made to the Case School of Applied Science by Mrs. Laura K. Axtell, of Painesville, sister of the late Levi Kerr, of this city in compliance with a wish expressed by that gentleman before his death.

Representatives of the Brooklyn, Kings, Essex, Elberon, Bedford, and Long Island Bicycle Clubs, to the number of 75, wheeled out of the Flatbush entrance to Prospect Park, Brooklyn, at 8 o'clock last evening.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 22.--The Faculty of Cornell University this evening selected the speakers for the June Commencement as given below.
LONDON, May 22. --The subscriptions to the Pennsylvania It Railroad Company's issue of $4,000,000 4 per cent. gold bonds have already exceeded in London six times the amount of the loan.

The body of the young man who was found on Battle Pass, Prospect Park, with a bullet hole in his head, has been identified as Abram Pomeranz, a Polish Hebrew, who carried on business as a locksmith in a basement at No. l,122 Thirdavenue.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 22.--At the morning session of the Presbyterian Assembly the standing committees were announced. The Rev. H. E. Niles, of New-York, presented a report on ministerial support, which was laid over for discussion.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 22.--A Battleford dispatch of yesterday says: "At sunset to-night Father Cochin and 25 other prisoners bearing a white flag arrived from Poundmaker's Camp with a letter asking upon what terms a surrender would be accepted.

The trial of Jeremiah J. Scanlon, who was charged with sending letters and circulars relating to lotteries through the United States mails, took place before Judge Benedict and a jury in the United States Circuit Court yesterday.

PARIS, May 22.--The French Societe Geographique has received news from the UpperCongo that the large Mohammedan population inhabiting that region, excited probably by stories of El Mahdl's success, have resolved to assert their claims to the centre of Africa.
MONTREAL, May 22.--Mr. Sheppard, proprietor of the Toronto News, was to-day committed to the Queen's Bench for having criminally libeled the officers of the Sixty-fifth Battallon.
"What have you in that package?" was the question put to a Waterbury clergyman on a Saturday afternoon some years ago as he sat in the station awaiting the arrival of a train.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 22.--The managers of the Charter Oak Park have guaranteed a ten-thousand-dollar stake for the 2:20 class race at the Fall circuit meeting, the entries to which have been made by the following parties:
LONDON, May 22.--The House of Commons has adjourned to June 4. Sir Charles Dilke has gone to Dublin to attend the meeting of a commission for housing the poor. He will be the guest of Earl Spencer.

RICHMOND, Va., May 22.--The fifteenth day of the Cluverius murder trial opened this morning with Alfred R. James on the witness stand. He testified to having seen the prisoner three times on March 13.
The St. Stephen's Guild, which has been frequently exposed by the public press and by the State Board of Charities, has adopted a new mode of operation.

A terrible snake story comes from the usually moral and orderly town of Port Jervis. It can hardly be read without a shudder, and it is understood that immediately after its publication the Women's Christian Temperance Union resolved to send a strong committee of workers and an eminent lecturer to Port Jervis without a moment's delay.
The Tammany Committee on Organization met last night and gracefully bowed to the inevitable by passing resolutions approving civil service reform.

PRINCENTON, May 22.--The regular exhibition game between Harvard and Princeton was played on the university grounds to-day. Both teams played with their change batteries. The result was: Harvard. 6; Princeton, 5. Base hits --Harvard, 8; Princeton, 10. Errors--Harvard, 11; Princeton, 11. The first game of the championship series between Harvard and Princeton will be played here to-morrow at 3 P.M.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--A Massachusetts clergyman and his pretty young wife were in court here to-day contending with each other for the possession of their little 6-year-old daughter.

TORONTO, May 22.--There is a threatened strike of all the employes of the Canadian Pacific Railway owing to their inability to obtain back pay. The men have not been paid for the past two months. The company has not yet received the much-sought-for financial aid from the Canadian Government this year, and they have no money with which to pay their employes.

Ex-Congressman Lamieson, of Lima, Ohio, is an old and intimate friend of Cal Brice, the millionaire, who has grown up in a night, like Jack's heaven-reaching bean stalk. Said he to-night: "About five years ago Brice wasn't worth a dollar; now he has made two or three fortunes, lost enough to build the new national library, and has $5,000,000 left.

GALVESTON. Texas, May 22.--Jasper Rhodes, a mulatto aged 35 years, was hanged at 12:30 to-day in the jail in this city for the murder of his wife in October last. Only a limited number of persons witnessed the execution. The doomed man mounted the scaffold with great firmness. He admitted his guilt.
There was a good attendance at the eighth annual Spring games yesterday of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute.
Inspector Byrnes appeared in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday with "Hungry Joe," the bunko steerer, who robbed Mr. Joseph Ramsden, a wealthy Englishman, of 50 on Tuesday.

ERIE,Penn., May 22.--Louis Rosenzweig to-day in the Erie County--Court won a suit against the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad, tha jury awarding him $48,000. The plaintiff, who had been ejected from a train near Cleveland, claimed $100,000 for injuries.

CINCINNATI, May 22.--The calamity of yesterday, by which 16 people lost their lives, has brought into strong light the slack manner in which officials who have to do with the law relating to fire escapes have been performing that duty.

The rooms of the New-York Flower Mission, at No. 239 Fourth--avenue, rear, will be open every Monday and Thursday until October for the reception and distribution of flowers to hospitals, asylums, and homes, and or delicacies and supplies to the sick poor in tenement houses.

BUFFALO, May 22.--The stockholders of the Buffalo Coal Company (bituminous) held their annual meeting at Clermont, McKean County, Penn., yesterday. The capital stock is $1,000,000 and nearly every share was voted.
Mr. J.B. Polk is soon to reveal to NewYork playgoers a comedy with the fascinating title of "Mixed Pickles."

PARIS, May 22.--When it became known this morning that death must come to Viotor Hugo in a very few hours Cardinal Guibert, the Archbishop of Paris, sent a special message to the author's residence offering to visit the dying man and administer to him spiritual aid and the rites of the Catholic Church.

A woman between 30 and 35 years old went to the Grand Union Hotel about 8 o'clock Thursday morning and asked for a room. On the card sent to her by the clerk she wrote her name as Miss J. Jones, giving no address. She had no baggage of any kind and paid in advance for the room, which was given her on an upper floor.

BALTIMORE, May 22.--To-day closed the Spring meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club, and it was a day of discomfort. The track was fetlock deep in mud and water owing to the rain, and the pool lawn was wet and muddy.
RICHMONDVILLE, N.Y., May 22.--In this village resides an aged and respected lady who has two silver plates that were purchased and inscribed to be placed on her coffin.

At a four hours' secret session of the Police Commissioners yesterday there was much discussion over the application of a number of citizens residing in the Twenty-ninth Precinct for permission to present a testimonial to Capt. Williams.
MONTREAL, May 22.--The Bank of Mentreal is having several of its employes shadowed by private detectives, as it appears Bernard, the defaulting clerk, had several accomplices.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--Capt. John B. Parkey Tenth Infantry, has been appointed to act as inspector on certain camp and garrison equipage at the cavalry recruiting rendezvous, Baltimore, reported an requiring the action of an inspector, and for which Capt. Stevens T. Norvell, Tenth Cavalry, recruiting officer, is responsible.
Richardson pitched a strong game for the New-York Club against the Buffalo team yesterday, and as a result the local players won by a score of 9 to 4. Richardson seems to improve in every game.

Pauline Schackel, age 23, formerly a servant at No. 136 Madison-avenue, was sentenced yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions, by Recorder Smyth, to five years in the penitentiary for stealing silk dresses and a diamond pin, valued in all at $425, from the place of her employment on April 24.

TORONTO, May 22.--A large number of delegates from all parts of the United States arrived in Toronto to-day to attend the Right Worthy Grand Lodge of Good Templars of the United States and Canada, in annual session here Monday next.

BUFFALO, May 22.--Many of the Buffalo bucket shop gamblers are bemoaning losses they claim to have sustained by the sudden suspension of the local branch of Skidmore, Brown Co.'s office in the Hayen Building.
Early yesterday morning John Hanley, a night watchman, discovered three men engaged in breaking open the safe in the office of Schultz's lumber yard at the foot of Fifthstreet, Hoboken.
While New-York's good citizens were in the land of dreams yesterday morning a party of sporting men assembled in an up-town hall to witness a glove fight to a finish.

PANAMA, May 22, via Galveston.--The last detachment of marines left Panama this morning for Aspinwall, under command of Capt. Cochrane. Those too sick to travel were sent to the hospital. The First Battalion of marines will sail for New-York next Monday on the steamer Acapuico.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 22.--The attendance at the eighth day's meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club was small, owing to the threatening weather. The track was muddy and heavy, though the racing was interesting and exciting.
PITTSBURG, May 22. -- Twelve people have fallen prey within the last two days to the epidemic raging at Paris Roads, which is supposed to be black fever.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., May 22.--The week goes out with a big increase in the production of Thorn Creek. The gauge to-day showed 7,300 barrels.

OLEAN, May 22.--John Grader, aged 60 years, a farmer living near the village of Alle gany, was robbed one night last Fall of a large sum of money. Since then he had made several attempts to commit suicide, but had been detected each time.

The Police of the First Precinct, Brooklyn, heard that there was a dog fight in progress shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday morning in a stable in the rear of No. 133 Concord-street, and raided the place. Two bulldogs were found engaged in a fight, and eight men were standing around urging them on. When the police entered there was a stampede, and two or the men escaped.
TROY, Penn., May 22.--Forest fires have destroyed a large amount property in the lumber regions of Bradford and Sullivan Counties: during the past few days.
The dispute concerning the will of the late Duke of Brunswick has been amicably settled: the Duke of Cumberland will get about 800,000, and the King or Saxony about 250,000.

Dr. Douglas pronounced Gen. Grant much better yesterday. The doctor attributed the increased irritation in the throat night before last to the result of exposure to the six of the Park during his drive that day.

Mr. Mantell's lago has dark curly hair and a small black mustache. He wears scarlet tights and russet boots; his coat is drab and he hides the handkerchief lost by Desdemona in a leatnern pocket attached to his belt.
PITTSBURG, May 22.--The hillside for a quarter of a mile along the Fort Wayne Railroad at Agnew, 10 miles from the city, is sliding at the rate of four feet an hour.
The anticipated default in the June interest payments of the Erie Railway gave rise yesterday to some further rumors that the appointment of a Receiver for that company would soon be asked for.
For three hours yesterday afternoon Mrs. Alice O'Keefe answered questions put by Joseph H. Choate about her former relations with Ross R. Winans, the young Baltimore millionaire.

While the Roosevelt committee was in session, early in 1884, County Clerk Keenan was a witness before it. After he had stated in detail the duties he performed, the fees he exacted, and the disposition he made of the fees, he was informed by the committee that he had improperly retained for his own benefit the fees other than those paid him for searches, inasmuch as...
Passengers on the Third-avenue elevated train which left Grand-street at 6 o'clock yesterday morning were startled just before reaching the Houston-street station by a heavy explosion.

OLEAN, May 22.--Moses P. Hall and Abram R. Miller are well-known farmers who live on adjoining farms in Hinsdale, this county. Some years ago they quarreled over the purchase of a cow, and a bitter feud has existed between them ever since.

Grant had no fear of responsibility, no fear of Secretary Stanton. I never knew him to above fear of anything. In September, 1864, while at Harper's Ferry returning from a visit to Sheridan, he learned that Wade Hampton had slipped in in rear of the left flank of the Army of the Potomac and carried off our entire beef herd, 2,600 head.
CINCINNATI, May 22.--William T. Bishop was to-day appointed Internal Revenue Collector of the Cincinnati District. He is a son of EX-Gov. Bishop.

Highlands is a station on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, about five miles north of Peekskill. It is composed of a chemical factory, a boarding house, a private residence, and the railroad station.

QUEBEC, May 22.--The bark Brilliant, which arrived here last night from Porsgrund, had on board the crews of the bark Bayard, Capt. Andresen, from Drobak, for Metis, and of the steamer Mary Louisa, of Newcastle, Capt. Greff,from New-York, for Liverpool.

MONTREAL, May 22.--The Board of Health to-day discussed the question of shooting horses affected with glanders, but found they had no power, as all mention of horses had been cut out of the new Contagious Diseases act.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 22.--The injunction taken out at the instance of Mr. Leniman against Mr. Lytell to stop the production of the play known as "The Romany Rye" camp before the Practice Court again this morning.

Master Harry C. Hall, the 10-year-old son of Prof. William B. Hall, is a pupil in Miss Palmer's Chestnut-street school, and on Arbor Day planted a vine and named it James Russell Lowed, in honor of our late Minister to England.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 22.--Mrs. Margaret Goldrick, of No. 672 St. Clair-street, was about placing the sugar bowl upon the table for dinner when she looked at the sugar and noticed that it had a peculiar grayish color.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., May 22.--Secretary Endicott and family, with Gens. Terry and Drum and Col. Barr, escorted by prominent Minneapolis Democrats, reached here this noon, via Minnehaha Falls, where a 45 minutes' stop was made.
The funeral of ex-Secretary Frelinghuysen is to take place at 2 o'clock to-day, from the North Reformed Church in Newark.
The Spring time tables of the new Central and New-Jersey Southern divisions of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad will go into effect to-morrow.

SUAKIN, May 22.--The British have wacuated Otao and returned to Suakin. DONGOLA, May 22.--El Mahdi is retiring his troops everywhere. He himself is retiring toward Jabel Etiri, leaving his steamers at Sobat, on the White Nile.

The body of a man was found in the water a short distance from the beach at Bath, Long Island, on Thursday morning, which some persons thought might prove to be that of S.S. Conant, the missing journalist.

Matthew Dowling, 40 years old, a laborer, of No. 90 Ridge-street," while working in Dougherty Rist's marble works, Nos. 172 to 178 Rivington street, yesterday afternoon, was caught in the machinery and instantly killed.
The Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company yesterday accepted the subsidy contract proposed by the persons controlling the Union Pacific and Central Pacific Railroads.
The Cincinnati Enquirer prints an interview with ex-Senator Thurman, in which occurs the following respecting the Democratic nomination for Governor of Ohio:

ROCHESTER, May 22.--What is known as the Monroe County fruit district includes, in some crops, territory in the western part of Wayne County in addition to Monroe County, and is included within a radius of 10 miles of the City of Rochester, the principal mart for fruit consumption, canning or shipping.

Inspector Bassett, of this city, went to Sing Sing on Thursday and called upon Postmaster Williamson. He told the Postmaster that he had come in obedience to orders from the department to sea why he had made no returns of the money order business for the month of April.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22.--There appears to be no end to the documents which have accumulated and are still piling up in the archives of the United States Circuit Court in the matter of the Reading Railroad litigation.

A side issue in the celebrated Charlie Ross abduction case is revived by the death of James Logan in this city on Sunday last. Logan formed one of the bands of amateur detectives who started upon this remarkable case with a theory of their own.

The want of adequate dock room on the North River is said by merchants to be seriously hampering the business of this city. The demand for such dock room is so great that the rent of North River piers has increased astonishingly during the last three or four years.

About two years ago the Brooklyn papers published at length the story of a woman found starved to death on a barren island near Bellport,and the arrest of her son-in-law for having left her to die there in order to inherit her money.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--The Dolphin will make another trial trip next Thursday, and Mr. Roach, who made the arrangement with Secretary Whitney for that day, expresses the greatest confidence in his ability to snow that the vessel is all the Government expected it would be.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 22.--At a meeting of live stock exporters to-day it was resolved "that the reduction in the size of cattle stalls, as agreed upon between the Government inspector and the steamship agents, is detrimental to the interests of live stock exporters, ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 22.--The conference committees of the iron workers and manufacturers met to-day to consider the new scale presented by the Amalgamated Association proposing a compromise by accepting a 10 per cent. reduction.

Louis Francois was marched from the Twentieth Precinct Station to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning for examination before Justice Welde. Assistant District Attorney Purdy appeared for the people, and Joseph Stiner was appointed counsel for Francois.

DETROIT, May 22.--The Hon. George V. N. Lothrop, the new Minister to Russia, is out in a card in the papers to-day in reply to the charges published against him in connection with the Phoenix Bank claim, which was in litigation a quarter of a century ago, and in which he was attorney in behalf of the bank.
The twenty-fifth anniversary of the wedding of Gen. and Mrs. George B. McClellan occurred yesterday.

A careful examination of the water route from the mouth of Churchill River, on the west shore of Hudson's Bay, to Europe by way of Hudson Strait was begun last Fall by the observers who were taken to their stations in July by the steamship Neptune.

Whatever other questions may from time to time come uppermost in British politics the Irish question is never far off. It enters, indeed, into the consideration of every phase of foreign as well as of domestic policy.

DUSHORE, Penn., May 22.--A large bear which had been stealing sheep from the pastures in Fox Township, in this county, for several weeks, having eluded all efforts of hunters to capture it, the farmers who had lost animals by its depredations rigged up a trap.
A certificate was lately filed in Brown County, Dakota, in these words:

LANCASTER, Penn., May 22.--A tragedy was enacted last night, between 9 and 10 o'clock, in Pequea Township, about five miles from this city. Mrs. Elizabeth Martin, an insane woman, was the wife of Albert Martin, a tenant on the farm of Eli K. Mylin.
TORONTO, May 22.--A serious accident happened here to-day to Miss Millie Alma, a New-York trapeze performer, who was giving exhibitions on the trapeze with Roberts's circus.

Officer Morris saw an Italian dragging a little girl by the arm through Exchange-place, in Jersey City, last night. The officer questioned the girl, and from her answers he was satisfied that; the man had kidnaped her.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23.--Vice-President Hendricks arrived at his home here at noon today. He is in excellent health and is looking better than he has for years.

The tenth annual field meeting of the Intercollegiate Athletic Association took place yesterday on the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds. A large attendance was present and the contests were generally very interesting.

READING, Penn., May 23.--The monument to Frederick Lauer, the deceased brewer of this city, the gift of the United States Brewers' Congress to the city of heading, was unveiled in City Park to-day with appropriate ceremonies.

ITHACA, May 23.--Charles E. Courtney, who calls himself an oarsman, and who is at present coaching the Cornell crew, has informed his intimate friends here that it is very likely he will row double scull with Conley, of Maine, this Summer, but that under no circumstances will he appear on the water in a single scull.
HAVANA, May 23.--The American schooner Emma H. Drummond, Capt. Higgins, bound from New-York for Nuevitas, has been lost on the rocks near Maternillos.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23.--The BennettDouglas yacht Priscilla, which was launched by the Harlem Hollingsworth Company on Thursday, left at noon to-day in two for Poillon's works, Brooklyn, where she will receive her spars, rigging fittings, and ballast. It is designed to have her in sailing trim by June 10.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 23.--The ninth day's racing of the Louisville Jockey Club was well attended and the fine sport was much enjoyed.
OSWEGO, N.Y., May 23.--The Palladium to-day publishes an interview with Thomas Crawford, the defaulting City Treasurer, who is now in Hamilton, Ontario.
Recent advices state that the cricket eleven of English amateurs from Devonshire will be here in August and play two matches before starting out on a tour through the central part of the State.

The volume of business on the Exchange continues small. Only one day in the past week was there anything like activity, and on that day, which was Monday, prices were spurted suddenly in the morning only to drop as suddenly in the afternoon, bringing the list generally to a slightly lower range than its close of the previous Saturday.

A fire occurred soon after 9 o'clock last night in the five-story tenement house No. 537 East Fifteenth-street, which, had it occurred at a later hour, might have resulted in loss of life. The house is one of the ordinary type, containing nine families, one on the ground floor, and two on each of the floors above.

Twenty or more marine engineers met in the rooms of the Stationary Engineers' Association, No. 48 Bleecker-st., last evening to consider the matter of forming a local branch of the National Marine Engineers' Association.

LONDON, May 23.--Paris advices state that the official closing quotation of 3 per cent. rentes to-day was 80f. 42 c., but they afterward became fiat and were quoted at 80f. 17 c., in consequence of the circulation of a rumor that the Emperor of Germany was dead.

LOUISVILLE, May 23.--The Mets won a Game from Louisville to-day a fine exhibition of base running, taking the most desperate chances, and succeeding in every instance.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 23.--Ex-Sheriff J.D. Foute, of London County, was convicted to-day of defrauding the State by forging jail warrants. He was sentenced to 18 years' imprisonment. There are five other cases against him to be tried. He is charged with obtaining $6,000 by fraudulent means.

CLEVELAND, May 23.--The outlook for the great iron mines of Lake Superior is not at present very encouraging. While those of which the ores are peculiarly adapted to the manufacture of Bessemer steel will be kept quite busy under existing contracts, it is not expected that the total production of 1885 will nearly approach that of last 3 year.

A singular fatality seems to follow the Presidents of the newly created Board of Education of Jersey City. A few days ago Mial Mason died, within a week of his election to the Presidency. David L. Holden was elected to succeed him. Yesterday Mr. Holden was stricken with paralysis and last evening he died.

UTICA, N.Y., May 23.--A decision was handed down in the adjourned General Term this afternoon in the case of William Meineke, alias Menken, twice convicted of the murder of a German girl in Elmire, affirming the judgment of the lower court. Meineke is sentenced to be hanged in the Broome County Jail on July 2, between the hours of 10 and 4 o'clock.

Dennis Murray, a well known saloonkeeper and politician, of Newark, N.J., died suddeniy yesterday. He was very active in Irish society matters. He took a prominent part in organizing the Butler party in Newark last Fall, and was candidate for Sheriff on their ticket. His place was a well known rendezvous for sporting men.

The racing season at Coney Island was opened yesterday at Brighton Beach, and several thousand persons were on hand to enjoy the sport, The racing was for the benefit of St. Mary's Hospital, and a great many tickets had been sold, but as there was no pool selling those who were present were greatly disappointed.

UTICA, May 23.--A week ago last Thursday evening, as Miss Cora Bartlett, aged 20 years, teacher of a district school in the town of Lee, was on her way home after school hours, she was overtaken on the highway by a man who pretended to have lost his way.

MEMPHIS, Tenn, May 23.--One of the most novel cycle meetings ever given occurred this afternoon at the Memphis Cycle Club Park and race track where there were 10 bicycle and tricycle races with 50 boys and girls, ranging in age from 3 to 18 years, as starters.

MONTREAL, May 23.--The "Romany Rye" case was again before Judge Doherty to-day, when Lytell's attorney managed to get the Judge to consider for a day or two whether he should be sent to jail for contempt of court or not. Lytell had refused to stop playing tho piece of the order of the court. Now, according to the Judge's ruling, he can play it until he gets an order to stop.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23.--After the close of the Stock Exchange this afternoon it was offically announced by the passenger department of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company that, beginning on Monday next, the 25th inst., a general reduction will be made in west-bound passenger rates by that company.

Adolph Heier, a young German, who since the 4th inst. had been in the employ of Mr. Jacob Cohn, of No. 349 West Twenty-eighthstreet, as coachman, committed suicide last evening by hanging himself in his employer's stable. His employer cannot assign any motive for the suicide. Heier was only 22 years of age.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 23.--Last Fall, in an accident on the Indiana, Bloomington and Western Railroad, William C. Whitehead was injured so badly that he has not since been able to leave his bed, and his death is only a matter of a short time. In a suit to recover damages the jury today awarded him $17,500, the largest sum ever named in a verdict in this State for personal damages.
The opening matches of the National Rifle association were shot yesterday at Creedmoor. Owing to the threatening weather the attendance was small, only about 40 riflemen being present.

LONDON, May 23.--The Right Rev. George Moberly, Bishop of Salisbury, will resign the Bishopric this Summer. Bishop Moberly is 82 years of age, and is one of the five clergymen who published, between 1857 and 1870, revised versions of the Gospel according to St. John, and of the Epistles to the Romans, to the Galatians, to the Corinthians, and of the Epistle of St. James.

The Rev. Arthur Ritchie, Rector of St. Ignatius Church, No. 56 West Fortieth-street, is having the same trouble with Assistant Bishop Potter that he had with Bishop McLaren in Chicago two years ago, and he has been subjected to a "remonstrance" by the Assistant Bishop, to which he is paying as little attention as he did to the admonition of Bishop McLaren.

SAN FRNACISCO, May 23.--An audience of 6,000 attended the glove contest between Charles Mitchell, of Birmingham, England, and Mike Cleary, of New-York, at Mechanics' Pavilion last night.
CITY OF MEXICO, May 23, via Galveston-- The Government has permitted the garrison of Vera Cruz to be vaccinated with yellow fever virus, according to Dr. Carmona's system.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., May 23.--In the County Court to-day William N. Johnston, of this village, secured a verdict against Spenccr Trask Co., the New-York bankers, for $5,107. Johnston purchased $10,000 of Ohio Central income bonds and claimed that the manager of the house guaranteed him against loss. The case has been appealed.

A number of Broadway property owners yesterday sent to Mayor Grace a document giving reasons why in their opinion the Arcade Railroad bill should not become a law.
ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., May 22.--A hearing in an interesting divorce case, which has been in progress for some days at Lancaster, N.H., has just closed.

There was unwonted commotion in Central Park-toward the latter part of the afternoon yesterday, and every vehicle upon the drives and every pedestrian upon the footpaths at 5 o'clock turned toward the statue of Webster, on the West Drive, to review the annual parade of the Coaching Club.
