The Atlantic Yacht Club will have their opening races on Decoration Day. The fleet will assemble at the foot of Fifty-ninth-street, Brooklyn, and at a signal from the flagship the club flag will be raised on the club house, and saluted by the firing off guns and the dipping of colors.
PARIS, May 4.--In a recent letter I gave a brief sketch of the military situation in Asia of the respective forces of the future combatants at the opening of the campaign.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Charles H. Brown was given a judgment for $25 to-day before Justice Hammer against John H. Redheffer, a lawyer, and George Ryall, agent of the American Protective Association, both of whom came recently from Philadelphia, and C.A. Cook, of this city.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Mr. Leonard Mueller, one of the owners of the steamer Ella Knight, made notorious by having been used, as is alleged, in the transportation of kidnaped boys from New-Orleans to Puerto Barrios, Honduras, ...

LONDON, May 23.--The Economist of this week says: "The rate of discount for bank bills, 60 days to 3 months, is 1 per cent., and for trade bills, 60 days to 3 months, 1 to 2 per cent. Money was inactive and the rates were extremely weak.
PARIS, May 23.--Crowds are still flocking to the residence of Victor Hugo depositing wreaths of immortelles. The street in front of the house was thronged with people last night up to a late hour.

BOSTON, May 23.--J.E. Stearns, a married man, aged 35, wore a carpenter's "jumper" this forenoon at his work in Charles E. Hall Co.'s marble manufactory, No. 67 Charlestownstreet.

LEXINGTON, Ky., May 23.--About 10 days ago a man calling himself Charles Green, who had worked for Grandison Clark, a stockman of Jasper County, Ill., about six months, forged the latter's name to an order for money, and on it obtained $1,000 from Middlesworth, Graybill Co., of Indianapolis, with whom Clark dealt largely.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--Some of the uneasy and unreasonable Democrats who have visited the capital to inform themselves about the purposes of the Administration have succeeded in getting the impression, which they have eagerly communicated to others, that a "clean sweep" of Republican once holders was imminent, and that preparations for such a change were being made in all the departments.
The eastern system of the Cape Colony railways, passing through the colonial coal fields, has just been completed and opened for traffic to Burghersdorp.
On Saturday, May 30, an interesting service will be solemized during the forenoon at the tomb of Gen. Zachary Taylor, near the Brownsborough road, six miles east of the city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 23.--The ten-milliondollar mortgage by the Postal Telegraph Company to the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company, filed in the Erie County Clerk's office yesterday, is found not to be of recent creation, but is dated Jan. 26, 1882. Its previous registration has been apparently overlooked.
BALTIMORE, May 23.--When the case of Joseph Sherlock, accused of bigamy, was called in the Criminal Court in this city to-day, it was found that he had disappeared.

The interior of the block bounded by Cherry, Roosevelt, Oak, and Pearl streets is almost entirely filled up with small tenement houses, which are reached by means of four narrow little alleys, unlike any to be found in any other portion of New-York.

MANSFIELD, May 23.--The Ohio Legislature last Winter passed an act providing for an intermediate prison for first offense convicts, appropriating $600,000 therefor, and providing for a committee of three to locate the institution.
At the recent banquet of members of the Delta Kappa Epsilon Fraternity in this city the organization of a social club was suggested.
TUCSON, Arizona, May 23.--A passenger just arrived from Georgetown reports that the Apaches killed a man at Bullard's mining camp, 80 miles north of Silver City.

Some important changes in the running of trains on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad will go into effect to-day. The Chicago limited express will leave the Grand Central Station at 9:50 o'clock A.M. every day in the week, and will run through to Chicago in 24 hours.

A comical incident in the Illinois Senatorial contest transpired at Watseka, Ill., yesterday. Major Peters, editor of the Republican of that place, and Republican member of the Legislature from Iroquois County, when assured of Logan's election telegraphed the boys from Springfield: "Logan is elected. Paint my old home red."
A fire broke out a little before midnight last night in the building of the Excelsior Electric Company, at Navy and Willough by streets, Brooklyn.
On Friday night John Keating, of No. 311 East Eighty-first-street, a peddler, met John West and Max Bettenheim, two boys, at play at Fourteenth-street and Third-avenue.
CHICAGO, May 23.--Yesterday a man was detected in Giles Brothers' jewelry store while trying to steal diamonds, and he was, when arrested, reeognized as Billy Murray, an old-time thief.

There is no room for doubt as to the feeling of the American people in regard to the dismissal of "offensive partisans" from the Federal service. Such removal will not only be accepted, it will be heartily and gratefully approved.

The present style for dresses has a decided tendency toward simplicity. Materials are handsome and rich, but skirts fall plain and almost without trimming. Some dresses are of colored faille covered with overskirts of embroidered network.

The most prominent convert that has yet declared himself at the Rev. Sam Jones's meeting in Nashville is Gen. W.H. Jackson, owner of the great Belle Mead stock farm, and brother of Senator Jackson, of that State.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Secretary of War Endicott arrived here at 3 o'clock to-day en route to Washington from Minneapolis and the Northwest. The Secretary was much pleased with his trip and spoke in high terms of the present condition and future prospects of the country through which he passed. The Secretary and staff departed for Washington to-night. Gens. Sheridan and Schofield waited on Secretary Endicott at his hotel after his arrival.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23.--The threatened strike of the horseshoers, which was to occur throughout the city on Monday, has been averted or postponed for a week at least, by the intimation from the Superintendents of several of the street railways that the demands of the men would be granted.

CHICAGO, May 23.--Gen. John A. Logan arrived here this evening from Springfield and was given an enthusiastic reception. He was met by a number of friends at the railroad station and escorted to the Grand Pacific Hotel, where the newly elected Senator had to submit for over two hours to the customary handshaking. A salute of 103 guns was fired during the reception.

CHARLESTON, West Va., May 23.--In the cases of Nelson Robinson, W.F. Owens, and the Central Trust Company of New-York against the Ohio Central Company, a consolidated decree of sale was ordered to-day by Judge Jackson of the United States District Court for West Virginia; said sale to take place in 120 days.

While the ferryboat Alaska, of the Roosevelt-Street line, was on her way to this city yesterday morning with a large number of passengers on board one of her wheels struck a floating log, which was carried up into the paddlebox, where it stock fast. The ferryboat was disabled by the accident and drifted about for some minutes.

A physical monstrosity almost equaling the Prince of Trepotkine is the carefully guarded son of a well-to-do merchant occupying a costly mansion not far from the southern boundary of the Central Park.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 23.--The body of an unknown man with a package of letters in his possession addressed to Philip McManus, NO. 212 Aliceanna-street, Baltimore, Md., was found lying on the track of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad near Newark this morning.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 23.--The physicians who are attending Miss Lulu West, a charming young lady of Laurens, S.C., as well as visiting physicians, are greatly puzzled over the condition of the patient.
Through the dense fog which hung over the ocean on the Banks of Newfoundland early on Tuesday morning last the Inman steamship City of Berlin was cautiously groping its way.

Eleven obstinate jurors prevented a verdict from being returned yesterday in the suit of Sternfeld against the Mutual Life Insurance Company in the Supreme Court. If they had gone around to the side of their associate a verdict would have been rendered in favor of the corporation.
"Sealed Instructions" will be acted all the Madison-Square theatre for another fortnight, and will be withdrawn for the Summer after June 6, when the regular season of the house will close.

Delaney, from Company H to Company B First Lieut. George F. Cooke, from Company B to Company H. The officers named will join the companies to which they are transferred.

WASHINGTON, May 23, 1885. The Secretary of the Treasury has appointed James McCausland, Patrick W. Riley, and Carl E. Roudrup to be Assistant Inspectors of Steam Vessels for the District of New-York.

The season at the Thalia Theatre was brought to a close yesterday evening with a gala performance, given for the benefit of Herr G. Amberg, the manager of that attractive and successful place of resort. The programme included the first act of "Der Feldprediger," ...

ST. JOHN'S NEW-FOUNDALAND, May 23.-- Dispatches from various parts of Conception Bay state that Orange persecution of Roman Catholics continues unrelentingly.
Magnolia is now a prohibition town, and no liquor can be sold within its limits. A few days ago a citizen announced that he had been bitten by a snake and wanted whisky to cure himself.

The property known as the Middleton estate, at the head of Lincoln-avenue, beginning at the eastern gate of the Soldiers' Home and lying between the road to the Home and the old Bladensburg road, Washington City, has been purchased for the site of the proposed Catholic university.

The testimony of merchants on the subject of the regulation of railway charges occupied yesterday a session of the Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce. Josiah J. White was the first to submit his opinions.
ALBANY, May 23.--Gov. Hill this afternoon received the resignation of the Hon. S.S. Cox as Representative in Congress from the Eighth Congressional District of this State.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 23.--Henry Auer, the Marshal of New-Straitsville, who was shot down by Albert Guest on the night of the 21st inst., died to-day.

NEW-HAVEN, May 23.--For a week Yale students have almost forgotten athletics. They have given their attention to matters of a very different kind, and have talked about very little outside of secret society matters. On Monday night the classes were collected at their respective fences, and were evidently awaiting some signal.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., May 23.--It has been ascertained that the woman supposed to have been murdered in New-York by her husband, Louis Francois, who was carrying her body to the river in a bag when stopped by an officer, is Celia Tatro, daughter of Isaac Tatro, now living in Washington, Mass., about four miles from this place.
The annual inspection and muster of the Third Battery, Brooklyn, Capt. Henry S. Rasquin commanding, will take place in the Fourteenth Regiment armory Tuesday, July 14, at 8 P.M.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., May 23.--David Meyers, a member of the Typographical Union of Syracuse, attempted to jump on an Erie freight train at Owego to-day. He slipped and fell under the wheels, which ran across his body. He lived but a few minutes. He was 55 years of age.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 23.--Yale College circles had a sensation to-day in the arrest of Emile Adolfa Schultze, Jr., who is a Senior, and one of the most prominent members of the Scroll and Keys Society, and one of the best known men in Yale.

James Irving, a sewing machine agent, employed by Joseph Jathelka, of No. 172 Attorney-street, was arraigned yesterday at Essex Market Police Court on a charge of assaulting Mrs. Emelia Dusch, of No. 7 Lewis-street.

In the final estimates for 1885 there was included an item of $150,000 to be used for extra street cleaning, the work to be done with the consent and under the direction of the Board of Health, the Mayor, and the Commissioner of Street Cleaning.

Several hundred persons called at the Morgue yesterday and attempted to identify the body of the woman who committee suicide at the Grand Union Hotel on Friday morning, but her identity is still unknown.

Among the numerous and rapid transformations that have come over New-York during the past 10 or 15 years and endowed it with a close resemblance to the princinal cities of Europe none have been more marked than those tending to make outdoor life, as distinguished from home life, easier and more attractive.

Mayor Grace yesterday telegraphed Gov. Hill thanking him for granting hearings on the New-York bills, and adding: "I wish to be specially heard upon the Harlem Ricer Bridge bill. It is a bill involving the expeniture of $2,000,000 by the city, and, besides, I do not think the bridge is located properly."

Many politicians in Hoboken are angry because the local appointive offices have not been distributed, and because, as there is a deadlock in the Board of Councilmen, it is likely that a long time will pass before they are distributed.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 24.--As a result of the recent meeting of the National Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association here, a movement to secure a fund for the erection of a building here received subscriptions of $40,000 in three days and will be raised to $75,000 during the coming week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--A Times's dispatch from Raven Run says; "The body of the tenth and last victim of the Cuyler Colliery disaster was recovered last night and was buried at Guardville to-day. It was badly decomposed and beyond recognition."
The plain meeting house at Rutherfordplace and Fifteenth-street was filled with a congregation of Friends yesterday morning and again in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, May 23.--President Cleveand will soon be on the fourth month of his term, and will probably do some of his work in June out at the Soldiers' Home cottage, to which be proposes soon to remove for residence.

--Gen. Gordon's diaries will be published simultaneously in this country and in England. Houghton, Mifflin Co. are the American publishers. The diaries have been edited by Mr. Hake, a cousin of Gordon's and the author of a life of him published several months ago. Letters will be printed from Gen. Stewart and ElMahdi, along with other important documents and maps.
LOWELL, Mass., May 24.--Major James W. Hart, who commanded Company D of the Sixth Regiment during its passage through Baltimore in 1861, died last night at the age of 63 years.

GALVESTON, Texas, May 24.--The Daily News announces this morning that arrangements are being perfected whereby it will establish a branch office of publication in Dallas, where the paper will be printed simultaneously with its issue at Galveston.

A Baltimore dispatch, printed yesterday morning, announced that David M. Porter, counsel for Mrs. O'Keeffe in the Winans divorce suit, had withdrawn because his client had misinformed him as to the value of her claim, and that the suit would collapse before Wednesday by the withdrawal of the complaint.
CAIRO, Ill., May 24.--At Cobden, Ill., last night, Alexander Welker was shot and killed by William Mayes. The trouble was over a girl with whom both men were in love. Mayes escaped.
Ten days ago Mrs. Highland Platt complained to the police of Jersey City that while she was absent from home in New-York her husband disappeared from the house with their 16-month-old babe.

RALEIGH, May 24.--On Friday last, in Contentnea Township, Pitt County, N.C., William Wilson, one of the employes of C.C. Bland, went hunting, accompanied by Bland's 4-yearold boy. After they returned Wilson was standing in the house with his chin resting on the muzzle of the loaded gun. The little boy began to play with the hammer and accidentally discharged the gun, blowing Wilson's head off.
BERMUDA, May 20.--The English schooner yacht Cambria, Capt. Jerham, 44 days from Cowes, via St. Michael's, April 26, bound to NewYork, arrived at St. George's on the 19th inst.

Among the passengers on the Cunard steamship Aurania, which arrived yesterday, were Francis Codman, Mr. and Mrs. R.G. Dan, Capt. L.M. Lewis, H.W. Kingsbury, Lady Anne Murray W. Cruger Pell, Theodore B. Starr, and the Hon. H.S. Stanford.

National Guardsmen and members of the Grand Army of the Republic mingled picturesquely together in front of the Lincoln monument on the Prospect Park (Brooklyn) plaza yesterday afternoon in the annual decoration services of the monument under the auspices of Clarence D. Mackenzie Post, No. 399.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24.--The reduction in passenger rates made by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to Chicago and principal points in the West, which goes into effect tomorrow, was made after mature consideration of the whole subject, and the result will be watched with much interest by the officers and shareholders of the company.

The autopsy on the body of Robert E. Odium, the man who leaped into the East River from the Brooklyn bridge, not only showed that the fall had crushed nearly all his vital organs, but also disclosed the fact that, in spite of his magnificent muscular development and stalwart physique, his body was far from sound.

The new style of mule now in the possession of Mr. Michael O'Donnelly, of Chicago, is generally regarded as a marked improvement in military mules, but it is quite certain that the animal would be of little use as a purely civil mule.

SYRACUSE, May 24.--The excursion steam-- er John Greenway, which runs on Onondaga Lake and the canal, started yesterday afternoon from its landing in Geddes for a trip across the lake.

NORWICH, Conn., May 24.--Two boys each 10 years old, while playing in a yard on Brand-street yesterday, set fire to a parcel of sulphur, and Willie, the son, a year and a half old, of Mrs. Daniel Drew, who was with them, fell into the fire. Frightened by his screams, the other boys ran away, and the boy was fatally burned before his screams brought assistance.

To the Editor: In your issue of the 14th inst. Mr. H.B. Hyde, President of the Equitable Life, makes a partial reply to the presentation of the Tontine and semi-Tontine system which I have made at three different times in your columns.

The baccalaureate sermon to the Senior Class of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church was delivered last evening in St. Peter's Church by Bishop Seymour, of Springtield, Ill. There were present the Rev. Dr. Beach, the Rector of the church; the Rev. Mr. Roche, Dean Hoffman, and the Faculty of the seminary.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 24.--Judge McComber has decided the long contested cause of L.C. Woodruff and Augustus Frank as Trustees of the Erie and Genesee Valley Railroad, against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western, in favor of the plaintiffs.

CHICAGO, May 24.--At the Nickel Plate shops in Hyde Park this afternoon Albert Hagedorn, an engineer of the Nickel Plate Road, was terribly cut and probably fatally wounded by McConnell, a switchman. The latter was arrested. The two men had a quarrel of several weeks' standing.

The first official response to "The Bitter Cry of Outcast London" is the recently submitted report of the royal commission appointed to inquire into the housing of the poor in London and other British cities.
LOCKPORT, May 24.--The fatal leap of Robert E. Odlum from the East River bridge, recalls a similar foolhardy exhibition which, however, did not terminate fatally.

WINNIPEG, May 24.--Emissaries of Poundmaker, the Indian Chief who fought Otter at Battleford, arrived at Prince Albert today to confer with Gen. Middleton with reference to Poundmaker's desire to get terms of peace.

DENVER, Col., May 24.--An attempt to blow up a passenger train on the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad with dynamite occurred here at 9 o'clock last night. The train was the Pacific express and consisted of seven cars well filled with passengers.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., May 24.--Three years ago Zeb Parker, a negro, robbed the store of C. L. Smathers' at Pigeon Valley, Haywood County, in this State, of $1,500 in money, nearly all of that amount being in silver.

WASHINGTON, May 24.--Capt. Clarence E. Dutton, of the Ordnance Department of the army, who has been engaged for 10 years in the study of the geology of the great plateau region of the West, started last week for California ...
Mr. Beecher was in an earnest mood yesterday, and at times during his sermon on evolution as applied to religion his voice and manner betrayed a depth of feeling not common in his public utterances.

At St. Agnes's Church, in East Fortythird-street, yesterday, the solemn pontificial mass was celebrated by the Right Rev. John Joseph Conroy, D.D., of the See of Curium, assisted by Fathers Macdowall, Begley, Murray, and Wall. At 4 o'clock in the afternoon Bishop Conroy administered the sacrament of confirmation to nearly 500 children.

The Hudson's Bay expedition, which is to sail from Halifax in the course of a few days, has not attracted much attention here, although it has for its object the solution of a problem of the very highest importance both to Canada and the Northwestern States of the Union.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24.--Seven deaths have occurred at Plymouth since last evening, and a number of new cases have been reported this afternoon. The hopeful feeling caused by the slight death roll of Thursday and Friday has again given way to despondency, the people seeing no end to the plague.

LONDON, May 24.--Lieut. John Loomis Schock, Assistant Naval Constructor United States Navy, on special duty at the Royal College, Greenwich, England, committed suicide today by shooting himself with a revolver. The tragedy occurred at Blackheath.
ITHACA, May 24.--There is unusual activity in university circles at the present time in view of the fact that there remain but a few weeks of the collegiate year.

Almost before the foreign Exhibition, which was held in Boston toward the close of 1883 and the beginning of 1884, was cold in its grave, as, according to all accounts, it was a disastrous failure, the idea of an American exhibition to be held in London in 1886 was promulgated in circulars issued by Gen. Charles Benjamin Norton.
The old Bowery Village Methodist Episcopal Church, now known as the Seventh-Street Church, yesterday held reunion services in commemoration of the ninety-ninth anniversary of its existence.
An important capture was made Saturday by officers of Inspector Byrnes's corps, the prisoner being the notorious Gustave Kindt, perhaps the cleverest and most successful safe burglar in the country.

PITTSBURG, Penn, May 24.--Last Thursday night the mangled body of Charles Weber was found on the tracks of the Pennsylvania Incline. It was supposed that he had committed suicide or had accidentally fallen off the car, but the detectives now claim that they have evidence that will show that he was a victim of foul play.
Mr. BEECHER treads upon perfectly safe ground in his series of sermons upon evolution as applied to religion.

LOCKPORT, May 24.--THE TIMES of June 15, 1884, contained the report of an interview between a correspondent with Sergt. Lewis Leffman, of Youngstown, near Fort Niagara, in which the principal events of his long and remarkable career were set forth in his own language. The death of this veteran soldier occurred at his home on May 14. He was in the eighty-ninth year of his age.

CHICAGO, May 24.--It became known only to-day that last Friday the S.W. Adams Manufacturing Company, whose store and office is at No. 167 South Canal-street, had sold out to the Pennsylvania Tube Works, of Pittsburg, in a manner to alarm the creditors of the former concern.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 24.--The German residents of this city, with the people generally of the town of Orange, are much excited over the unaccountable disappearance of Mrs. Emil Brehm, the daughter of Bernard Oberkehr, one of New-Haven's most conspicuous German citizens.
Three big brass bells clanged loudly but musically in the Fourteenth Ward yesterday morning. They were strangers to the locality and they quickly attracted attention.

We have had a striking illustration in this State of the effects of two different methods of gaining prestige in politics in the careers of two successive Governors. Mr. CLEVELAND was known in Buffalo, not as a politician, but as a man of sturdy independence and thorough-going honesty.
There was only a limited quantity of strawberries sent to this market last week, as the Norfolk strawberry crop is very late and the Charleston crop has been mostly gathered.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 24.--M.C. Apt, at one time a well-to-do citizen of West Pittston, was found dead in the Susquehanna River at Port Blanchard Saturday morning by two boys who were fishing.
LONDON, May 24.--Mr. Willam H. Vanderbilt arrived at Queenstown this evening on the Germanic, and will visit the Lakes of Killarney to-morrow.

The efforts of Mr. Max Avromovitz, who is described by the bills as a German-Hungarian comedian, and those of M. Louis Pizzarello, who may be designated, in theatrical parlance, as a French grotesque, enlivened last evening's performance at Koster Bial's.
LOWELL, Mass, May 24.--Frank Huntoon, aged 18; Annie Byron, aged 18, and Nellie Devlin, aged 15, while boat-riding on the Concord River this evening were carried over a sevenfoot dam.

Mr. Max Strakosch announces that Mme. Charlotte Patti will return to this country in September next, and enter upon a concert tour under his management at once. Mme. Patti will be accompanied, of course, by M. de Munck, and an efficient troupe is to be engaged to support her.

The basin used for several years at Stapleton, Staten Island, for the yachts of the Seawanhaka Yacht Club was bought recently by George Bechtel, the brewer, and the members of the club were noticed that the docks previously used by the club would be torn down.

Ex-Judge William T. Hoffman, who is conducting the State's defense against the certiorari proceedings brought by the New-Jersey Central Railroad Company to defeat the operation of the new railroad tax laws, says that the case will probably be heard at a Special Term of the Supreme Court, to be held at Trenton in October, for the consideration of all the railroad tax cases.

The steamer Valora, of this port, Capt. Haskell, is engaged in shooting whales for the factory at Boothbay. Thursday, when off Cape Porpoise and just in sight of land, an immense whale was encountered and the steamer started in pursuit, but just as they got near enough to fire at the monster he sounded.
The matches of the National Rifle Association to be shot at Creedmoor on Saturday next and Saturday, June 6, and 13, will begin at 9:30 A.M., and no shooting will be allowed after 5:30 P.M.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 24.--At Haile's gold mine, Lancaster County, this State, last Friday, William Cunningham, a white employe, shot at Valentine, a colored employe, and killed Robert Brown. Cunningham afterward wounded Valentine twice. He has escaped.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 24.--The years of misgovernment that have followed the Hayes bargain of 1877 have finally borne fruit in the organization of a committee of 100 of the best conservative citizens of New-Orleans for the purpose of establishing a sort of surveillance over the lawless element of the office-holding regency and holding the public servants to the correct performance of their public trusts.
CAMBRIDGE, May 24.--Every student at Harvard studying for the degree of A.B. is required to take four courses during his last three years at college.

CLEVELAND, May 24.--Ten years ago the new Court House, on Seneca-street, was built at great cost to the county. Since that time the mammoth structure has served only to furnish quarters for the Probate and Criminal Courts and Prosecutor's office.

RALEIGH, May 24.--On Wednesday as the train on the Narrow Gauge Railroad was crossing the high trestle near Lenoir, in this State, the tender left the rails and scared the negro fireman so that he leaped from the engine. He fell 150 feet, striking on his head, and was masbed to pieces. The train bumped over the ties a short distance and reached the ground in safety.

MONTREAL, May 24.--Oliver Gauthier, 25 years of age, fell off the steamer Beaubarnois into the river to-day and was drowned. There were about 300 people on the boat, but no effort was made to rescue him.

Under the direction of Assistant Chief Engineer Smith the firemen yesterday thoroughly overhauled the ruins of the wrecked lard factory in Boerum-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, the boiler of which exploded on Saturday night.
Acting Mayor Hanway yesterday received a letter from New-York parties inclosing a one-dollar note issued under ordinance of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, May.
At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the cigarmakers reported that during the past week they had won a strike in the shop of Kaufman Worms, on Twenty-thirdstreet.
During the past week the New-Yorks held their lead in the race for the League championship. They are now 2 games ahead of the Chicago representatives.

CINCINNATI, May 24.--Col. L. Markbreit, the Assistant United States Treasurer at this place, to-day removed the coin and currency in his care from the old Post Office building at the corner of Fourth and Vine streets to the new quarters on the second floor of the new Government building at the corner of Fifth and Walnut streets.

FAIRBURN, Ga., May 24.--Considerable excitement exists in this part of the State owing to troubles between colored laborers. The approach of cotton chopping time always gives employment to more hands than can usually be obtained.

When the Hon. Neal Dow, Maine's apostle of temperance, rose to speak in Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon, in reply to some of the statements made at the convention of brewers last week, he was greeted with warm applause from an audience which filled the hall.

PITTSBURG, 24.--A Post special from Newark, Wirt County, West Va., says: "Yesterday a deadly fight occurred between J. P. Buffington and August Killian, farmers.

MOREHEAD, N.C., May 24.--Two large whales have been caught here during the past month. They got the bar into the harbor and were killd at low tide. Others have been seen, and efforts are being made to capture them.

The attache of the Chinese Legation at Paris may be called not so much a Chinaman spoiled as a Chinaman Frenchified. He seems to have caught exactly that cynical style peculiar to the feuilletoniste, and many of the passages in the volume read as if they had been written for the Figare.
PARIS, May 24.--To-day being the anniversary of the fail of the Commune, the Cominunists of Paris attempted to hold a demonstration at the tombs of their comrades in the Pere-la-Chaise Cemetery.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 24.--A notable event in church matters here to-day was the Rev. Dr. Charles R. Hemphill, of South Carolina, assuming the Pastorate of the Second Presbyterian Church, which was for so many years under the charge of the eminent Dr. Stewart Robinson. He preached two powerful sermons to crowded houses.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 24.--Ever since the establishment of the Newport Casino music has been furnished during the season by New-York musicians. The Executive Committee this year decided to employ the United States steamer New-Hampshire band, belonging to the naval station here.

The plans of the New-York Arcade Railway Company, whose bill, authorizing the construction of an underground rapid transit road uuder Broadway and Madison-avenue through the entire length of those thoroughfares, was passed by the Legislature just before its adjournment, and is now awaiting the signature of Gov. Hill, contemplate the building...
A hundred or two persons visited the Morgue yesterday, hoping to identify the body of the young woman who shot herself at the Grand Union Hotel.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 24.--In Screven County yesterday Robert McCoy was convicted of the murder of Henry Miller, and was sentenced to hanged on June 26. McCoy killed his victim by sinking a pine knot into his brain.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 24.--This afternoon Lizzie Mahoney became intoxicated and with some friends went on board the schooner Sarah H. Pryor.
BALTIMORE, May 24.--The annual meeting for the election of officers of the Maryland Jockey Club will take place to-morrow, and indications are that it will be rather stormy.

BERLIN, May 24.--The Earl of Rosebery and Prince Bismarck exchanged visits to-day. The German papers state that England is desirous of securing the Emperor William as arbitrator of the Afghan dispute between Russia and England.

Work on the Broadway surface road was continued until 7 o'clook yesterday morning, and tracks were laid as far south as Tenthstreet. The stones and earth taken up for two blocks below Fourteenth-street were replaced, and all traces of the trench hidden beneath...

CHICAGO, May 24.--An unkempt looking crowd of Anarchists, containing a sprinkling of Socialists and a few peaceably inclined workingmen, held an open-air meeting on the lake front to-day, at which the customary expressions against the tyranny of capital were induiged in for a time without creating any unusual excitement.
CINCINNATI, May 24.--Hermann Brinkman, 18 years old, was drowned at the Cincinnati Swimming School this afternoon. He was an expert swimmer, and it is not known-how he met with the accident.

The body of the man round in Flushing Bay on Saturday was yesterday identified as that of William Grimlich, of No. 143 Delanceystreet, in this city. He, on May 3, left his home with a man named Volzner to go fishing.
BARACOA, May 18.--In port--Steam schrs. Jeanie, Coggins, to sail 19th; Maynard Sumner, Dyer, about 21st.

COLUMBUS, May 24.--The heavy rains of the last two days have raised the water in all the streams in Central Ohio and in some instances damaged growing crops. Some apprehension is felt by railway officials that the very heavy rain of to-day will wash out trestles and cause landslides.
Secretary of the Treasury Daniel Manning, who arrived at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel late Saturday night, was not troubled by many callers yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 24.--H.B. Scutt Co., of Joliet, Ill., have filed a bill in the Circuit Court of Will County, against the Washburne Moen Manufacturing Company, of Worcester, Mass., and I.L. Ellwood, of De Kalb, Ill., to recover ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 24.--The Rev. W. J. Horn, Pastor of the African Methodist Church, died in his pulpit to-night. He was explaining his relation to some petty scandal set afloat in his flock, and was evidently much excited. He was reared at Baltimore, was from 35 to 40 years old, and leaves a wife and child. The doctors who have seen the corpse attribute his death to heart disease.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 24.--The House yesterday was again in session on the Franchise bill. Mr. Mills moved to insert a clause providing that no revising officer be eligible as a candidate for Parliament in any constituency where he prepared voters' lists for five years after he had ceased to be revising officer.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 24.--The night express on the Mount Vernon and Pan Handle route was wrecked about 10 miles from Mount Vernon at 2 o'clock this morning.

HAVANA, May 24.--A small filibustering expedition under Sanchez landed at Point Caletas on the 19th inst. The band was dispersed on the same day by troops, who wounded one man and seized a quantity of arms and documents.
Drs. Shrady and Douglas found Gen. Grant much more comfortable yesterday afternoon than when tney saw him on Wednesday. The condition of all the affected parts showed encouraging improvement.

There was more or less talk in job printing houses yesterday to the effect that in Sullivan's and in some other establishments there was custom of cleaning "forms" by pouring kerosene or benzine over them and setting fire to the fluid. If such was the case it is easy to understand how an open can of the stuff near the forms might have been exploded.
Referring to the death of Victor Hugo the Rev. R. Heber Newton said in his sermon yesterday morning: "France lost the past week a noble man whose name and fame are the common property of humanity.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 25.--The trial of Adolph Spreckels, son of Claus Spreckels the sugar king, for shooting M.H. De Young proprietor of the San Francisco Chronile, on Nov. 16 last, was commenced to-day. The trial will occupy several days.
When 110 veterans marched into the armory of the Fourteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, last evening 625 uniformed men applauded by thumping the floor with the butt ends of their muskets.
WASHINGTON, May 25.--It is extremely probable that the recent changes in the Treasury and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing will bring about some modifications of the paper money of the country.

Jollity and pleasure held sway among the Germans in their celebration yesterday of Pfingstmontag. The New-York Turnverein turned out in a procession 1,000 strong, and as they marched from their hall, in East Fourthstreet, the natty blue dresses of the Turners attracted much attention from passers by.
QUEBEC, May 25.--Details of the fire in Somerset last week state that the total loss is $300,000.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., May 25.--Col. W. Johnson, correspondent for several sensational weekly papers at Gloversville, was cowhided today in a village drug store by Prof. West, of the Salvation Army. Johnson is seriously injured. West has been arrested.
PARIS, May 25.--Victor Hugo's funeral will take place next Sunday. The poet's body will lie in state under the Arc de Triomphe until Saturday.

A slender, dark-haired young man stood on the bridge promenade, about 150 feet east of the New-York tower, about 3:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The man was clad in a respectable suit of black cloth, and wore a pair of goldrimmed spectacles.

CLEVELAND, May 25.--Ray S. Hathaway, city editor of the Toledo Sunday Democrat, was tarred and feathered this afternoon by C.L. Merry, H.E. Smith, and W.H. Peters, prominent and wealthy citizens of Norwalk. The outrage was committed in the rear of the United States Hotel at Norwalk.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 25.--The goods and store of Gill Myers, gas fitters and plumbers, are in the hands of the Sheriff. Cognovit notes dated Dec. 13, 1884, and Jan. 15, 1885, in favor of S. Bardshar for $1,000 and $2,000 were ...

OWEGO, N.Y., May 25.--The decision of Judge H. Boardman Smith in a case in which the Question of the legitimacy of one of the leading citizens of Chemung, this county, is to be settled is being awaited with great interest in this community.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 25.--The committee appointed by the General Assembly, consisting of Senators Cable, White, Wolcott, and Insurance Commissioner Reinmund, will leave here to-night for New-York for the purpose of investigating the tontine insurance system.

ATLANTA, Ga., May 25.--The death of Norman B. Harwood, announced from Florida, has created a sensation here, where he had a life insurance of $200,000. Harwood was born in Bennington, Vt., 56 years ago, and was a member of a wealthy family.
Henry V. Lucas, the millionaire manager of the St. Louis League Club, was in an unhappy mood last evening. As he left the Polo Grounds his usually pleasant countenance had a troubled expression.

PITTSBURG, Penn., May 25.--There is no abatement in the epidemic at Paris Roads. Another child of Nicholas Truax, who has already lost two, died to-day, and Lida Gardner, the stepdaughter of Kennedy Truax, who lost five children and whose wife is insane, is not expected to live over to-day.

The Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club begins to day at Jerome Park. The Spring has been very unfavorable for training, and there are a great number of horses not yet ready to run at their best. It is predicted that there will be many surprises at the meeting.
WASHINGTON, May 25.--The Spring races of the Capital Bicycle Club, of this city, took place at Athletic Park to-day.

Several resident ministers of Brooklyn lately have received copies of circulars through the mails, signed by Augustus Barr, Secretary, and setting forth the advantages to be derived by sending a subscription of $5 to the "American Bureau of Searchers for Legacies" at Pittsburg, Penn.

PANAMA, May 17.--Since the last mail the train of events here has been much less exciting and the wisdom and determination of the Provisional Government have justified the belief that they are equal to the situation and can preserve the peace of the isthmus and the freedom of transit.

MONTREAL, May 25.--Four of Pinkerton's detectives came near being arrested here last night.
Mr. Alonzo Stoddard's Count Arnheim was the only portrayal in last evening's representation of "The Bohemian Girl," at the Fifth-avenue Theatre, that demanded attention or approval.

RICHMOND, Va., May 25.--Over an hour was spent this morning in the Cluverius murder trial in arguing the question as to the admissibility of the torn note found at the American Hotel addressed to T.J. Cluverius and alleged to have been written by Lillian Madison.

WASHINGTON, May 25, 1885. Zach Montgomery, of California, was to-day formally appointed Assistant Attorney-General for the Interior Department.
BRENHAM, Texas, May 25.--Jefferson Bassett, the junior member of the private banking firm of Bassett Bassett, committed suicide this morning.

President Robert Harris, of the Northern Pacific; Elijah Smith, of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company, and Sidney Dillon, representing the Union Pacific, conferred yesterday in regard to the joint lease of the Railway and Navigation line.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25.--News has just reached here that the Yosemite stage which left Madera Friday morning was robbed by highwaymen near Clark's Station.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 25.--Mrs. G.O. Holden, of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, in this city, has for several years taken a great interest in educating and Christianizing the Chinese laundrymen of this city, and has associated with her in the work about 20 other ladies connected with the church.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., May 25.--John Sturm, a German Catholic, who belonged to the local Grand Army post, died on Saturday. Before his death he expressed a wish to be buried with post honors.
OLEAN, N.Y., May 25.--George Gardner, who lost a fortune in unlucky oil land speculation, has been working as a teamster at Petroleum Centre for several years.

A meeting of the Eastern trunk line railroad Presidents and the managers of some of the Western railroad lines will be held in Commissioner Fink's office to-day for the purpose of discussing the question of a restoration of rates.
Yesterday morning Mr. George Law, a well-known soap manufacturer of Haledon, near Paterson, N.J., drove into the city with a lady, a neighbor, and stopped at a harness store to get a new bridle.
An inquest was held yesterday in the case of Catherine Reilly, the wife of Thomas Reilly, a cabman, living at No, 146 West Nineteenth-street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 25.--To-day closed a very successful meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club. The weather was bright and pleasant, the attendance good, the track in excellent condition, and the time in the first race was the best heat record yet made for the distance.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., May 25.--James W. McCutchin, who set fire to the house in which his family were sleeping at Philadelphia, last November, and fled to Canada, has been captured and lodged in jail here.

CHICAGO, May 25.--Early this afternoon Detectives Cosgrove and Palmer walked to the Newberry Furniture Company's establishment, at No. 284 Wabash-avenue, and arrested Charles E. Ackran, employed there as a salesman.
The feast of Pingster was celebrated duly by the St. Nicholas Club last evening, at the club rooms, at No. 12 East Twenty-ninthstreet.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 25.--Mrs. Walker McCarty, of Beallsville, while in a despondent mood this morning, went to the stable, and, fastening a rope about her neck and then to a rafter, drew on it so as to choke herself to death.

BALTIMORE, May 25.--The fashionable society and club circles of Baltimore were well represented in the Criminal Court to-day. Some were there as witnesses and others to satisfy their curiosity.

Samuel Parsons, Jr., of Flushing, was yesterday appointed Superintendent of Central Park, in place of Aneurin Jones, removed. Mr. Jones was appointed in 1881. He hailed from Wilkesbarre, Penn., and was a house carpenter.
READING, Penn., May 25.--St. Paul's Catholic Church, a structure recently remodeled, and St. Joseph's Hospital were to-day consecrated by Archbishop Ryan, assisted by 100 priests.
The Retail Grocers' Union last evening adopted a standard of weights for measuring fruits and vegetables in dealing them out to customers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 25.--A tremendous waterspout, eight miles south of the city, has done great damage. Fields of corn were washed away and fences scattered in every direction. The spout traveled in a northeasterly direction, and was a mile in width.

PRINCETON, May 25.--A large and enthusiastic audience assembled in University Hall this evening to hear the first annual contest between the class music clubs.

OTTAWA, May 25.--It is reported that the Dominion Government have been notified of two cases of cholera having appeared on an inward bound vessel, and that the patients have been landed at the Grosse Isle quarantine station.
COLUMUUS, Ohio, May 25.--About 250 miners began work at New-Straitsville this morning at the rate of 40 cents a ton.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25.--The Central Union Telephone Company has given notice to all renters of telephones in Indiana that the company will avail itself of the contract privilege to remove their instruments on June 30, the day on which the law regulating telephone rentals passed by the late Legislature goes into effect.

A deputy in the Ludlow-Street Jail told James D. Fish yesterday afternoon that some gentlemen were waiting to see him in the parlor. The ex-President of the defrauded Marine Bank hurried there to meet them.

The State Civil Service Commission met yesterday morning at the New-York Hotel and did not adjourn until late in the afternoon. All the Commissioners were present and also Chief Examiner Silas W. Burt.

LONDON, May 25.--To-day (Whit-Monday) is a holiday here, and the Bank of England and the Stock Exchange are closed.

CINCINNATI, May 25.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly this morning the Rev. S.B. Bell, D.D., of Missouri, offered resolutions against Sunday newspapers and committing the church to the policy of "what is generally known as prohibition."

WASHINGTON, May 25.--Telegraphic information received at the War Department from Gen. Crook indicates that the hostile Apaches under Geronimo will remain in the mountains of West New-Mexico and raid the settlements.

An unusual dullness pervaded the grain market yesterday, and brokers in the Produce Exchange devoted a good part of the time to skylarking. The inactivity of business was partially attributable to the fact that yesterday being Whitmonday, was a bank holiday in England.
PANAMA, May 17.--The Haytian General, Pautrizelle, and George Davis, alias Cocobolo, a West Indian negro, of Prestan's band, which burned Colon, were executed on the 5th inst.
Messrs. Harrison and Gourlay are to be seen at the Grand Opera House this week in "Skipped by the Light of the Moon."

Lieut. John Loomis Shock, of the United States Navy, whose suicide at Greenwich, England, on Sunday, was mentioned in THE TIMES of yesterday, appears to have been a victim of overstudy and mental aberration.
BURLINGTON, Vt., May 25.--Senator Edmunds has been summoned to testify on points in American law before the British. House of Lords. He will sail on Saturday.
ELMIRA, N.Y., May 25.--James H. Mills, a young married man, for several years kept books at the meat market of Frank B. Sadler, on Lake-street.

A surface railroad through Broadway from Union-square to the Battery, connecting at the former point with the present Broadway and Seventh-avenue line to Central Park, seems now to be an assured fact.

The steamer John Sylvester, which plies between New-York and Staten Island, was passing Governor's Island yesterday morning, when Carl Gottfried Ferron, a septuagenarian dealer in china at No. 1,443 Second-avenue, leaped overboard.

Michael Rosenbaum, a Grand-street dry goods dealer, disappeared from his home and place of business early in the present month. Charging that he had absconded after having defrauded them, his creditors attached and sold ...
PRINCETON, May 25.--Among the many pleasant drives enjoyed by visitors to Princeton the favorite one is by the road leading to the south toward Trenton and through Lawrenceville.

ALTON, Ill., May 25.--This city was struck last night by a tornado, which burst from the southwest, sweeping across the river with terrific fury. Several large buildings on the river front were damaged, some of them seriously.
WILKESBARRE, May 25.--There were two deaths and nine new cases in Plymouth today. The General Executive Committee, at its meeting to-night, voted $500 out of the general ...

Collector Robertson called upon Secretary Daniel Manning, at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, yesterday, and had a pleasant chat. The Collector denies the statement recently printed that he has tendered his resignation to President Cleveland.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, May 25.--Smallpox is raging in Shenandoah. Page County, Iowa, and special police are out guarding the infected houses. Nineteen houses have been thus quarantined. The Mayor and President of the Board of Health both have the disease.
The monument erected by the NewYork Police Department to the memory of Commissioner Sidney P. Nichols was unveiled in Greenwood Cemetery yesterday afternoon.

Since the withdrawal of D.M. Porter from the management of Mrs. O'Keefe's interests in her divorce suit against Ross R. Winans, ex-Judge George M. Curtis has taken up the case and will conduct it before Referee Nash at the hearing to-day.
CHICAGO, May 26.--Frithjof Anderson, a young Norwegian, applied to the Circuit Court to-day to be released from marriage bonds which he claims were forced upon him by fraud and intimidation.
GIRARDVILLE, Penn., May 26.--Eleven months ago Adam Mart, a veteran of the war, who was wounded at the battle of Buli Run, received through the Pension Agency at Washington $1,000.

DETROIT, May 26.--The Post Office Department has informed William G. SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 26.--Yesterday afternoon Mrs. Max Rits was sent to the Utica Insane Asylum. This afternoon her husband was struck by a Delaware and Hudson Railroad train and instantly killed. Five children are left.

CHICAGO, May 26.--Frank P. Bernard, formerly employed as a bookkeeper of the Bank of Montreal, was arrested in this city a few days ago by Detective Mathew Pinkerton, on a charge of embezzlement, but Judge Moran today granted a writ of habeas corpus, Pinkerton's ...
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 25.--Two young men who were rowing in the harbor last night approached the British warship Canada and were hailed by the sentry.

Edgar P. Putnam, Postmaster, at Jamestown, N.Y., has been suspended, and Charles E. Weeks will take his place. Mr. Putnam was appointed only a little more than a year ago upon the recommendation of Represensative Brewer.

The efforts now being made to find a market in the Northern States for the recently issued $3,500,000 of 5 per cent. Georgia State bonds are being stoutly resisted by persons who hold portions of the $8,000,000 of State bonds repudiated by Georgia in 1873.

The annual meeting of the Produce Exchange was held in the call room yesterday. The President, J. Hobart Herrick, made an address, in which he said that the Exchange has passed through a year of unusual commercial depression with less suffering and distress than any other branch of trade or manufactures.

CINCINNATI, May 26.--The Superior Court to-day granted a restraining order upon the petition of the Taxpayers' League enjoining the Board of Public Works and the City Controller from issuing about $300,000 in bonds for the purpose of supplying deficiencies in the Board of Health, infirmary, and general funds.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--A good-looking, well-built man came with the crowd of callers at the Pension Office this morning and entered the room of First Deputy Commissioner McLean. When his turn for an interview was reached he asked the Deputy to be allowed to see the Commissioner.

James and John Ryan are brothers who live at No. 1,260 Second-avenue. While taking dinner there yesterday a dispute arose about some trivial matter, but eventually the quarrel quieted down, and James left the house.
LOUISVILLE, May 26.--Louisville won a game from the Metropolitans to-day, pounding Lynch for 16 hits, making the third time in succession that the home nine has secured 16 hits to a game.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, May 26.--Capt. Smith, of the Fourth Cavalry, had a fight last Friday with the Apaches in the Mogollan Mountains, 20 miles east of Alma. The Indians were routed. Their loss is unknown. The troops are crowding the redskins. Another conflict is expected at any moment.

There was to have been a meeting of the Mayor, the Commissioner of Street Cleaning, and the Board of Health in the Mayor's office yesterday, but as a majority of the members of the Health Board were absent the meeting was postponed until to-day.

A lighted taper on the altar of the Roman Catholic church on Montrose-avenue Brooklyn, during service on Monday afternoon ignited some artificial flowers, and for a time it looked as if a dangerous fire would ensue.

CINCINNATI, May 26.--The residence of Col. T.C. Campbell was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. Campbell and his wife have been absent since last Wednesday, leaving their two sons at home with the gardener and his wife, who acted as housekeeper.
George N. Walling, of the Railway Postal Service, was killed yesterday morning on an outgoing train of the New-York Central Road, at One Hundred and Twelfth-street and Fourthavenue.

The final concert of this season of the Bayonne City Philharmonic Society, Mr. L.C. Jacoby conductor, given at Bergen Point, N.J., last evening, was very successful. The programme included part songs by Mendelssohn, Hatton, Kucken, and Barnby, four choruses for male voices, a duet from "L'Elixir d'Amor," and Gounod's motett "Ave Verum." The soloists were Miss H.W. Amerman, Mr. E. Blanchard, and Mr. Jacoby.

PARIS, May 26.--It is officially announced that Victor Hugo will be buried in the Pantheon. Before this announcement was made a decree had been drafted secularizing the Pantheon in order to permit of the interment therein of Hugo's body.

SIMLA, India, May 26.--The troops of the Second Corps have been informed that they are no longer required for immediate service. This is the corps which the Duke of Connaught, who was on his way to England, was recently summoned back to command.

Fifteen hundred little boys and girls belonging to the Baptist Sunday schools of Harlem marched about the shady paths of Mount Morris Park yesterday afternoon carrying flags and banners of many colors.

UTICA, N.Y., May 26.--At a meeting today of the Directors of the New-York State Baseball League James Jackson, manager of the Rochester team, was deprived of membership because of the non-payment of fees and dues, and W. Rheinhardt was admitted from Rochester in his stead. A.G. Rheinhardt, President of the Rochester Association, was authorized to accept the transfer of the players, nearly all of whom have consented to play under a new management.

The dispatch boat Dolphin steamed slowly away from her pier at John Roach's shipyard early yesterday morning, headed for the Sound. Passengers looked at her from the decks of incoming Sound steamers with some curiosity, under the impression that she was undergoing another trial to demonstrate that she was fit for the Government's acceptance.

CAPE CHARLES CITY, Va., May 26.--In an altercation last night between W.T. Rayfield and John Young, the former struck the latter, and inflicted wounds from which Young died today. The dispute was provoked by some trifling affair, and the punishment inflicted upon Young ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 26.--An elopement took place in this city this morning, the young ady being Miss Sena, daughter of W.Y. Miles, President of the Board of Trade and member of the firm of Miles, Bancroft Sheldon.

MONTREAL, May 26.--Judge Gill rendered judgment this morning in a most peculiar action, in which the plaintiff, Mrs. Waldron, sues her daughter, Mrs. Alfred Eaves, for $5,000 for defamatory and malicious libel.

The Department of State received to-day a report from Mr. Osborn, Minister to Brazil, in regard to the arrest and imprisonment of Beckford Mackey, United States Consul at Rio Grande do Sul. It appears that Mr. Mackey had ...

The new library building of the General Theological Seminary of the Protestant Episcopal Church, at Twenty-first-street and Ninthavenue, was formally dedicated by Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter yesterday morning.

A convict named Joseph Pankuch escaped from Sing Sing Prison yesterday morning. At 3:50 o'clock Keeper Abram Jones took him, together with another prisoner, from his cell to go to the kitchen as usual to prepare the breakfast for the other convicts, they being the prison bakers.
Poor little Crowley was better yesterday, having obtained some rest the previous night. He is, however, by no means out of danger yet, and is still taking regular doses of rum and sugar.

The words of censure uttered by a number of leading German papers regarding appointments in the diplomatic and consular service have been eagerly seized not only by Republican but also by Democratic papers, and they have endeavored to construe this into a general antagonistic feeling of the Germans against the Cleveland Administration.

The fact that Judge Phelps in the Circuit Court at Baltimore had authorized Receiver Stevens, of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company, to sell all of that company's property in the State of Maryland, gave rise yesterday to various Wall-street rumors concerning the future of the Bankers and Merchants' Company.

ALBANY, May 26.--The Governor's chamber resembled one of the ante-rooms of the Legislature to-day. Members of the two houses wandered in and out and communed with vistors whose faces were familiar at the regular session and at committee hearings throughout last Winter and Spring.

Dr. Henry B. Millard made yesterday what he hopes will be his last appearance in the witness chair before the Surrogate in the Hoyt will contest. Before Senator Evarts began to question him Dr. Millard asked to be allowed to make a statement.
Two women, one middle-aged and the other young, looked daggers at a stout, comfortable-looking German whom Officer Weiss brought into Essex Market Police Court yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--A special meeting of the Eastern League of Professional Baseball Clubs was held at the Girard House this afternoon. The delegates in attendance were: Joseph Simmons, Virginia Club, Richmond, Va.; Michael Scanlan, National, Washington, D.C.; ...

To-morrow the Dolphin is to make her fourth trial trip in the quiet waters of the Sound, and in case her machinery can be worked for a few hours and she can attain a fair rate of speed she will afterward make a trial trip at sea, provided, of course, a sufficient number of reckless men can be found to go to sea in her.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 26.--Theodore Vandever, a rich farmer who lives near Harville, Butler County, Mo., was robbed of $4,000 Sunday night. The thieves numbered four and were masked.
From poverty and distress the family of Gustav Fleischer, the German carpenter who tried on Monday to jump off the Brooklyn bridge, were raised yesterday to comparative affluence.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 26.--Shelbyville was startled this morning by the report of a child murder and suicide of a peculiarly distressing nature, which took place last night in the vicinity of Manilla, a town on the Jeffersonville, Madison and Indianapolis Railroad, in the western edge of Rush County.

Mr. ZACHARIAH MONTGOMERY, who has just been made Assistant Attorney-General for the Interior Department, has gained his unfavorable opinions about the common school system, not through the perversity, but by the natural shallowness and imbecility, of his mind.

The iron centreboard yacht Priscilla, which will represent the New-York Yacht Club in the international race for the America's cup in August, arrived in this harbor yesterday in tow of the tug Ocean King. She was taken to Poillon's ship yard at the foot of Bridgestreet ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 26.--Samuel Radcliffe, a highly respected and wealthy woolen manufacturer, of Shelton, aged 50, committed suicide at midnight last night by jumping into the canal at Shelton, where he was drowned. He had been in poor health for a number of years and traveled all over the country to obtain relief, but despaired of recovery.

Gustave F. Kindt, alias Isadore Marchal, alias "French Gus," was again arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning. Mr. Mellvil Horton, of the firm of G.B. Horton Co., leather dealers, at No. 59 Frankfort-street, made a complaint of burglary against him.
PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--Three races were trotted at the opening of the Spring meeting at Belmont Park to-day.
LEXINGTON, Ky., May 26.--The trial of Lucretia Munday for the murder of her husband in conjunction with her son-in-law, Dr. Davies, was begun here to-day.
NEW-ORLEANS, May 26.--Three thousand people witnessed the St. John's Club's sculling regatta at West End, Lake Pontchartrain, today. The favorites fared badly, and considerable money changed hands.

MONTREAL, May 26.--Dr. Ross, Premier of the Province of Quebec, is going to NewYork to borrow money, of which his Government stands in great need. He makes the usual statement that he is going for medical advice.

The mysterious disappearance of the Rev. Oscar F. Brown, the Rector of the Reformed Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, in West Fifty-first-street, near Ninth-avenue, was reported at Police Headquarters late last night.

OTTAWA, Ontario, May 26.--An examination of the pubilc accounts shows that J.G. Baker Co., of which firm Conrad, of Montana, is the moving spirit, have drawn over $2,000,000 during the past four years for supplies in the Northwest.

EUFAULA, Ala., May 26.--City Clerk E.L. Catteville committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the brain. He leaves a widow and six children. It is believed that he was behind in his accounts $1,500 or $2,000. His family is almost destitute, but he was insured in several secret organizations to the amount of $10,000 or $12,000.

KEY WEST, Fla., May 26.--The Cubans here are parading the streets with bands of music in consequence of the reported landing at Santiago de Cuba of an expedition, numbering 200 men, under Varona and Maceo, which, it is stated, has since been reinforced by 1,000 men from that district. A state of siege has been decreed, and the Captain-General of Cuba has gone with the troops to that province.

Col. Lamont, the President's private secretary, yesterday telegraphed Gen. Martin T. McMahon that Mr. Cleveland will be at the Windsor Hotel Saturday morning at 9:30 o'clock, together with Secretaries Endicott, Whitney, and Lamar, and Postmaster-General Vilas.
LONDON, May 26.--M. Pollini, Director of the Stadt Theatre of Hamburg, has concluded a contract with Mme. Patti for the entire Winter of 1885-6, including tours throughout Europe.

PITTSBURG, May 26.--Charles Boyd, who committed forgeries amounting to over $100,000 while connected with S. Hamilton Co., music dealers, of Steubenville, Ohio, arrived in this city to-day in custody of a detective, who captured him in Columbia, S.C., where he first ...

CINCINNATI, May 26.--The Superior Court Judges, sitting in General Term, to-day decided invalid the contracts by which the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company has for three years controlled the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton system of roads.
LONDON, May 26.--An inquest was held this afternoon in the case of Lieut. John Loomis Shock, of the United States Navy, who shot himself last Sunday at his lodgings near London.

Letters of administration upon the estate of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderbilt, widow of Commodore Vanderbilt, were granted yesterday by the Surrogate to her brother, Robert L. Crawford, who, with her mother, Mrs. Martha E. Crawford, are the surviving members of her father's family.

PITTSBURG, May 26.--Two more deaths have occurred in the Brockford family at Paris Roads from the disease which has within a few weeks caused 30 deaths. It is rapidly spreading, and there are 30 new cases.

The Spring regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club will occur on Saturday of this week. The start will be a flying one, and the yachts of the different classes will cross the starting line between 10:30 and 11 o'clock A.M.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--There appears to be very little foundation for the reports circulated that the surveyors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad laying the route for the new road in the "Neck" have been driven away with guns.

Over 400 laborers and mechanics were engaged yesterday in the construction of the new surface railroad on Broadway from Fourteenth-street to the Battery, and the progress made was rapid and satisfactory to Contractor Wharton and the officers of the new road.

The flight of GERONIMO and his band of fifty Chiricahua Apaches from the San Carlos Reservation and their murderous raid upon the settlers seems to have been caused by the restlessness and inherent depravity of these Indians rather than by unfair treatment.

At the office of the United States Life Insurance Company, No. 261 Broadway, is a cabinet-size photograph of Norman B. Harwood, whose death occurred in Florida last week, and who had policies on his life to the amount of $200,000.

MEMPHIS, May 26.--In the Criminal Court to-day Walker Kennedy, editor of the Sunday Times, who spat in Attorney-General Turner's face in open court last week, was sentenced to pay $50 and serve 10 days in jail.

GRIFFIN, Ga., May 26.--Milton Smith, 16 years of age, while playing with a pistol, in company with Richard Price, a companion, shot himself through the heart and died. He didn't know the pistol was loaded.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 26.--George Peabody Wetmore was inaugurated Governor of Rhode Island to-day. The streets of this city were crowded with visitors from all parts of the State. Gov. Bourne and staff, members of the Legislature, , were escorted to the ...
LONDON, May 26.--Mr. James Russell Lowell delivered an oration at Cambridge to-day on the occasion of the unveiling of the bust of the poet Gray.
About $3,000,000 was paid out of the Treasury to-day for pensions, making the total amount paid out on that account during the present month about $10,000,000.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 26.--Adam Brunn and Katie Bohn are the son and daughter, respectively, of farmers living in Hanover Township, this county.

Capt. Samuel Burroughs, of the bark Philadelphia, now lying at a dock near Hudsonavenue, Brooklyn, was awakened at about 1 o'clock yesterday morning by his wife, who said she had heard cries for help.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 26.--Thomas Shortell, alias Wilson, and Thomas Conners, alias Lewis, alias Williams, two New-York crooks, were tried to-day in the United States Circuit Court for passing and having in their possession $1,200 of counterfeit money, some of which they passed at the races recently.

CINCINNATI, May 26.--At a meeting of the members of the whisky pool this afternoon it was decided to restrict the manufacture of spirts to 20 per cent. of the capacity, and not to permit manufacture in excess of that limit even for export.

Jay Gould and Russell Sage, as Trustees of the Kansas Pacific Railroad, have recently been purchasing and retiring the Kansas Pacific consolidated bonds with funds received from the sale of lands belonging to that company. Since Dec. 24 last about $710,000 of Kansas Pacific consols have been canceled by the Trustees.
Surrounded by friends and flowers police Captain Williams, in full-dress uniform, sat on a platform in Lyric Hall, Sixth-avenue, last night, and modestly listened to several very flattering speeches.
WASHINGTON, May 26.--Secretary Whitney returned to-day from New-York, where he inspected the Omaha last Saturday.

Just as Dr. John Bell and his young daughter, Miss Ella, of No. 233 Warren-street, Brooklyn, were driving by the house No. 257 Warren-street, at about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, a large tree, at which two men had been cutting for some time, cracked and snapped, and, leaning over the street, crashed directly across the seat of the doctor's buggy.

EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio, May 26.--Angus Bratt walked up to the room of Jefferson C. Davis, at the Caldwell House, to-night, called him to the door, and deliberately emptied the five chambers of his revolver into his body.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 26.--This afternoon a small boat containing two young men was taken from a passing tow-opposite this city, and the men were brought up to Police Headquarters.

Edmund H. Dewey, a lawyer, of No. 30 West Forty-seventh-street, was stricken down at his office in the Stewart Building yesterday, and an ambulance was called from the Chambers-Street Hospital.
A large number of the members of the Cotton Exchange listened to the reading of the fifteenth annual report of the Board of Managers, in the new board room, yesterday noon.

The Virginia Club, the leader in the fight for the Eastern League championship, easily defeated the Jersey City nine in Jersey City yesterday. The visitors outplayed their opponents both at the bat and in the field, and won by figures of 10 to 6.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26.--The house No. 2,009 Chestnut-street, known as "Gen. Grant's house," was sold at auction to-day by M. Thomas Sons under the-instructions of William H. Vanderbilt, for the sum of $22,500. Frank K. Hess, of No. 205 South Sixth-street, was the purchaser.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 26.--A week ago Deputy Sheriff O'Neil, while on his way to NewYork City, noticed in the car in which he sat two men who were acting in a suspicious manner, such as asking passengers where they were going, , and made up his mind that they were thieves.

READING, Penn., May 26.--A wreck on the Reading Railroad occurred at Sanatoga Station last night. The axle under a gondola car broke, tearing up several hundred feet of track and precipitating 18 loaded coal cars into the river. This was at midnight. It took seven hours to clear the tracks, and all passenger trains were late this morning.
GAINSVILLE, Ga., May 26.--Mrs. Keith, a well-known lady of Harmony Grove, committed suicide to-day by jumping into a well 65 feet deep.
DONGOLA, May 26.--The British and Egyptian troops have laft Merawi in boats for the Lower Nile.

PARIS, May 26.--As many as 8,000 people went to the Cemetery of Pere la Chaise yesterday to attend the interment of the revolutionist Cournet.

WASHINGTON, May 26.--The report of the committee of Treasury officers upon the distinctive fibre paper has not yet been signed, but it is understood that it will not be favorable to the paper.

WASHINGTON, Penn., May 26.--Several hundred persons assembled on the gymnasium grounds this afternoon to witness the tenth annual contest in Olympics between the Junior and Sophomore Classes of Washington and Jefferson Colleges. The battle was easily won by the Juniors, the contest resulting in their favor by a score of 11 to 3.
Bondholders of the Houston and Texas Central Railroad have received notice from C. P. Huntington within the past two or three days that he withdraws the proposition recently made by him to them.

BALTIMORE, May 26.--Many well-known society people again thronged the Criminal Court this morning at the trial of James Graham Pearre, charged with attempting a felonious assault upon Mrs. Estelle M. Kirkland, a widow, at the Albion Hotel.
Day before yesterday GUSTAV FLEISCHER was one of the most wretched men living. He was out of work, out of money, out of friends, and his future was as dark as his present.

READING, Penn., May 26.--Samuel W. Barto, who was divorced from his wife several years ago, the custody of a daughter, 7 years old, being given to the mother, produced a sensation by boldly taking the child away from the mother's residence in Sinking Springs yesterday.
CHATTANOOGA, May 27.--Patrick O'Brien, an engineer on the Alabama Great Southern Railroad, attended a picnic given by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineoers at Oakdale Junction to-day.

PARIS, May 27.--The Official Journal publishes a decree restoring the Pantheon to its original use--a receptacle for the remains of great men--and ordering that the body of Victor Hugo be buried there. The funeral has been fixed for Monday next.

The annual parade of the Police Department took place yesterday. About 1,500 of the 2,862 men of the force formed in line at the Battery at 3 o'clock, and began their march up Broadway with four bands of music under Gilmore playing inspiring airs.

ATCHISON, Kan., May 27.--Cyclones visited Nortonsville, Goffs and Frankfort, in Northeastern Kansas, between 10 and 12 o'clock this forenoon, doing great damage to property.

Georgia State bonds might by invested in by savings banks in this State.

RICHMOND, va., May 27.--In the Cluverius murder case to-day the case for the defense was continued. B.W. Healy said he was in Richmond on March 13 and saw the prisoner, but saw no lady with him.

Whatever may be the outcome of the present dispute between Great Britain and Russia--and that to some extent is still doubtful--there is evidence of a radical change in the ultimate policy of the English Government regarding the defense of India.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--At the Point Breeze Park races to-day Blanche won the 2:34 class race in straight heats, Effie aecond, Champion Wilkes third. Time-2:27 ; 2:28 ; 2:30. Mambrino Sparkle won the 2:24 race, also in Straight heats, in 2:23 ; 2:27 . and 2:26 . Revenge took second money, Dick Organ third. Ward Medium was distanced in the second heat.

DENVER, Col., May 27.--Millions of young grasshoppers are reported coming out of the sandy soil on the south side of the Arkansas River above Pueblo, devouring early vegetables and tender shrubs. Their appearance is said to be similar to that of 1872, when they were swept east by winds, and consumed an immense amount of growing crops in Kansas.

CHICAGO, May 27.--Walter Miller, a printer who has been employed in the Inter Ocean composing rooms, and Clara Peters, a domestic working at the residence of Charles P. Kimball, the newly appointed Consul to Stuttgart, are under arrest for robbery.

The second annual session of the American Climatological Association began yesterday afternoon at the hall of the Academy of Medicine in West Thirty-first-street. Delegates from all sections of the country were present.

The fire which early yesterday morning utterly destroyed Henry Hermann's furniture manufactory, Nos. 320 to 334 Delancey-street, was spoken of yesterday by Chief Oscar O. Shay and others as one of the fiercest and fastest they had ever seen.

The Staten Island Rapid Transit Company is bound to maintain a ferry between the foot of Whitehall-street and Bay Ridge. Last Summer it run its boats to the wharf of the Long Island or Manhattan Beach Railroad Company, south of Sixty-fifth-street, Bay Ridge.

The will of Andrew J. Dam was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's office. The instrument is dated Jan. 2, 1884, and John W. Murray, Jacob A. Gross, and Andrew J. Dam, Jr., are made Executors.

PITTSBURG, May 27.--Two new cases, but no deaths, were reported at Paris Roads to-day. The disease is still spreading, but the physicians hope to check it within a few days. They have enforced strict sanitary measures.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, May 27.--The steamer Alert sailed at noon to-day on a scientific expedition to Hudson's Bay.

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, May 27.--The community was startled this afternoon by news of the murder of the keeper of the Sherwood Cemetery, four miles from this city. The victim was Patrick Callaghan, 67 years old, who lived alone at the cemetery.

Capt. Alfred Aylward, whom an Associated Press dispatch from London, in yesterday's papers, charged with having incited Riel's revolt, is in this city. He says that the London story, with one or two trifling exceptions, is utterly untrue.

A new Common Council was elected in Hoboken at the recent charter election. The new Councilmen divided into two factions of four each on the question of a President, and have since at almost nightly meetings balloted fruitlessly for one.
Henry F. Post, alias "Hungry Joe," was sentenced yesterday by Recorder Smyth to four years in the State prison.

The trial of Patrick Hayes, the gambler, who has been on trial for the past two days in the Brooklyn Court of Sessions, charged with having attempted to kill his wife, came to a close yesterday afternoon and the case was given to the jury. HARTFORD, May 27.--In the United States court to-day Postmaster James D. Cook, of Unionville, who was detected a few months ago in robbing the Post Office of that place to the amount of $3,800, of which $900 was made good, was put on trial.
