NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 27.--The Senate and House to-day passed on its first reading a registration bill similar to the law now existing in New-York and Ohio. In the Senate two Republicans voted for the measure.

About two hundred Spaniards met in Tammany Hall last night to discuss the preliminaries for celebrating the fourth centennial of the discovery of America by Columbus. ConsulGeneral Miguel Suarez Guanes presided, and Jose G. Garcia, editor of the New-York Novedades, was Secretary.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 27.--Judge Allen, of the Criminal Court, this evening instructed the Grand Jury to indict all persons found selling or buying pools on races after to-morrow, as he had discovered that the law passed by the Legislature authorizing their sale was unconstitutional. The order created considerable excitement in sporting circles. The pool room proprietors will test the matter in court.

CHICAGO, May 27.--Samuel Richter, proprietor of a pawnshop at No. 373 Clark-street, met with a shocking accident this morning. He was in the rear of his store pumping out oil into a gasoline stove, which was burning.
Mrs. Ellen Healy, of No. 228 West Fortyseventh-street, was fined $10 in the Yorkville court yesterday for assaulting Miss E.J. McKibbin, a teacher in the West Forty-first-street school.

An unusually great variety of assets were disposod of in the Real Estate Exchange by Adrian H. Muller Son yesterday. A mixed lot or property belonging to the estate of James D. Fish was sold by order of Assignee Morris.
QUEBEC, May 27.--The report that Asiatic cholera is prevalent in Quebec is utterly false and unfounded.

A fire was discovered last evening in the cellar of No. 737 Broadway, under the store of the New-York Electric Company. Superintendent Walling, who was on his way home in citizen's attire, was one of the first to see the fire.

A remarkably pretty girl, Miss Lizzie Spinler, of No. 138 Owinnett-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, has for seven years been employed in the tailoring establishment of Louis Dell, at No. 65 Walton-street, and her beauty brought her many suitors of her own station in life.
Holders of about 50 per cent. of the bonds of the Omaha Division of the St. Louis, Kansas City and Northern Railroad met in the office Stewart Boardman, No. 49 Wall-street, yesterday.
ROME, Ga., May 27.--The Vestry of the Episcopal church here has called the Rev. George Dame, of Prince George County, Md., as its Rector.

The old Board of Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company was re-elected at the annual meeting of the stockholders yesterday. Mr. Henry Hart voted in proxies for 154,000 shares, of which all were an favor of the old board, save 20,000 shares, which stipulated that the name of J.W. Shaw be not voted for.

BUFFALO, May 27.--A meeting of leading citizens of Niagara Falls and Suspension Bridge was held at the International Hotel last night to discuss the advisability of a grand demonstration in connection with the formal opening of the Niagara Reservation in July.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27.--Annie Hudson, 18 years old, a girl of uncommon beauty, committed suicide by taking strychnine at a farm house near Camden this morning. Annie lived in the family of Benjamin Collister, on the Pea Shore Road just outside of Camden.
LONDON, May 27.--It is asserted that the English proposals recently offered to the Turkish Envoy, Hassan Fehmi Pasha, for the occupation of the Soudan by Turkey have been declined by the Porte.

LA LIBERTAD, via Galveston, May 27.-- The Salvador Government is concentrating a military force at this place, constructing earthworks and intrenchments. Bands of insurgents, largely composed of Indians, are concentrating 14 leagues from here. An attack on La Libertad is threatened. There is no American or other war vessel on this coast, and foreigners are consequently much alarmed.
The New-York life insurance companies are to be congratulated that the Tontine legislative committee have made a very bitter and hostile report against those companies.

Edward Rowanthal, an 18-year-old steward on the bark Tyburnia, now lying at the foot of Sedgwick-street, Brooklyn, had been jilted by his sweetheart, and yesterday morning he attempted to revenge himself upon his faithless beloved by swallowing a dose of sulphuric acid. He was removed to St. Peter's Hospital, where they physicians pronounced his case hopeless.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29.--The final set in the series of the tennis tournament games was played off this afternoon. The contestants were A.H. Larkin, '87, and T.N. McCarter, Jr., '88, the former winning the championship. The first prize is a racquet. The score was 6--2, 6--2, and 6--3.

"Elks' Rest," in the Cemetery of the Evergreens, East New-York, was yesterday crowded with members of the Benevolent Protective Order of Elks and their friends, who had come to strew flowers on the graves of departed brothers.

Thomas Simons, Assistant AttorneyGeneral, in charge of Government cases before the Court of Claims, has tendered his resignation to the President to take effect June 1, and Robert Howard, of Little Rock, Ark., will succeed him.

Young Mr. Trigg lives with his father at No.106 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixthstreet. He wished to take a drive on the avenue last Thursday afternoon. Accordingly he wrote an order and signed his mother's name to it requesting the Excelsior Livery Stable to deliver to the bearer the family horse and phaeton.

PETERSBURG, Va., May 31.--Thomas H. Harvey, alias "Brighton," of Brooklyn, N.Y., has been arrested here and lodged in jail charged with having committed two forgeries in Manchester, this State.

PITTSBURG, May 31.--Daylight disappeared much less rapidly to-day than on any previous Sunday in May for the last three years. Instead of the solid wall of black smoke, which Pittsburgers have been accustomed to see rise alone the south banks of the Monongahela and Allegheny on the after-noon ...
Michael Springer, a butcher, of No. 242 Fifth-street, was somewhat intoxicated Saturday evening, when he called on the servants at the French hotel, No. 47 East Tenth-street.

WEST POINT, May 31.--The pleasant annual epoch of busy excitement and social gayiety which is every year permitted to disturb the calm and monotonous serenity of this soldiers' stronghold in the Highlands will begin to-morrow.

CHICAGO, May 31.--A strange story of murderous hallunication, which resulted in the death of one and possibly two persons, was developed here this afternoon upon the arrival of the Kansas City express over the Wabash Road.
ALBANY, May 31.--Tip which way they may, the scales will tumble a big heap of loaves and fishes into the lap of the politicians as the result of the campaign in this State this Fall.
John Ruse, 40 years old, and Jos Moatz, 10 years his junior, both Italian laborers and unmarried, have lived together in a basement at No. 110 Front-street, Brooklyn.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, May 31.--At Sioux City last night, during the progress of a temperance meeting, a man arose and said that the "wife" of the lecturer, who was sitting on the stage, was his runaway wife.

LANCASTER, Pa., May 31.--A heavy thunder and hail storm, accompanied by a strong wind, passed over the northern end of this county this afternoon. The wind tore strong trees up by the roots and threw them across the roadway and in some instances tobacco barns were picked up bodily and demolished. The hail stones, which were very large, fell to an unusual depth.

HEARNE, Texas, May 31.--The waters of the Brazos River yesterday reached the highest mark ever previously known. The bottom lands of a great many plantations are submerged to the depth of several feet. The loss on crops in this section will be very heavy. Last night the river had ceased rising.

QUEBEC, May 31.--Information has been received here from the Government exploring expedition now at Mistassini that Mr. Bignell, P.L.S., of this city, who was sent out in charge of the expedition as its chief, has been succeeded by Mr. Lowe, of Ottawa, a member of the Dominion ...

WHEELING, West Va., May 31.--A sensation has been created at Weston, Lewis County, by the discovery of the theft of 600 indictments, found by the last Grand Jury, from the Clerk's office, in the Court House. The indictments were principally against saloon keepers and wholesale liquor dealers, a few of whom, it is alleged, contributed enough money to secure the abstraction of the records.
At the inspection of the First Brigade, National Guard, by Gov. Abbett, at Riverside, near Paterson, N.J., on Saturday, the Fourth Regiment (Jersey City) rendezvoused near the Erie Railroad track.

President Cleveland spent yesterday at Secretary of the Whitney's home, entertaining callers until afternoon, when he was driven to the Pennsylvania Railroad Station and took the 4 o'clock train for Washington.
The twentieth anniversary of the Hebrew Free School Association was celebrated in the Lexington-Avenue Opera House yesterday morning.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31.--The herd of buffaloes at the Zoological Garden is increasing, three little wooly coated strangers having come into the world during the past week.

CHICAGO, May 31.--The corner stone of the new synagogue of the Temple of Zion congregation was laid this afternoon at Ogden-avenue and Washing Boulevard. Dr. Thomas, the well known Liberal minister of this city, took an active part in the ceremonies, which were conducted by Dr. Felsenthal and other rabbis in the presenco of a very large throng of spectators.

A paragraph having appeared in a Milan newspaper stating that there have been 50 suicides at Monte Carlo during this season, it has been copied into most English papers, accompanied by much moral disquisition.

A party of seven men who had been drinking hired a boat and took a row on the North River yesterday. About 4:30 in the afternoon, when they were opposite Forty-thirdstreet, the hat of one of them, James Hickey, of No. 511 West Thirtieth-street, blew oft. He jumped into the water for it and was drowned. The body was recovered.

CITY OF MEXICO, May 31, via Galveston. --Robert Hardy, an American, 21 years old, was murdered here at a public dancing party by a Mexican at 5 o'clock this morning. Jealousy was the cause of the deed.

LIMA, May 31, via Galveston.--A military display, including a sham fight and artillery manoeuvring, took place just outside this city on Friday. The President and the Ministers were present.

A trout was caught last Tuesday in the Kennet at Newbury which weighed 16 pounds. It was a well-known fish, and many anglers had visited Newbury in the hope of catching it, but it had always evaded the hook, although it could be seen every day swimming for hours in the neighborhood of the bridge. It was captured by means of a net, a scandalously unsportsmanlike proceeding, which ought not to have been allowed.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton discussed the revision of the Old Testament yesterday before a large audience. It was curious to note, he said, the national idiosyncrasies that came forth in the conjoint labors of the English and American revisers.

The weather of last week was entirely too cool to ripen fruit very rapidly, consequently the supply of strawberries was not so great as was expected. Nor were they so good as they would have been had there been less cloudy weather.
Louis Muller, the German chef at Huber's Prospect House, in East Fourteenth-street, and Adolph Christian, who works under Muller, had words in the kitchen yesterday afternoon.

Here is a droll story about Gen. Gordon that has not yet found its way into print. The General entertained peculiar ideas concerning the Edenic apple by which Mother Eve introduced "death and all our woe" into the world.

LONDON, May 31.--The Marquis of Hartington has returned from his visit to Ireland. He has fully recovered his health.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 31.--Decoration Day was observed here on a scale surpassing that of all previous years.
BOSTON, May 31.--Charles Stevens, who stole $20,000 bonds and fled from this city in September last, was arrested in Detroit to-day.

BAINBRIDGE, Ga., May 31.--On Wednes day last two colored raftsmen on Flint River, from near Cheevertown, reported the drowning, on the morning previous, of Robert Gary, who had been operating with them.
Those who wish to see the benefits of university education extended to women have every reason to be satisfied with the rapidly increasing success of the ladies' colleges at Cambridge and Oxford.
The contest at the annual election of the Cotton Exchange to-day promises to be a very sharp one. Two tickets are in the field, both headed by Siegfried Gruner for President.

VICKSBURG, May 31.--Mr. Polk Bass is here on the way to Baton Rouge for the purpose of investigating the status of M.S. Powell, the defaulting Sheriff of East Carroll Parish, and in the interest of the appointment of a successor to Powell. Powell is a fugitive, his defalcation amounting, it is claimed, to $15,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 31.--The various street car companies having given notice to their drivers of a reduction of wages to $50 a month, to commence June 1, the drivers in turn give notice to the companies that they will go out on a strike at daylight to-morrow morning. There is much bad feeling, and trouble may ensue. This is the third car drivers' strike in a year.

The door of Clark R. Trumbull's stationery stone, at the corner of Bond-street and the Bowery, was found open late last night. As the German Exchange Bank is in the same building, it was suspected that burglars had gained access to in that way. The police surrounded the bank and made a search, which proved that the suspicion was unfounded.

ST. LOUIS, May 31.--A waterspout burst in Yankee Branch and Crooked Creek Valleys, Crawford County, Mo., Friday afternoon, and swept nearly everything out of them. Fences, growing crops, and all portable things were carried away and nearly all the farms on Yankee Branch were almost destroyed, the soil being washed off to the depth of several feet. The damage will reach many thousands of dollars.
The Rev. Elias Nason, of North Bellenca, Mass., will read a paper on "Daniel Webster--the Secret of His Power" at the meeting of the New-York Historical Society to-morrow evening.
RICHMOND, Va., May 31.--Mr. W.L. Royall, who has been the legal representative of the foreign bondholders in all of their suits against the State of Virginia, leaves to-night for London.
ATLANTA, Ga., May 31.--A remarkable revival of religion has succeeded the National Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., May 31.--Capt. Lyman came to this town from New-York not long ago. Capt. Lyman is a woman, and she commands the Salvation Army here.
An alleged interview with Mr. WILLIAM H. VANDERBILT was published in NewYork on Saturday in the form of a cable dispatch from London. Its contents hardly justify the expense of transmission.

CITY OF MEXICAN, May 31, via Galveston. --The House of Deputies adjourned at 10 o'clock this morning until Sept. 16. Last evening various appropriation bills were passed and provisions were made for the appointment of a Committee of Fifteen to arrange unfinished business. Committees were also appointed to inform the President and Senate of the adjournment. It has been generally expected that the session would be prolonged.
Coroner Tice was summoned to Bedford, Westchester County, to hold an inquest yesterday in the case of Mrs. Anna N. Weed, wife of Samuel P. Weed, a carpenter.

John Helriegel, the German who attempted to jump off the bridge Saturday afternoon, was taken before Justice Walsh, in Brooklyn, yesterday, and, on complaint of Officer Gannon, committed to the RaymondStreet Jail for examination this morning at 10 o'clock.
Among the passengers of the Hamburg steamship Westphalia, which sailed yesterday afternoon, were 180 Bohemians, who are on their way to their native land for a short visit.

MONTREAL, May 31.--A deputation arrived here from Jamaica this evening to confer with the Dominion Government in reference to obtaining a reciprocity treaty with Canada.

SILVER CITY, New-Mexico, May 31.-- Although the Indians have apparently left this immediate vicinity, many fresh trails have been discovered in the country about here. The trails are small, indicating that the bands are broken up and are wandering through the country, doubtless seeking a way to escape.

HUDSON, N.Y., May 31.--Patrick Sherman, a resident of this city, 56 years old, was instantly killed Saturday evening while walking on the truck of the Hudson River Railroad near Stockport, being struck by the "flyer," which was running at the rate of 50 miles an hour.

A woman about 50 years of age, and who wore the garb of a Sister of Charity, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday. She screamed frantically whenever an officer approached her, and seemed to be insane. She is a German and was registered as Mary Doe.
ROME, Ga., June 1.--James Dunn, a wellto-do farmer, cut his throat from ear to ear today. Bad health was the cause of the suicide.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 1.--Owing to a reduction of 10 per cent. in their wages the freight crews of the Kentucky Central Railroad have struck. No freight trains are running on the road to-day. The workmen in the roundhouse are also out.
The steamship Etruria, which arrived off the bar shortly before noon on Sunday, and was detained seven hours by fog, came up to the city yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 1.--A pleuropueumonia bill was passed by the Senate today. The Governor is directed to appoint two Commissioners to inspect cattle thought to be diseased. Cattle that may be ordered to be killed shall be paid for at regular rates for beef per pound. Five thousand dollars is appropriated to carry out the provisions of the act.
ALBANY, June 1.--There are rumors of dissensions in the new Capitol Commission just appointed by the Legislature. The gates were not opened to the workmen this morning as had been expected.

ALBANY, June 1.--The appointment of Deputy Attorney-General Maynard as Second Controller of the Treasury at Washington was received with satisfaction at the Capitol, especially in the Attorney-General's Department. He has proved a most efficient official, a courteous gentleman, and an able lawyer.

The brigantine Ambrose Light, formerly of Philadelphia, which was captured a few weeks ago by the American man-of-war Alliance and taken into Aspinwall, arrived at Quarantine late last evening under the command of Lieut. Fisher Wright and a prize crew.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., June 1.--In the United States Court to-day Thomas E. Platt, President of the United States Express Company, filed a suit against the Lafayette, Bloomington, and Muncie Railway Company, the Lake Erie and Western Railway Company, the Central Trust Company of New-York, and George J. McGourkey.
SING SING, N.Y., June 1.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for May were $21,761 26; the expenditures, $15,759 68, and the profit for the month, $6,001 58.

Disturbing influeuces are still at work among the railroads of the Northwest. The Dubuque and Northwestern Railroad, projected to run from Dubuque, Iowa, to a connection on the Minnesota State line near Mona with the Minnesota and Northwestern for St. Paul, is assuming tangible form.

The thirty-third annual session of the International Typographical Union was opened yesterday morning in Irving Hall, with 110 delegates present, representing 88 unions in various cities throughout the United States and Canada.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., June 1.--Hathaway, Soule Harrington, shoe manufacturers, employing about 300 hands, gave notice some days ago that a revision of the scale of wages on piece work would take elect to-day.

MONTREAL, June 1.--The Union Bank of Lower Canada has to-day issued a circular marked "confidential" to the shareholders, saying that on account of heavy losses at the Winnipeg branch it would be impossible for them to pay a dividend out of the earnings of the current half year.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 1.--Chief of Police Lipscomb, of Manchester, arrived here this evening to take to that place for trial Thomas H. Harvie, of Brooklyn, N.Y., who is in jail here charged with forging the name of Walker Co., of Wilmington, Del. Owing to the serious illness of the wife of the accused his removal was postponed until Thursday.

LONDON, June 1.--Mapleson will open a short operatic season in the middle of June at the Covent Garden Theatre, with Mme. Patti in "Carmen."

WASHINGTON, June 1.--Lieut. George C. Foulk, of the navy, under date of Seoul, Corea, March 29, has sent to the Navy Department an account of the destruction of the American schooner Sherman and the beheading of a portion of her crew on the coast of Corea in 1866.

HARTFORD, June 1.--The Judges of the Supreme and Superior Courts at their annual session to-day reappointed all the present State attorneys and made an allotment of Judges for the year ending May next.

WEST POINT, June 1.--To the visitors already here awaiting the annual exhibition of various mental and physical soldierly accomplishments that will begin to-morrow this has been a day of almost intolerable dullness.

Some of the newspapers that do not like any of President Cleveland's appointments complained that Col. Charles Denby, of Indiana, who was named by the President as Minister to China, had closed his war record by resignation in consequence of the emancipation of the blacks.

SYRACUSE, June 1.--The Syracuse Journal, Republican, authoritatively announces that Senator McCarthy is a candidate for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant-Governor, and will ask for the support of the delegates from this district.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 1.--Etta Lewis, the Connecticut young woman who recently enlivened Newark, N.J., by disporting in man's clothes, is credited with an interesting career in this town and in Derby.

CHICAGO, June 1.--Henry Magoon, of Argyle Township, Ill., 60 years of age, it is alleged, has eloped with a girl 14 years old, the daughter of C. Smith, a wealthy farmer. Magoon formerly worked for Smith, and while there made love to the child. When this was discovered he was discharged. Then he corresponded with her through the Post Office, and, meeting her here, both went West.

Principal Kelly, of Public School No. 8, in Jersey City, has frequently complained to the School Board that the ceilings in the primary department were not safe.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--A long and interesting opinion was rendered to-day in the Court of Claims by Chief-Justice Richardson, the full bench concurring, on the claim of the Cherokees East of the Mississippi River for a partition of the funds and proceeds of lands held by the Cherokee Nation.

Surrogate Rollins yesterday granted an application of H. Mason Raborg to be appointed guardian of his brother and sister, all being the children of Dr. Samuel A. Raborg, who a few years ago was a well-known and prosperous physician living a Fiftieth-street.

CINCINNATI, June 1.--This morning the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church selected Minneapolis, Minn., as the place for the annual Assembly to be held in Westminster Church, that city.

The most closely contested election that has ever occurred in the Produce Exchange resulted yesterday in the advancement of VicePresident Charles M. Vail to the Presidency by a majority of two votes over Alexander E. Orr.

CHICAGO, June 1.--The leading produce markets were quite active to-day, and main took a lower range of prices. Fine weather and absence of demand from outside were the principal reasons for the weakness, as on more than one day of last week.

MAHANOY PLAIN, Penn., June 1.--The Philadelphia and Reading coal miners went to work this morning in all this region, and mining will continue uninterruptedly until the quota for June (2,500,000 tons) has been sent to market. Trade continues dull.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--The movement of troops from the Washington Barracks began last night. Battery H. Capt. Wilson and Lieut. Crawford, and Battery B. Capt. Grugan and Lieut. Lewis, left Washington by the Baltimore and Ohio Road for their new station at Barrancas, Fla.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 1.--Aaron A. Chase, editor of the Scranton Times, walked from the court room to the County Jail to-day in custody of the Sheriff, and this afternoon's issue of his paper announced that for the next 60 days he would edit it from his cell.

HAVANA, May 28.--The leaders of the Conservative Party appeared before the Governor-General on the 23d inst. and offered, in the name of the party, to assist him in repelling the filibusters who recently landed in the Province of Santiago de Cuba.

NORFOLK, Va., June 1.--Capt. Wyndham R. Mays, the newly appointed Collector of Customs at this port, assumed the duties of his office to-day. The first thing he did was to remove several offensive partisans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 1.--The Ohio Legislature on April 29 passed a bill which provided that after June 1 all executions should take place within the walls of the penitentiary. The Williamsburg Yacht Club held their fifteenth annual regatta yesterday under most favorable auspices. A strong breeze from the southwest caused the small craft, with spinnakers ...

Lulu Sephas, a colored girl, 11 years old, was sent to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children from the Harlem Court yesterday, pending the decision of the Coroner as to the cause of the death of Sarah A. Shitoh, a colored child, 7 years old, who died at her parents' residence, No. 116 East One Hundred and Nineteenth-street, on Sunday.

When young William Taylor, who lives in Foster-avenue, Parkville, a little village between Brooklyn and Coney Island, went into a barn adjoining his father's house about 7 o'clock yesterday morning he saw his brother Samuel on his knees in front of a chair with his head hanging down on his breast.

CHICAGO, June 1.--The Rev. James McMullin, a graduate of the Catholic Propaganda College at Rome, was sent to the Washingtonian Home to-day in default of $25 fine. At the police court he trembled with delirium tremens. The spree was begun in New-York. He was en route from Rome to California to take charge of a large and wealthy parish in that State.

HUDSON, N. Y., June 1.--Dr. Samuel J. Reynolds, a physician of Valatie, has been arrested by order of Coroner Waldron upon a charge of having performed a criminal operation on Henrietta Ogden, a young woman of Stuyvesant, who died suddenly a few days ago.

Lieut.-Col. Albert P. Stewart was unanimously elected Colonel of the Eleventh Regiment last night to succeed the late Col. Frederick Unbekant. Brig.-Glen. Ward presided at the election, which was held in the regimental armor, in the Essex Market Building.
Early on the morning of May 20 Policeman McGowan, who was recently appointed on the force and assigned to duty in the Twentysecond Precinct, heard a woman screaming for ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 1.--The muchtalked, of game of baseball between the NewYork and Philadelphia League Clubs was played at Recreation Park to-day. This contest has excited great interest and for two hours before the grand stand was opened a large number of ...
The hackneyed saying that Paris is France is seldom so fully verified as when a French hero dies. All France seems to join the funeral procession.

According to tho Rev. D.T. Phillips, who read an essay before the Baptist Pastors yesterday morning, the effect of philosophy on religion was beneficial in the way that fire was when applied to separate the dross from the gold.
The report from Raleigh, N.C., that Internal Revenue Collector Isaac J. Young had been reappointed is denied here, and the stories about his bragging over securing the place are considered jests.

ERIE, Penn., June 1.--The fifth tragedy resulting from the Erie Savings Bank swindle occurred here to-day in the shooting of Teresa Maguire by her brother, one of the crazed depositors, who lost all his hard-earned savings. The girl is only 12 years old, and was a favorite sister. Her condition is critical.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 1.--Mayor Guillotte says that the five-thousand-dollar appropriation for the purpose of taking the Liberty Bell back to Philadelphia will be forthcoming. The trip will be made over the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, and the Mayor has written to various points along the route arranging for stops to be made.
ITHACA, June 1.--Cornell added another victory here this afternoon to her already brilliant baseball record, by defeating the Columbia College nine by a score or 10 to 4.

Louis Douglass, who was formerly chief veterinary surgeon to Maximilian I., of Mexico, and was well known as a trainer of horses, was found dead in bed at his home at Bowery Bay from heart disease yesterday morning, Douglass was nearly 70' years old.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 1.--The bill of complaint in the case of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway Company against Henry H. Porter was filed in the United States Circuit Court this forenoon.

HARTFORD, June 1.--Charles B. Thompson, one of the Bridgewater bogus trade operators who swindled many New-York merchants and others, pleaded guilty on two complaints last week and was remanded to jail.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 1.--Stephen Russell, Jr., manufacturer of jewelry, doing business under the name of Russell Co., made an assignment to Joseph A. Locke to-day. The amount of his liabilities is not known, but are thought to be about $4,000 or $5,000.

EASTON, Penn., June 1.--While the Lehigh Valley passenger train due here at 8:50 o'clock was running between Penn Haven and Mauch Chunk this morning at the usual rate of speed, the rear driving wheels of the engine mounted the rails and afterward feil on the road bed.
SHENANDOAH, Penn., June 1.--At noon to-day, while several gentlemen from Mahanoy City were crossing the Broad Mountain midway between Delana and Mahanoy City, they stumbled over a human body.

At the semi-monthly meeting of the Congregational Ministerial Union, at the Bible House, yesterday, a remarkably large increase of membership was reported for the month--three times the usual number for the same period. The feature of the meeting was a paper on the...

Semi-annual interest was due yesterday on the first mortgage bonds of the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad. At the office of the Union Trust Company, where the interest was payable, it was stated that there were no funds for that purpose. The default caused no special comment in Wall-street, it having been expected.

It is evident that without pool selling there can be no racing at Brighton Beach. The attendance there yesterday was very slim. There was no attempt at pool selling. There were five races, of which the following is a summary:

WAYNESBOROUGH, Penn., June 1.--Daniel Hollinger and his son John were awakened about 2 o'clock this morning by a noise in the vicinity of their chicken coop. Both men went out, the son approaching the chicken house with a revolver in his hand.

HUDSON, N.Y., June 1.--An unknown man, about 40 years old, apparently a French Canadian, was killed by a down train on the Hudson River Railroad this morning a short distance below this city. There was nothing on his person by which he could be identified.

DARIEN, Ga., June 1.--A remarkable scene was witnessed at the close of the trial of the Rev. Robert Mifflen, D.D., Pastor of the African Baptist Church, for alleged improper relations with some of his flock.

EAGLE PASS, Texas, June 1.--Information was received here to-day of a sharp battle between a squad of State rangers under Lieut. F.E. Seiker and a band of Mexican horse thieves yesterday afternoon 35 miles below on the Rio Grande River.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1.--The Mahone leaders in this State say they fully expect that the Republican Senate will refuse to confirm all of the appointments made by President Cleveland in this State to succeed Republican officials whose terms had not expired.

RICHMOND, Va., June 1.--In the trial of Thomas J. Cluverius, charged with the murder of Miss Fannie Lillian Madison, the prosecution and defense to-day each put two or three witnesses on the stand to prove some immaterial facts in rebuttal.

A gang of expert burglars entered the premises No. 80 Duane-street some time between 7 o'clock last Friday evening and 7 o'clock yesterday morning, and broke open and plundered three safes, securing, however, only $100 in money and $75 worth of jewelry for their trouble.

MONTREAL, June 1.--The annual meeting of the Bank of Montreal was held this afternoon, Mr. C.F. Smithers presiding. The General Manager, Mr. W.J. Buchanan, read his annual report of the business for the year ending April 30, 1885, which showed the balance ...

Business in the Cotton Exchange was neglected yesterday in consequence of the absorbing interest shown by a large proportion of the members in the annual election. There were three tickets in the field, but only two of them showed any strength.

MONTREAL, June 1.--Sergt. D. Angelis was to-day tried by court-martial at St. John's Military School on a charge of desertion. He was found guilty, sentenced to one year's imprisonment with hard labor, with ignominious dismissal from the service.

WASHINGTON, June 1.--A gentleman who had an engagement with Prof. Riley called at his house this morning and found the entomologist alone in his dining room reading the morning papers as he finished a late breakfast.
WASHINGTON, June 1.--The following is a recapitulation of the debt statement issued today, [new form:]

ALBANY, June 1.--The sensation created four years ago this month by the charge in the Assembly Chamber that Senator "Lo" Sessions had attempted to bribe Assemblyman Bradley to vote for Mr. Depew in the Senatorial contest ...

RISING SUN, Iowa, June 1.--The Rev. Dr. Pritchard, of New-YorK City, editor of the Church Organ, was to-day elected Financial Agent of the Reformed Presbyterian Church by the General Assembly. The report of the committee shows that the church has 10,600 members in America, and last year gave over $25,000 to the support of missions.

From early morning yesterday people gathered on the sidewalk at the corner of Hudson and North Moore streets, peering into Crawford's drug store and talking of the murder of which that was the scene during the dawning hours of Sunday.

James J. Lynch, 23 years old, who was joint proprietor with his mother of the saloon at West and Leroy streets, went to Martin's Hotel, No. 445 Hudson-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday and asked for a room.

Merivale's drama entitled "Our Joan' was acted at the Grand Opera House last evening. The play was reviewed in these columns when brought forth at Wallack's some weeks since, and may therefore be dismissed with brief comment.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 1.--The 12year-old son of Prof. Dubois, at Tallahassee, Fla., accidentally hanged himself yesterday while playing with a rope in his father's barn.
LAWRENCE, Kan., June 1.--Secretary Bayard will visit this city and deliver the annual address before the State University June 8.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., June 1.--Ex.-Gov. James E. English wrote a letter to-day to the City Park Commissioners saying briefly that they were at liberty to draw on him at their own convenience for $10,000 to establish a new driveway similar to the Farnham Drive, now the principal avenue of approach to the city's East Rock Park.

WILMINGTON, N.C., June 1.--Mrs. James W. Winn a widow, and three of her children, and Mrs. Tony Stefano, the wise of an Italian musician of this city, was drowned off Zeke's Island, about 25 miles below this city, to-day. The children were wading in the water, and, getting beyond their depth, Mrs. Winn and Mrs. Stefano went to their rescue, when all were drowned.

PARIS, June 1.--Although rain fell during the night and there was every indication in the early morning of more rain, hundreds of thousands of people were abroad at daybreak, crowding the streets and boulevards through which the great procession was to move that accompanied the body of Victor Hugo to his last resting place in the Pantheon.

The Committee on By-laws, Elections, and Qualifications of the Board of Education considered yesterday afternoon charges made against Moses L. Phillips, of the Board of School Trustees of the Eleventh Ward, by George B. ...
PITTSBURG, Penn., June 1.--The second general strike in the Western iron trade, by which 100,000, men are thrown out of employment, was entered upon to-day.

CEDAR KEYS, Fla., June 1.--Anna, wife of James Harris, a well-known colored man of this place, was shot and fatally wounded by a negro deperado named Stetson, alias Harrison, in the suburbs this afternoon.

HARRISBURG, Penn., June 1.--In the morning session of the General Synod of the Lutheran Church the report of the Board of Publication at Philadelphia was read and passed upon. The following donations were made:
The entries for to-day at Jerome Park promise good sport, and Miss Woodford will make her debut for the season. The following is a full list:

HARTFORD, June 1.--Prof. Hadley, the Chief of the new Labor Bureau, came here today by agreement to have a consultation with some of the leaders of the labor union organizations, but he was received in a manner which was distasteful and insulting.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1.--The town of Corydon was greatly excited over the appearance of 250 men in the street at midnight, Saturday, bringing letters for the County Commissioners and certain county officials.

Entirely apart from the question whether an underground rapid transit line is a desirable thing for this city, there are objections to the Arcade Railway bill now in the hands of the Governor which would certainly justify him in withholding his approval.

Nathaniel Sands's plea to be allowed to present his defense to the action in the Supreme Court in which the city recently took a judgment against him for $142,000, through his failure to appear, has been granted by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers.

Steps are being taken by a dozen or more substantial capitalists of this city to organize a new bank to succeed the wrecked Marine National Bank. The new institution is to have $300,000 capital, and it was quite generally understood in Wall-street yesterday that the Presidency of the new bank had been, or would be, offered to Vice-President Orson Adams, of the Bank of the Republic.

The Republican leaders are very properly studying the situation with reference to the platform on which the party shall enter the next campaign in this State, which for various reasons they regard as of unusual importance.

CHICAGO, June 1.--Judge Blodgett, in the United States District Court, to-day decided the mining case of Goodrich, of the Goodrich Steamboat Line, against a man named Alvord, who was once a wealthy wholesale grocer in the State of Iowa.

The Trustees of Columbia College held the last meeting of the current year yesterday. They decided to add a course of instruction in sanitary engineering to the School of Mines. The chair will be filled by Dr. Billings, United States Army, who will also deliver a course of lectures on hygiene.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1.--At to-day's meeting of the committee of citizens appointed to raise subscriptions for the relief of the sufferers at Plymouth a communication was also received from Chairman Davis, of the Plymouth local committee, which stated that a very favorable change had taken place in the epidemic.
The annual return of the taxes imposed on miscellaneous corporations was filed by the New-Jersey State Board of Assessors with Controller Anderson, at Trenton, yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 1.--Since his wounds have been dressed Reaume, the madman who took possession of a Wabash Railroad train yesterday, has become somewhat more communicative.

CHICAGO, June 1.--Postmaster S. Corning Judd this morning took formal possession of the Post Office, and receipted for it to Mr. Frank W. Palmer, his predecessor. His first act was to reappoint Mr. Collins S. Scuires as his First Assistant. Mr. Squires has been in the office for nearly 25 years, and has been the practical manager for over 12 years. His retention is therefore looked upon with much favor by the business community.
LONDON, June 2.--A portion of the official papers relating to the attack by the Russians on the Afghans on March 30 has been published.

WINNIPEG, June 1.--Gen. Middleton left for Fort Pitt, to which point Gen. Strange retreated early yesterday morning, taking with him a force of over 1,100 men, consisting of the Ninetieth Battalion, Winnipeg; Toronto Grenadiers, Midland, Ontario, Battalion; Kingston ...

PITTSBURG, June 1.--In a petition filed to-day, M.J. Dinsmore, a creditor of an estate of which Levi Bird Duff, the lawyer and politician is Assignee, charges the latter with failing to properly account for the funds collected by him.

Coroner O'Connell continued the inquest in Newtown, Long Island, last evening is the case of William Grimlick, of No. 143 Delanceystreet, this city, whose body was found floating in Flushing Bay on May 23. Grimlick had been missing from his home 20 days.

OMAHA, Neb., June 1.--Rutherford B. Hayes to-day sold to Henry Osthoff and Garlichs Johnson for $14,000 the saloon property at Sixteenth and California streets. Formal transfer will be made to-morrow. The price paid is much below the value of the property.
Mr. Charles Powell, Secretary of the Church of England Workingmen's Society, arrived in this city on the steamship Etruria yesterday.

CAIRO, June 1.--The emissaries of El Mahdi now daily enter Suakin. The sick soldiers in Suakin are increasing in number. The Indian troops suffer terribly.

CHICAGO, June 2.--Mayor Harrison today, through the Police Department, issued an order that all gambling houses not closed on and after the 5th inst. shall be raided by the police, their occupants arrested, and their apparatus destroyed.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--Capt. Henry Metcalf, Ordnance Department, has been appointed to act as inspector on certain camp and garrison equipage and recruiting property at the recruiting rendezvous, Albany, N.Y., reported as requiring the action of an inspector, ...
WASHINGTON, June 2, 1885. Joseph B. Fowler, one of the chiefs of di vision in the Third Auditor's office, recently dismissed by Secretary Manning, has been reinstated as a third class clerk.
The press dispatches from San Francisco did rather more than justice to Senator SHERMAN'S views in regard to silver coinage.
Before the production of "Nanon" at the Casino, Miss Lillian Russell will be tendered a benefit, and appear in "Billee Taylor," ...

An unostentatious, modest young man, who enjoys a glass of beer and a good cigar, and who may be seen loitering about the Park Hotel in Hoboken, has been the centre of attraction among the many German residents of Hoboken ...

BOWIE, Arizona, June 2.--The troops following the renegade Indians' trail with scouts from Apache, on the head waters of the Gila River, are reported as having captured the main portion of the band, including the squaws, and...
About 200 persons attended the annual meeting of the Actors' Fund Association, at the Union-Square Theatre, yesterday afternoon. Harry Miner presided.
A very fine display of fashionable and artistic furniture is being made by George C. Flint Co. at Nos. 104, 106, and 108 West Fourteenthstreet, near Sixth-avenue.
TRENTON, N.J., June 2.--The railroad companies protesting against the payment of the tax imposed upon them by the Board of State Assessors have thrown the matter into court.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 2.--The Fiftyninth annual meeting of the American Home Missionary Society opened to-night with a very full attendance. Many of the delegates arrived a day before the opening, drawn by the superb weather and the great attractions of the place.

WASHINGTON, June 2.--Holman, the objector and economist of the House and one of the self-constituted "watch dogs" of the Treasury, is being laughed at just now by some of the Democrats because he has started on what they are pleased to call "a junkering trip."

WASHINGTON, June 2.--The Southern Telegraph Company, controlling lines extending from Washington to the South, has separated from the Bankers and Merchants' Company, and entered into business arrangements with the Mutual Union Telegraph Company, with which it will exchange business at this point hereafter.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 2.--This morning R.L. Reynolds, ex-First Auditor of the Treasury Department in Washington, was killed at the Southern Hotel by a fall through the ventilating hatchway from the third floor to the marble floor of the rotunda, a distance of about 40 feet.

The metal market has been dull of late, and the dealers in iron, steel, and other metals have had abundance of opportunity to observe and discuss the experiments of metal manufacturers and the changes in processes.

BOSTON, June 2.--A fourth meeting of the creditors of James R. Osgood Co., the publishers, was held this morning and the following proposition was presented: It is proposed to form a firm under the name of Ticknor Co., to be composed of Benjamin H. Ticknor, Thomas B. Ticknor, and George F. Godfrey, ...

An unindorsed check for $5,000, drawn by the late Dr. J. Marion Sims on the People's Bank in favor of the United States Trust Company, was deposited with the latter corporation by Gilbert L. Crowell in the latter part of 1882. Crowell deposited it to his own account as Trustee for Dr. Sims, who was then in Europe.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 2.--The iron workers having temporarily suspended the manufacture of iron, devoted a large part of to-day to the manufacture of rumors that this firm and that firm had signed the scale.
LONDON, June 2.--The summer meeting at Epsom began to-day. The weather was grand, and the course, which is covered with herbage, is in excellent condition. The meeting promises to be a great success.
A case of "self-spacing type" was yes-- terday placed on exhibition at the convention of the International Typographical Union, and attracted the attention of nearly every printer present.
A gentleman who met ex-President Arthur at Fortress Monroe during his recent visit to that place says that he was apparently as unhappy a man during his entire visit as could have been found.

At 10 o'clock last night a dozen persons were playing cards and otherwise amusing themselves in a small room in the rear of Carl Heusler's dry goods store, on the first floor of No. 137 Ludlow-street. Carl had just come in with a pitcher of beer when a kerosene lamp exploded, and the oil, which ignited, was thrown ...
ST. LOUIS, June 2.-- The thirty-eighth annual meeting of the American Institute of Homeopathy began its sessions here to-day. 150 delegates being present.

LONDON, June 2.--A dispatch from Serinagur, India, says that city was visited by a frightful earthquake on Sunday last. The shocks, which occurred at intervals of 10 minutes, were of great violence. The greater part of the city was destroyed, and the cavalry barracks are a mass of ruins.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 2.--A special to the Journal from Evansville gives the particulars of an unusual tragedy in Dubois County, last night. Robert H. Reeves is a farmer living in Columbia Township, Dubois County.

The first day of the Spring trotting meeting of the New-York Driving Club, at Fleetwood Park, opened yesterday. The weather was all that could be desired, barring a stiff breeze that occasionally caught the horses on the lower turn and up the back stretch, keeping their time back many seconds.

UTICA, N.Y., June 2.--Dr. Gunn's charge that Senator Coggeshall had solicited a bribe from him has been an exciting topic of conversation here to-day. Mr. Coggeshall is at his home in Waterville, and his denial of the accusations and his explanation of his conference with Dr. Gunn were received here this evening.

NYACK, N. Y., June 2.--The Excise Board held another meeting to-day and granted 15 more licenses, several of them being applicants who were refused licenses a month ago. Among them were Lawrence McMahon, of Nyack, and James Sarvent, of Piermont, who were last year arrested through the Law and Order Society and tried for violation of the law.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 2.--Samuel Eby, the banker, of Elizabethtown, who failed last January, has been arrested on the charge of embezzling $6,000 belonging to the estate of Edward Sweeney, of which Eby was one of the Executors. The money was deposited in Eby's bank, and it is charged was used in the speculations which caused Eby's failure. Eby gave $2,000 bail for trial.

ROME, June 2.--The Sanitary Conference, which has been in session here for some time, in addition to providing for five days' quarantine at Suez of infected ships from the East, also adopted a resolution declaring that a ship without a doctor should undergo a Consul's inspection.

The President has removed Mr. Clarence Pullen, Surveyor-General of New-Mexico, appointed by Gen. Arthur about a year ago, and has appointed George W. Julian, of Indiana. Mr. Pullen is a civil engineer, a resident of New Mexico ...

The wide sward that flanks the railroad station at Garden City was the scene of rare activity yesterday. From early in the morning, when trains began to leave carloads of passengers there, until dark, when the last of them came away, the walks and stretches of grass on either side bustled with life and color.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 2.--About 3 o'clock this afternoon, while a freight train was crossing the bridge which spans the Erie Canal, a distance of nearly 150 feet, by some means one of the cars jumped the track in the middle of the bridge.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 2.--Engine No. 6, drawing the Boston berry train of the NewYork, Philadelphia and Norfolk Railroad, and engine No. 93, with peninsular freight train, came into collision with fatal results, in the cut south of Stannes Crossing, near Middletown, on the Delaware Railroad, at 5 o'clock this morning.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 2.--Emma Belmont, who was horribly beaten by Mrs. Hendricks on May 12, has so far recovered as to be able to return to Philadelphia to-morrow.

BOSTON, June 2.--Mr. Henry E. Dixey has begun new proceedings against C.F. Atkinson and Harry Mills, of Atkinson's Comedy Company, now playing "Peck's Bad Boy" at the Boston Theatre, to restrain the defendants from singing the song "It's English, You Know." Before Judge Allen, in the Supreme Court, today, counsel for plaintiff asked to have the case assigned to to-morrow for a hearing on the question of a preliminary injunction.

LOCKPORT, June 2.--In the intervals of some successful angling along the shores of Lake Ontario and the streams' discharging into it, your correspondent has learned some curious and interesting facts relating to the sturgeon of our great lakes as an article of food and commerce.

VIENNA, June 2.--Serious anti-Jewish riots have again broken out. They were renewed yesterday with increased violence. The inciting cause at the present time is the excitement of the people growing out of the election agitation. The Carmelite Platz was filled with a howling mob and free lights were frequent.

For several months the firm of J.W. Kohlsaat Co., Pine-street brokers, were engaged in manipulating a "pool" of the stock of the Underground Electric Cable Company, the price of which vibrated in the market between 10 and 180.
When the bankers and brokers quitted Wall-street yesterday afternoon, and business was considered over for the day, the employes of one bank found no rest, but went on toiling until near midnight.

NEW-LONDON, June 2.--Jasper Goodwin was here to-day, arranging for accommodations for the Columbia University and Freshman crew, which will arrive on Saturday to prepare for their race with Harvard over the Thames course. The Columbias will quarter at Gale's Ferry this year, next to the Yale quarters. The Harvard and Yale crews will arrive in a fortnight.
DENVER, Col., June 2.--At an early hour this morning the residents of the western portion of this city were startled by a loud explosion.

Lieut. M. Fisher Wright, of the United States war vessel Alliance, reported at the United States District Attorney's office yesterday his arrival with his prize, the brigantine Ambrose Light.

DAYTON, Ohio, June 2.--At a mass meeting of citizens of Dayton a committee was appointed to draft resolutions and attend to other necessary duties attending the presentation of an adjustable invalid reclining chair to Gen. Grant. The committee reported:

The names of J.L. Brisbane, A. Hull, and W.H. Diamond were bulletined on the floor of the Produce Exchange yesterday as having been dropped from the membership roll. It was explained that the three men had been expelled for non-payment of gratuity fund assessments.

LIVERPOOL, June 2.--A leading grain circular says: "The weather is fine and cool. Vegetation advances slowly. Grass lands are suffering from want of rain. Trade is uniformly dull. Business is limited.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 2.--The Supreme Lodge of United Workmen convened this morning and was called to order by Supreme Master Leroy Andrews, of New-York. At this point Mr. Fleming, Grand Foreman of Iowa, introduced the Mayor of Des Moines, who welcomed the Supreme Lodge to the city.

The case of B.F. Ashley against Edwin A. Weed for $20,000 damages for an assault committed upon him on March 16, 1881, occupied the entire day in the Court of Oyer and Terminer at White Plains yesterday. Mr. Ashley was the editor of the Port Chester Journal, and published an article from a correspondent which offended Mr. Weed.
Five hundred undertakers gathered in the large hall of the Grand Opera House yesterday to begin the first day's session of the convention of the Undertakers' State Association.

The New-York Steam Company, which is tearing up Broadway for the purpose of laying steam pipes, had reached Reade-street in its progress up town yesterday morning, and ground had been broken for the west track of the Broadway surface railroad as far south as Pearl-street.

PARIS, June 2.--On the Avenue des Champs Elysees, at the Rue de Boetie, stands the fine residence of the Baron Roger. Desiring to protect his grounds from the intrusion of the crowds who were gathering even at midnight to secure good places wherefrom to view the funeral procession of Victor Hugo, the Baron ...

The second of the series of games between the New-York and Philadelphia Clubs was played on the Polo Grounds yesterday. This was the first appearance of the Quaker City players here this season, and the event attracted nearly 5,000 spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2.--The Pennsylvania Railroad Company announced to-day that it will to-morrow reduce the rate of fare on the New-York and Chicago limited express train between those two cities from $30 to $25.

The directors of the National Rifle Association yesterday decided to have a contest at Creedmoor on the Fourth of July, for the benefit of all riflemen who care to pay 25 cents for permission to shoot at the 200-yard range.

BALTIMORE, June 2.--Townsend Cook, the negro who assaulted Mrs. Carrie V. Knott, of Carroll County, was taken from the jail at Westminster about 1 o'clock this morning by a body of masked men and hanged.
CINCINNATI, June 2.--The Latonia Club had fine weather and good attendance at the races to-day, but the track was slow. Following are the details of the various races run:

CINCINNATI, June 2.--A petition of H.J. Jewett for the removal of the case popularly known as Hafer against the Erie Railroad and others to the United States court was argued before the Superior Court Judges to-day.
Mrs. McCabe, an elderly woman, of No. 353 Greene-avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday charged with having brutally treated little Emma Silvernail, a ward.

WEST POINT, June 2--It adds a shade of disappointment to the rosy prospects for graduation week to know, almost beyond a doubt, that President Cleveland will not be able to attend the closing ceremonies.

The concert season, after lingering in the lap of Spring, appears likely to extend well into the Summer, and Chickering Hall was thrown open once more last evening to a concert, audience of the usual sort.

RICHMOND, Va., June 2.--The event of Richmond society this season was the marriage here this evening of Miss Julia Jackson, the only daughter of the late Gen. T.J. (Stonewall) Jackson, to Mr. William Christian, of this city.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 2.--A new mail route has been established between this city and Havana, by which that city is reached with papers and letters two days in advance of the regular steamer leaving New-York on Thursdays. This will prove a great convenience to the business and commercial world.

LONDON, June 2.--The literary world is of the opinion that the controversy is ended between Messrs. Frederic Harrison and Herbert Spencer about the publication in America of a volume containing a reprint of three recent articles by each gentleman.

The representation of Freemasons at the one hundred and fourth annual communication of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons, which opened at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the Masonic Temple, was a large and influential one.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 2.--Gen. Curtis and Controller Chapin appeared before the Governor to-day in relation to bills concerning the public printing. One bill provides that a commission, composed of the Secretary of State and Controller, shall advertise in two papers in Albany, New-York, Syracuse, and Buffalo ...
PARIS, June 2.--Gen. Roussel de Courcy has taken command in Tonquin in place of Gen. Briere de I'Isle.
The unveiling of the Pilgrim statue presented by the New-England Society to the city will take place at 3 P.M. on Saturday at Central Park.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 2.--It appears that Lou Johnson, the Chinaman who was murdered yesterday, was a detective in the employ of the city, and his death was the result of jealousy on the part of certain persons whom he had betrayed.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 2.--The United Presbyterian Assembly, in session yesterday afternoon, adopted the report of the committee on the Board of Foreign Missions. It appropriates to missions in Egypt $36,000; in India, $31,000, and $6,600 for other expenses of the board.

The detectives who are searching for the murderer of Robert H. Hands are convinced that they have a difficult task to perform. They admit, though not in so many words, that they have no case against Angemier. The latter is still in the Leonard-street station.
M. Steinheil, who died a few weeks ago in Paris, was a brother-in-law of Meissonier, and was widely known among French artists as the restorer of the stained glass windows in the Sainte-Chapelle.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., June 2.--It is reported that Prof. Thompson, Greek instructor in Phillips Academy, Andover, has been elected Principal of Williston Seminary, East Hampton.

HALIFAX, Nova, Scotia, June 2.--The message picked up in the bottle on the beach at Digby yesterday is no doubt a hoax, as no such vessel can be found in the American or Norwegian records. J.H. Mathers, Norwegian Consul here, knows of no vessel named Hossestein, or anything like it, being bound to this port from Cardiff, as stated.

TRENTON, N.J., June 2.--In the case of the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company against the American Rapid Telegraph Company. Judge Nixon, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, granted an order to-day appointing Edward Harland, of Norwich, Conn., as the Receiver of the latter company.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 2.--The Board of Visitors to the Naval Academy, consisting of Lieut.-Col. O.M. Poe, United States Army; Prof. William G. Greener, New-Haven, Conn.; John N.A. Griswold, New-York; William Reed, Baltimore; James S. Grinnell, Massachusetts, and A.M. Craig, Illinois, have arrived in this city on their annual tour of inspection.

MONTREAL, June 2.--Mr. Graham, Cashier of the National Bank of Scotland, and Mr. Brunton, chief clerk, arrived here to-day to give evidence against Hall and Fox, who will be tried during the present term of the Court of Queen's Bench for forging circular notes.

CHICAGO, June 2.--Shortly after 5 o'clock this afternoon a heavy storm of thunder, lightning, wind, and rain struck the city, lasting nearly an hour. No damage was done in the principal business portions, but reports for the outskirts and suburbs tell of numerous ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 2.--The recommendation made to the Legislature by Gov. Bate that when bonds are hereafter presented for funding the interest due on coupons attached from July 1, 1883, to July 1, 1885, be incorporated in the face of the new or settlement bond, instead of being paid, has not been well received in financial circles.
LIMA, June 2, via Galveston.--Further dispatches from the interior confirm the news of the victory obtained by the Government troops over those of Caceres at Huancayo.
The day at Jerome Park yesterday was one of surprises, only two of the favorites winning, while two outsiders handsomely rewarded their backers, leaving the knowing ones filled with disgust.

The catamarans Jessie and Iris again tried conclusions in the Bay yesterday, the race being the second of the series, best three in five, and the course from Bedloe's Island to buoy No. 8 , off Sandy Hook, and return. Mr. Fred Hughes sailed his own boat, the Jessie, which defeated the Iris on Monday, and Mr. Fearon held the stick on the Iris.
HARRISBURG, Penn., June 2.--The General Synod of the Lutheran Church to-day resolved to undertake a mission among the Jews in Chicago, to be under the supervision of the Board of Home Missions.

WINNIPEG, June 2.--As usual, at a critical period, the wires from the front have gone down and no word can be got through. It is certain that Gen. Middleton has by this time advanced on the enemy's position, and the general impression is that the fight is now in progress. Gen. Middleton, before the wires went down telegraphed the militia authorities here that he intended making an attack this afternoon.

Dr. Douglas said last evening that the swelling outside and inside Gen. Grant's throat had so far abated that the parts were now examined with greater ease than at any time since the General's serious illness. The patient this week has eaten solids, asparagus and steak, in very moderate quantity.

A little company of singers met at People's Hall, No. 97 Varick-street, last evening and practiced sacred hymns under the leadership of the Rev. E.C. Goss. Next Sunday, or Sunday after next, the hymns are to be reproduced in one of the public parks, probably the Battery.
ALBANY, June 3.--Gov. Hill has had a comparatively quiet day. There were no important hearings on the calendar, but during the remaining days of the week he will be very busy.
CHICAGO, June 3.--There is every prospect that after to-morrow public gambling houses will be a thing of the past in Chicago-- for a time at least.

The hearing in the Winans divorce case was to have bean continued before Referee Stephen P. Nash yesterday, but after the adjournment of last week Mr. Nash received a call which made it imperative that he should go to Europe, and he sailed last Saturday.

ST. LOUIS, June 3.--Edward Hanlan, the oarsman, arrived here from San Francisco today. He is now stopping at the Southern Hotel in this city, and will remain here several days. A small table in his room was covered with gold medals, diamond rings, pins, and brooches, and a number of brilliant colored, handsomely embroidered silk morning caps.
CINCINNATI, June 3.--The Latonia races were well attended this afternoon. The track was fair and the weather fine.

LONDON, June 3.--The greatest event on the English sporting calendar, the race for the Derby Stakes, was run to-day at Epsom Downs. The weather was brilliant, a pleasant breeze tempering the heat of the sun's rays.

An old Democratic war horse, Mr. Daniel A. Ogden, of Penn Yan, N.Y., has been appointed a chief of division in the Third Auditor's office, Treasury Department. The position only pays $2,000, and some of the New-York Democrats express surprise that so venerable a worker should have got nothing better.
WASHINGTON, June 3.--Secretary Whitney has returned from New-York, and was at the Navy Department to-day:

ZANZIBAR, June 3.--Owing to a treaty of alliance concluded by Germany with Simba, the rebel chief of Lamo, the German representative here has called upon the Sultan to suspend hostilities against Simba. The Sultan, complying with the request of the chiefs of the Chagga and Kilimanjaro districts, has accepted suzerainty over their country.

HAVANA, May 30.--It is officially announced that complete tranquillity reigns in the Province of Santiago de Cuba. The forces sent in pursuit of Limbano Sanchez meet with much difficulty on account of the rising of the rivers. The principal passes have been occupied by the troops.

Dr. Rafael Zaldivar, President of the Republic of Salvador, arrived in this city yesterday from Panama on the steamer Acapulco. In his company were Carlos Salozar, a companion, and Col. R. Cobos, his Adjutant. They were driven to the Hotel Dam, and paid Bernard Biglin $7 to cart up their baggage.

OTTAWA, June 3.--Another lot of carriages, valued at $5,000, imported from the United States has been seized, it having been discovered by the Board of Appraisers that the axles used in their construction are the product of prison labor. The consignment came from Cincinnati, while the axles were manufactured at the Auburn Prison, New-York State.

WEST POINT, June 3.--The military display of the day, and so far the most imposing event in the closing ceremonies of the academical year, was the grand review of the cadet corps, this evening, in honor of the Board of Visitors.
The mosquitoes at Whitestone, Long Island, are fat and ferocious. During the Summer they depend for existence upon the stranger who enters their domain, and they make it very warm for him.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 3.--The remains of the Hon. A.H. Stephens, which were deposited in the Catting vault in this city, will be removed to Liberty Hall, in Taliaferro County, on the 10th inst. The oration will be delivered by Gen. Toombs.
LONDON, June 3.--The official report of the earthquake in the Vale of Cashmere shows that it was not as disastrous in its results as the earlier reports made it appear.

PARIS, June 3.--M. Goblet, M inister of Public Instruction, has published a reply to the protest of Cardinal Guibert against the "desecration" of the Pantheon by its preparation for the reception of the body of Victor Hugo.

Lawyer Andrews on Tuesday afternoon asked the Kings County Supreme Court for a warrant for the arrest of Edith Evelyn Hoyle, a 3-year-old child, who, it was alleged, had been abducted from her home in Auburn, N.Y., by a woman who was then staying at No. 17 Patchenavenue.
ALBANY, June 3.--Work was resumed on the Capitol this morning. Commissioner Perry put 550 men at work to-day, and expects to add 100 men on Saturday.

SHOHOLA, Penn., June 3.--A novel combat was witnessed by two Erie Railway employes on Sunday, on Big Walker Pond, a few miles back of this station. The men were fishing in the pond, and were in a boat near the west shore, when they saw a commotion in the water a few rods away.
Two theories were held yesterday by those interested in the capture of Richard S. Scott, the missing Paying Teller of the Bank of the Manhattan Company. Both were worked industriously.

CHICAGO, June 3.--The time during which the holders of the common stock of the Consumers' Gas Company had the precedence over outsiders in the matter of subscribing for the proposed preferred stock has expired, and there are 60 days yet in which the books remain open for subscriptions by the public in general.

BUFFALO, June 3.--There is general approval here, where the appointee is best known, of Attorney General O'Brien's choice of the Hon. Charles F. Tabor for his first deputy, to succeed Judge Maynard.

WASHINGTON, June 3, 1885. The President to-day appointed John H. Far ley to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Eighteenth District of Ohio, and Thomas C. Bronston to be Collector of Internal Revenue for the Eighth District of Kentucky.

The Grand Jury, after examining Nathan D. Daboll, Assistant Cashier of the defunct Marine Bank; Irving Fish, John D. Fish, and other witnesses, found an indictment on Tuesday afternoon against Ferdinand Ward for grand larceny in the first degree.

The steamship Weser, of the North German Lloyd Line, from Bremen, which arrived at Quarantine late Tuesday evening, was detained there all day yesterday because three cases of smallpox were found on board.

A report of an examination by the Commissioners of Accounts of the accounts and methods of the Bureau of Licenses for the period from May 1, 1882, to Dec. 31, 1884, has been sent to the Mayor. During that period 68,863 licenses were granted and accounted for, and 20 granted and not accounted for.

CHICAGO, June 3.--Some time ago A.M. Billings, President of the People's Gaslight Company and of the Home National Bank, listened to the representations of William Whalen and agreed to furnish the capital to develop six mines in Nevada, which Whalen claimed to own.
TRENTON, N.J., June 3.--The bodies of two men were found on the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad near Lawrence station at 2 o'clock this morning.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 3.--Dr. E.E. Loy, who killed Harry Champlin, his brother-inlaw, was to-day discharged in the Police Court, the Judge saying that the testimony made out clearly a case of self-defense. A shout of applause greeted the decision, and the doctor and his wife were deeply affected.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 3.--The following is the Court of Appeals day calendar for Thursday: Nos. 227, 220, 232, 233, 221, 234, 85, 197.

EASTON, Penn., June 3.--One of the Bethlehem Iron Company's furnaces, which has been idle several months, was filled yesterday and the match applied this morning. The stack will be ready for blast on Saturday. The gravel train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad between here and Mauch Chunk, which was suspended several months since, is again on duty. A full force of men was put to work this morning.

The bill "to improve the condition and operations" of the sinking fund of this city, which is in the hands of the Governor, was intended to wind up the fund entirely on the discharge of the obligations which are now made by law a charge upon it.
The new steamship El Callao, the first vessel which has been built specially for the new steam line to Venezuela, arrived here from England by way of Bermuda yesterday.
The convention of printers and pressmen yesterday discussed several proposed reforms to be introduced into the composing rooms of the Union.
LONDON, June 3.--The application of the Times for an injunction to prevent the publication of the Morning Mail has been refused by the court.

LONDON, June 3.--A Sinjou dispatch says a meeting of the British-Russian Afghan Boundary Commission is expected to take place soon, when will be begun the consideration of the question of the delimitation of the Afghan boundary.

COLUMBIA, Mo., June 3.--The Hon. Stephen B. Elkins delivered an elaborate ad dress this evening before the Alumni Society of the State University here, his subject being "The Industrial Question in the United States."

Surrogate Rollins has rendered a decision in the case of the contested will of Mrs. Augusta Gillender by which the daughter of the testator was disinherited, the property, valued at $80,000, going to her son-in-law, the Marquis of San Marzano. The Surrogate denies the probate of the duplicate will offered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 3.--The Voters' Union met in convention here to-day, about 150 delegates from all sections of the State being present.

Moulton W. Gorham, a dealer in heating and ventilating apparatus, is alleged to have fled to Canada for the purpose of evading his creditors. On that allegation James Stanley, one of his creditors, has procured from the Supreme Court an attachment against the property left by Gorham in his store, No. 24 Cliff-street, and elsewhere.

The steamship Acapulco, of the Pacific Mail Line, which arrived yesterday from Aspinwall, brought 145 men of the First United States Marine Battalion, who were sent to the isthmus to protect American interests soon after the breaking out of the recent troubles there.

CHICAGO, June 3.--Postmaster Judd today received a committee of a Democratic veteran soldiers' organization asking that their members be considered in making appointments in the Post Office.

PHILADELPHIA, June 3.--A woman rushed out of P. Coffiero's barber's shop, at No. 2,318 Market-street, about 9 o'clock this evening, and shouted to Officer Sankey, who stood on the corner, "Arrest that man! he has murdered my husband."

As many people as the Brooklyn Academy of Music could hold attended the twentysixth annual Commencement of the Long Island College Hospital last evening. The stage was crowded with Regents of the college, well-known ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 3.--A sad shooting accident occurred at Kingston this afternoon. Mrs. John Remmel was returning from a friend's funeral when she stopped in front of T.H.B. Lewis's residence to chat with Mrs. Lewis.
CHICAGO, June 3.--About 30 of the Chicago underwriters met yesterday and formed the Chicago Fire Underwriters' Association.

Mrs. Susan R. Buck, who has figured under a dozen different names and whose exploits were told in THE TIMES on Monday, was arrested yesterday by detectives. The woman had been living at Norwalk, Conn., but after the publication of her career in the papers she left there and went to Brooklyn.

ALBANY, June 3.--When in New-York on Memorial Day Gov. Hill extended an invitation to President Cleveland to visit the State camp at Peekskill this Summer while the National Guard were on duty. The Governor said this afternoon that the President had intimated that he would probably accept, and spend perhaps two or three days there.

HAVANA, May 30.--El Comercio de Sagua of the 23d inst. announced the arrest of Manuel Martinez, Mayor of Rancho Veloz, who is charged with being chief of a band of kidnapers. Martinez has been lodged in jail at Sagua.

A statement was made some time ago by a New-York paper that not half of the national banks would renew their charters when they expired. Three New-York City national banks have this month made application for renewals, and the Controller of the Currency is led to believe that few or none of the city banks holding charters will fail to renew them at the proper time.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 3.--The fine opening of the American Home Missionary Society Tuesday evening has been followed by a day of great interest. Saratoga air and water together have supplied the physical tonic, and the exercises at the church have been mentally invigorating.
MONTREAL, June 3.--The prisoners Hall and Fox were to-day committed to the Queens Bench on a charge of issuing forged circular notes on the National Bank of Scotland.
CHICAGO, June 3.--A large two-story frame house at the corner of Archer-avenue and State-street was vacated yesterday morning by its tenant, a hardware dealer.

The Hon. James Oliver, member of Assembly from Paradise Park, dined at Delmonico's Tuesday evening with another member of the State Legislature. LANCASTER, Penn., June 3.--Joseph Herzog, the farmer who victimized banks and prominent citizens here to the extent of about $100,000, had promised to plead guilty to numerous indictments against him, but when Sheriff Tomlinson went to the County Prison for him this morning to take him into court be fainted in his cell and became so ill that he could not be removed. The cases were continued until he recovers.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 3.--A child of Daniel Schupp, of Marion Township, 4 years old, administered a dose of liniment to a baby 1 year old yesterday, and the little one died in a few hours despite the efforts of the physicians.

Skipper Fearon, who handled the stick aboard the catamaran Iris in her races with the Jessie, was very well pleased with himself and the boat last evening. When he rounded the judges' boat at Bedloe's Island he was the winner of the third race in the series, having sailed to Sandy Hook and back in 7 minutes and 52 seconds less time than that made by Skipper Hughes on the Jessie.

WARSAW, N.Y., June 3.--Miss F. Belle Doolittle, daughter of the late Eli Doolittle, of Wethersfield Springs, has become suddenly insane. She is a handsome girl, of charming address, a close student, not yet out of her teens. As a pupil at Warsaw Union School she applied herself closely, and stood at the head of her class. Insanity is hereditary on both sides of the family.

The robbery of the Bank of the Manhattan Company differs in several respects from the common run of bank robberies. There is in the circumstances no impeachment of the sagacity and faithfulness of the Directors before the robbery nor of their good faith afterward.

At a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday the report of the Teachers' Committee on Education recommending the removal of Miss Rachel Gorlitz, assistant in the primary department of School No. 25, was presented.

READING, Penn., June 3.--City residents on North Sixth-street beyond the Reading Railroad car shops, are in a great state of excitement. There is a row of substantial brick dwellings on the west side, just where the high ground of the city begins.

Yesterday's session of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York, in the Grand Lodge hall, Masonic Temple, opened with prayer by one of the Grand Chaplains, the Rev. John G. Webster, of Greenbush, N.Y.

Two men appear to have been surprised by the appointment of George W. Julian to be Surveyor-General of New-Mexico. One man is Mr. Julian, who is already reported to be unwilling to accept the office.

John Marshall, the father of Jesse Marshall, of Rossville, Staten Island, an account of whose arrest for an attempted assault upon Myra Marshall was given in yesterday's TIMES, said yesterday that the published statements of the case were incorrect in almost every particular.
The Metropolitans appeared on the Polo Grounds yesterday for the first time in their new uniforms, and they celebrated the event by defeating the Louisville players after a rather interesting game.

CHICAGO, June 3.--Confessions of judgment have been entered against the Kappes Furniture Manufacturing Company, at No. 89 Albert-street, in the southwestern part of the city, in the amount of $13,277, in favor of numerous Chicago creditors, and the Sheriff took possession of the establishment and closed it.

UTICA, June 3.--When asked to-day what further action, if any, he intends to take in regard to Dr. Gunn's charges Senator Coggeshall said: "I have no present intention of going to New-York to demand a retraction, or to bring a libel suit against the doctor." The Senator regards his explicit denial as sufficient.
AMSTERDAM, N.Y., June 3.--Garret B. Vandeveer, a well-known farmer, died last week leaving a large estate.
