Henry E. Dixey visited the Stock Exchange yesterday noon, and was accorded the unusual privilege of an informal reception in the board room. He was introduced by Broker Richard H. Halsted to Chairman Mitchell and several members of the Exchange.
Well-known faces in the theatrical profession were seen yesterday at the funeral of George F. Browne, the popular chop house keeper and former actor, at the Church of the Tansfiguration.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 3.--In August, 1882, while proceeding from his store to his residence, M.T. Bennett, a prominent merchant of Lebanon, was murdered and robbed by unknown persons. His body was discovered next morning, the head being frightfully crushed with a stone or some other hard weapon.

While the bakers employed in Grau's bakery on Kearney-avenue, Jersey City, were at work on Tuesday morning, some one stole from their clothing, which was hanging in one of the side rooms, a gold watch and $40 in money.
The Chamber of Commerce received yesterday an oil painting of the late Matthew Maury, presented by the family of the dead merchant.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 3.--A dispatch was received here to-day from Pinkerton's New York agency giving a description of Scott, the fugitive Teller of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, with the warning: " Look out for him: he is heading your way." A detective boarded the Air Line train as it come in to-night.
OTTAWA, Ontario, June 3.--There is considerable speculation with regard to the Cabinet changes that take place at the close of the present ession.
CHICAGO, June 3.--A large number of affidavits have been filed before Judge Tully in the bucket-shop cases.

PETERSBURG, Va., June 3.--In consequence of the extreme illness of the wife of Thomas H. Harvie, of Brooklyn, N.Y., who is charged with having committed forgery in Manchester, this State, and who is in jail here, efforts have been made to have the charge withdrawn.
Between the blue covers of the "American Yacht List" for 1885, which has just been issued, may be found a great variety of information of especial interest and value to yachtsmen.

LEXINGTON, Ga., June 3.--Judge Gilham Ordinary of this county, to-day issued a marriage license which authorized his mother, Mrs. William Gilham, to become the wife of Mr. Lindsay Jacks to-morrow. This is believed to be the first instance on record where a son was called upon to do such a service for his mother.

LONDON, June 3.--Letters from Saigon, the capital of French Cochin China, state that the Cambodian revolutionists against French authority have, with the King's secret support, attacked Panomping, or Nam Wang, the capital of Cambodia, and driven the European residents from the city. The refugees were sheltered on board a French ship, which lay in the Me Kong River.

Builder John J. Kierst, who erected the new Standard Theatre, wrote to President Purroy, of the Fire Department, making a very serious charge against Examiner John M. Thornton, of the Bureau for the Inspection of Buildings.

While men, women, and children were tearing away for firewood parts of a dilapidated structure that stood on a lot running from Broadway to Greenwich-street, at the foot of Broadway, the wreck suddenly fell, injuring several of them, some fatally.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 3.--Joseph Tausch, 19 years old, was fatally injured to-day by the caving in of a well. He was engaged in taking bricks out of an old well, and had started up the ladder with a load when the walls gave way, burying him out of sight.
The Bricklayers' International Union, the Stonecutters' Union, and the Framers' Union yesterday sent to the Aqueduct Commissioners ...

TOPEKA, Kan., June 3.--The Synod of the United Presbyterian Church adjourned to-day after adopting a resolution providing that, "We think it wise and proper to counsel the members of the United Presbyterian Church to stand aloof from this (the Grand Army of the Republic) and similar organizations"--where an oath and an obligation are taken.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 3.--The naval cadets gave the Board of Visitors this morning exhibitions of their skill in seamanship and gunnery on the United States steamer Wyoming. Commander C.L. Huntington had charge of the guns and Commander H. Elmer of the seamanship drill. The target was placed at 800 yards and the firing was excellent. The final examination of the classes of naval cadets of 1883 begins to-day.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 3.--The Supreme Lodge of United Workmen to-day amended its constitution by providing that the beneficiary shall be named in the beneficiary certificate.

PARIS, June 3.--It is stated that Lord Lyons, British Ambassador to France, has conferred with M. de Freycinet, Foreign Minister, in reference to the conduct of the foreign press, which is mainly French, in Egypt. England, it is reported, has made concessions which will probably lead to an agreement between the two nations on the subject.
There were three events on the card of the New-York Driving Club yesterday, instead of two, as everybody was led to believe.
CHICAGO, June 3.--The creditors of the Durham House Drainage Company have as yet taken no new steps in the direction of an adjustment of the affairs of that badly crippled concern.
CHICAGO, Ill., June 3.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad Company was held here to-dhy, when 367,000 votes were cast out of a total of 419,600.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 3.--Last February Mary Gibbons, the daughter of respectable parents living in Pittston, married a young man named Hart.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 3.--Yesterday, in the Twenty-sixth Judicial District, comprising the Parishes of Jefferson, St. Charles, and St. John the Baptist, was held an election for District Judge in place of the Hon. Michael Hahn, who resigned his place on the bench upon his election to Congress last November.

Our contemporary the Tribune is a good deal troubled about the Garden City Cathedral. It complains that the cathedral is situated in a village, instead of being placed within a few minutes of the law courts, the beer shops, and the theatres.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 3.--In March, 1883, Walter Fuches, a prominent farmer of the town of Mamakating, this county, took a check for $64.05 to W.O. Coggswell's store, in Wurtsborough, and requested Coggswell to cash it. Coggswell did not have sufficient money by him at the time, but gave Fuches $40, with the understanding that he could have the balance when he came in again.

Four shares of the stock of the Eighth Avenue Railroad Company were sold at auction by Adrian H. Muller Son, in the Real Estate Exchange, yesterday. The par value of the shares is $100 each. They brought $256 each. Eighty-six shares of stock of the Broadway Railroad Company of Brooklyn (par value $100 each) were sold for $235.50 each. Other sales by the Messrs. Muller yesterday were as follows:
MONTREAL, June 3.--There were three deaths to-day from smallpox in St. Jean Baptiste village and two new cases reported.

TORONTO, June 3.--A large meeting of business men was held here to-day to protest against the injustice of the exemption act passed at the last session of the Manitoba Legislature, which exempts merchants in that Province to the extent of $2,500 on real property, ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 3.--The Banner publishes full reports as to the growing crops in 51 counties of the State. The acreage of wheat compared with that of last year is 72 per cent. and the present condition 35.

Speaking of the recent appointment of a Receiver for the Scioto Valley Railroad, C.P. Huntington said yesterday that the application for a Receiver was made after consultation with the largest creditors and bondholders, and the object of the step was to protect all of the security holders and creditors of the road. Mr. Huntington expressed confidence in Receiver Robinson's ability.
LONDON, June 3.--A dispatch received here this afternoon from Durham says that a fire broke out in the Philadelphia Colliery, situated near that city, at noon to-day.

Hook and Ladder Company No. 12 left their quarters at No. 243 West Twentieth-street at 9:48 o'clock last night, in response to an alarm of fire sent out from the signal box at Eleventh-avenue and Thirty-third-street.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 3.--The strike on the Kentucky Central Railroad assumed an appearance of violence this morning.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 4,--An unknown man was found unconscious in Dockstreet this morning. His arm and one rib were broken and he had received internal injuries from kicking or clubbing. He remained unconscious all day. To-night it is thought he is dying.

The coolest, most self-possessed man in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday was Ferdinand Ward. His thin, sharp-featured, pallid face was almost expressionless from the time no entered the room until he left it.

Dr. Clemence S. Lozier, Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake, Oliver Johnson, Albert O. Willcox, Justus O. Wood, Mrs. Lewis, and 40 or 50 other ladies and gentlemen gathered at No. 103 West Forty-eighth-street last evening and held the annual meeting of the New-York City Woman's Suffrage Society.

Mr. J.B. Runkle, merchant at Mount Airy, Carroll County, has a number of beehives in the rear of his house. The bees have been quite lively for the past few days, and the odor of locust blossoms has had the effect of drawing out the families from every hive.

SARATOGA, N.Y., June 4.--The last day of the convention of the American Home Missionary Society opened with clear skies and unabated enthusiasm. The first hour of the morning was given to the church building department.

Messrs. D. The New-York Academy of Medicine listened last evening, at its hall, No. 12 West Thirty-first-street, to a paper, by Dr. Richard H. Derby, that attracted much interest from the physicians present, on "Contagious Ophthalmia in some of the Orphan Asylums and Residential Schools in New-York City."

PARIS, May 15.--The excessive cold weather of the present so-called blooming month of May has made society some what indifferent to the tailors' strike. Fashionables have been obliged to take out their furs, and they lose sight of the momentous danger to riding habits and tailor suits.

DETROIT, June 4.--The Hon. George V. N. Lothrop, the newly appointed Minister to Russia, is getting ready to leave for St. Petersburg, and now expects to sail on or about the 17th.

PITTSBURG, Penn., June 4.--It is reported that the sheet mill men of the Amalgamated Association, in secret session here, are considering the advisability of accepting the 10 per cent. reduction proposed by the manufacturers. Nothing definite can be learned in regard to the meeting as the Amalgamated officers refuse to affirm or deny the report.

The type setting contest at the Star office yesterday afternoon between Joseph McCann, of the Herald, and Ira Somers, of the World, attracted a crowd of expert printers.

The clouds were lowering over Jerome Park yesterday and light rain fell at intervals during the afternoon, but not enough to injure the track or make it uncomfortable for the spectators, who numbered several thousand.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Des Moines and Fort Dodge Railroad was held at No. 61 Wall-street yesterday. H.H. Hollister, R.G. Agnew, and David Stewart were elected Directors for three years. Mr. Hollister succeeds John L. Ludlum.

The Central Park, North and East River Railroad Company, (the Belt Line,) becoming fearful that the Broadway Surface Road would invade its tracks in Whitehall and State streets and Battery-place, brought a suit to prevent this.

Of the three appeals to the people which have just been made in the form of public speeches by three conspicuous members of the House of Commons that of Lord RANDOLPH CHURCHILL may be safely let go without serious consideration.
DUBLIN, June 4.--Charles Henry James is the name of the official who absconded from here about June 1. James had been for 30 years in official Assignee in bankruptcy.
The lacrosse team of the University of the City of New-York won a well-contested game from the Stevens Institute Club on the St. George's Cricket Grounds, in Hoboken, yesterday afternoon.
The St. Nicholas Society met last night at Delmonico's, and Presicent Cornelius Vanderbilt occupied the chair.
The treaty with Great Britain regulating the rights of our citizens in the fisheries on the coasts of the Dominion of Canada expires by limitation on the 1st of next month.
The Rev. Dr. Barten, of Norfolk, Va., is at the Windsor Hotel. Oliver Garrison, of St. Louis, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

Howard, late Collector of Customs of Portsmouth, resigning his office on the ground that he is a radical Republican, and cannot consent to hold office under a Democratic Administration.

The prize brigantine Ambrose Light was formally seized by United States Deputy Marshal Curtis yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard upon an order by United States District Judge Brown, a libel having been filed by the District Attorney against the vessel.

Thomas Devine was one of the striking carpet weavers of the Smith factory at Yonkers. He was arrested by one of the policemen of that city charged with disorderly conduct in walking up and down on Nepperhan-avenue in front of the drum shop.

The convention of the International Typographical Union yesterday decided that it was impracticable to select a permanent location for annual sessions. The Corresponding Secretary had asked the subordinate unions to express an opinion in the matter, and had received 43 replies in favor of a permanent headquarters and 42 against it.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4.--The Board of Visitors to the Noyal Academy continued its labors to-day. This morning the annual competitive drill of the four companies of naval cadets took place.

The printers enjoyed a sociable banquet in Irving Hall last night. Four long tables accommodated the banqueters, and for more than two hours the incessaut clatter of dishes and rattling of table cutlery demonstrated that printers could eat as well as set type.
The question of closing places of business in this city at 1 P.M. on Saturdays during the Summer months was discussed with much earnestness at a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday.

EL PASO, Texas, June 4.--The latest news received here concerning the raiding by the Apaches comes from the neighborhood of Hillsborough, New-Mexico. Fifteen armed men under the leadership of one Jackson left Hillsborough Tuesday morning and before noon had recovered 28 horses.

Two small boys put out into the Sound in a little skiff from Barreto's Point last evening, just at the foot of the hill on which stands the old tumble-down mansion after whose proprietor the diminutive peninsula is named.

George W. Cass, the holder of 13 of the convertible bonds of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, has begun suit in the Supreme Court against that corporation to recover judgment for the semi-annual interest due on the bonds on May 1 last.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., June 4.--John Fagan, of Glenville, has a pretty daughter 18 years old. Tuesday afternoon a strange man called at Fagan's house, and said he was a farmer in Rotterdam, and wanted to hire a girl.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 4.--A meeting of the Halifax Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon, when the protection of the fisheries and a reciprocity treaty were discussed.

Sir John Lister Kaye, of Yorkshire, England, a Young gentleman of wealth and cosmopolitan inclinations, is visiting the city. Sir John left England about eight months ago and has been traveling through the Southern and Eastern States, Cuba, and Canada.

Ex-Gov. Seymour reached his seventyfifth birthday anniversary Sunday. Although his health has not been the best during the Winter, he was able to be in town yesterday. That many more years may be added to his peaceful life is the sincere wish of his many friends. Mr. and Mrs. Seymour celebrated their golden wedding anniversary the same day. The Hon. Roscoe Conkling presided at the dinner.

NORFOLK, Va., June 4.--The steamer Luray this morning landed at this port nine seamen brought from St. Jugo, one of the Cape Verde Islands.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 4.--A number of Brooklyn people occupied the Executive Chamber to-day, including Mayor Low, Senators Kiernan, Cullen, and Daggett, Assemblymen Heath, McCann, Coffey, Myers, Earl, Lindsay, Nagle, and Connelly.

SEDALIA, Mo., June 4.--Officer George Fifer learned last night that safe blowers were at work in the building of Barley Brothers, bankers, on Main-street. He called to his assistance Policeman McGee and Frank Gassage, a hack driver, and started at once for the premises named.

The North German Lloyd steamship Weser and the Carr Line steamer Polynesia, both of which were detained by Health Officer Smith Wednesday because there was smallpox on board, remained at anchor off Quarantine all day yesterday.

Coroner Bernard F. Martin last week determined that the statue of Liberty presented by his countrymen to the people of the United States should not go without a pedestal if he could assist in obtaining one.

LONDON, June 4.--Americans here express themselves well pleased with the warmth of the reception accorded Minister Phelps at the banquet given last evening by the Lord Mayor to the Judges.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 4.--The Senate this morning passed the House Civil Rights bill, which gives colored people the same rights as whites in hotels, restaurants, theatres, and other public places.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--Leave of absence for three months, to take effect about July 1, has been granted Capt. Richard Comba, Seventh Infantry. Leave of absence until Sept. 1, to take effect when his services can be spared, has been granted Major John S. Poland, Eighteenth Infantry.
The wind was not favorable for yachting contests yesterday. The catamarans Jessie and Iris undertook to sail the fourth race of their series, and started away from Bedloe's Island at 12:52 o'clock.

ALEXANDRIA, June 4.--The Guards, who arrived here some time ago from Suakin, have received orders from England to remain at this place for the present.
LANCASTER, Penn., June 4.--Joseph Herzog, the forger, having recovered from his illness of yesterday, was brought into court this morning and pleaded guilty to seven indictments for forgery.
The first match this season between the Newark and Manhattan Cricket Clubs was played yesterday at Prospect Park.
An effort will be made to secure a statue of ex-President Pierce, to be placed in the Capitol Park, in Concord, N.H., as a companion to that of Daniel Webster.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4.--The Governors of the Newport Casino declined to re-engage the orchestra led by Prof. Landers, of New-York, for this season, and last autumn made terms with the New-Hampshire Naval Band to furnish music for the present Summer.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 4.--The Republican State Committee decided last night, after a long discussion, in favor of a two day's convention, the object being to enable the Committee on Renomination ample time to compromise the widely different views held in the party regarding the liquor law.

The members of the Naval Board of Inspection arrived from Washington yesterday morning, and, accompanied by Commodore Chandler, the commandant at the Navy Yard, visited the United States man-of-war Omaha, lying off West Twenty-sixth-street.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 4.--Piedmont Church, in this city, the largest and one of the wealthiest Congregational churches in Central Massachusetts, is anxiously awaiting the decision of the arbitration committee in the case of Deacon Rufus N. Meriam.

Yesterday the Rev. Jacob Hood and his wife, of Lynnfield, observed the sixty-fifth anniversary of their marriage. Mr. Hood is 93 years old and his wife is 88.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 4.--Intelligence from Northwest Arkansas has been received to the effect that locusts and grasshoppers have suddenly appeared in different localities to an alarming extent.

CHICAGO, June 4.--The annual meeting of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company was held this afternoon, when the following were elected Directors for three years: A.G. Dulman, C.M. Depew, Albert Keep, D.S. Kimball, S.F. Barger, and M.L. Sykes.

Capt. W.W. Lawrence, one of the oldtime sea Captains, died yesterday of heart disease and pneumonia at No. 334 Jay-street, Brooklyn. He was born in Mott-street, in this city, in 1813, and at the age of 13 years he went to sea.

The Sheriff of Bergan County has completed all the arrangements for the hanging today of Sanford Sisco, the colored murderer of Abram Gurnee, the Paskack storekeeper, whom he killed last Fall.

WEST POINT, June 4.--The light battery drill this evening was an effective display of motion and noise. The exhibition is one of the few among those usually arranged for the graduating ceremonies that affords the participants equal enjoyment with the spectators.

A handful of persons attended the meeting last evening of the Committee of Arrangements of the Sociologic Society of America in the Church of St. John the Evangelist, West Eleventh-street and Waverley-place. Mrs.I.C. Fales presided.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4.--A plan of settlement with the holders of Tennessee bonds who may hereafter present them for funding, at the rate of 50 cents, with 3 pet cent. interest, has been agreed upon.
MEMPHIS, June 4.--The Memphis and Charleston Railroad filed a suit in chancery today to break its lease to the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 4.--An explosion of gas, which resulted in the burning of five men, three of them fatally, occurred at No. 4 slope, Nanticoke, this morning.

LONDON, June 4.--The Epsom Grand Prize for 3-year-olds was run at Epsom to-day. R. Wright's b.c. Bird of Freedom won, with the Duke of Beaufort's gr. c. Pepper-and-Salt second, and R. Howett's b.c. Barnacles third.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--Admiral Jouett has made an official report to the Navy Department of his recent trip to Cartagena for the purpose of taking a number of Commissioners in order to make, if possible, a peaceful settlement with the revolutionists.

MACON, Ga., June 4.--Near Russellville, Monroe County, Emma Murphy was found stabbed to death. Investigation showed that Ben Watkins, but two weeks out of the penitentiary, was the murderer, and that he committed the deed with small pocket knife. He has fled.

DES MOINES, June 4.--The speeches made by the officers of the Supreme Lodge of United Workmen at the public reception last night have caused comment to-day. The Iowa court decision upholding the seceders was analyzed with ability and keen sarcasm.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 4.--Mrs. John Remmel, who was accidentally shot by the young man, Arthur Lewis, at Kingston yesterday afternoon, died this evening in great agony. The young man who did the shooting is in a terrible state of mind over the sad occurrence and raves like a madman.

CHICAGO, June 4.--Congressman W.L. Scott, of Erie, Penn., was in the city to-day attending the annual meeting of the Northwestern Railway Company. Speaking of the Pennsylvania Federal officeholders, Mr. Scott said that nearly every one of them was an offensive partisan and liable to be removed on that account at any time.

PARIS, Ill., June 4.--A tornado of wind and rain, accompanied by terrific lightning and thunder, lasting 15 minutes, struck this town this afternoon. Half of the Metropolitan Block was unroofed, leaving valuable stocks of goods exposed to the torrents of rain which fell. The Presbyterian church and a number of other buildings were almost totally demolished. The loss will aggregate several thousand dollars. No lives were lost so far as learned.

OYSTER BAY, Long Island, June 4.--William E. Larrabee, a confidential clerk in the employ of James H. Ludlam Co., general dealers in this village, has disappeared, and his accounts are found to be short nearly $1,000.

VICKSBURG, Miss., June 4.--The case of the State against George M. Klein, President of the late Mississippi Valley Bank, charged with receiving funds under false pretenses, was on trial to-day, and was given to the jury at 10 o'clock to-night. The jury were not out five minutes, when they returned with a verdict of not guilty. The jury was composed of citizens of Vicksburg.
BATTLEFORD, June 4.--Only one courier arrived here since Gen. Middleton left. He reports that Gen. Strange has had three engagements, in the last of which one man was killed and three wounded.

LONDON, June 4.--The action for libel against Lord Chief-Justice Coleridge brought by Charles Mantell Adams and based upon attacks on his character made by the defendant in letters to mutual friends for the purpose of prejudicing Miss Mildred Coleridge, whom Adams was courting, against him, was brought up for trial in the Court of Appeal here to-day.

PORTLAND, Me., June 4.--The British brig Anne P. Odell, Capt. Lipsett, from Porto Rico, which arrived this morning, reports yellow fever on board. Both mates died during the passage, and one man is sick. The vessel was ordered to Quarantine.

BOSTON, June 5.--The gross earnings of the Union Pacific Bailroad for the first four months of 1885 were $7,201,607, an increase over the same period last year of $47,140. The expenses were $4,959,494, a decrease of $213,018. The surplus earnings were $2,242,113, an increase of $268,158.

DETROIT, June 5.--The May output of the Calumet and Hecla mine was 2,547 tons; Quincy, 250; Atlantic, 215; Franklin, 190; Huron, 115, and Copper Falls, 65. RICHMOND, Va., June 5.--Cluverius, the convicted murderer of Lilian Madison, was brought to court this morning and through his counsel made a motion for a new trial. Judge Atkins postponed the hearing of the argument on the motion until Monday, and the prisoner was recommitted to jail. He showed no signs of depression, but, on the contrary, appeared brighter than for some time past. There was a large crowd in and about the court room.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 5.--The Senate to-day passed the amended Militia bill, which provides for a force of 4,000 men of all arms, a yearly appropriation of $80,000 for the ordinary expenses of the National Guard, and $85,000 for the purchase of uniforms and equipments.

ST. PETERSBURG, June 8.--A terrible accident has occurred on the railroad from Kosloff to Rostoff, on the River Don. OTTAWA, June 9.--The attention of the Dominion Government has been called to a serious difficulty which may at any time arise between the United States and the Dominion Governments, through the delay in definitely fixing the international boundary line between Alaska and British Columbia.
By the action of the Board of Police yesterday Superintendent George W. Walling was retired into private life after an almost continuous service of nearly 40 years in the police force of this city.

The Summer work of the Children's Aid Society was opened on Monday by a party of 230 children from the Germans and Bohemians on the east side of the city being sent to the Summer Home at Bath, Long Island.
Host (something of a musician, who is entertaining a Kentucky friend at dinner)--Would you like a sonata before dinner, Colonel?

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 9.--The Sinking Fund Commissioners met in open session this afternoon. Several letters were read which included the correspondence that had passed between the board and leading Eastern bankers.

ST. LOUIS, June 9.--Lieut. L.K. Reynolds, United States Navy, son of George M. Reynolds, late First Auditor of the Treasury, who was killed at the Southern Hotel last week, is in the city for the purpose of having the Coroner's inquest on his father's remains reopened, new testimony heard, and the verdict of suicide reversed, he believing that his father's death was accidental.

OTTAWA, June 9.--The steamer Peerless, valued at $50,000, was burned to the water's edge at Montebello this afternoon. An excursion party was aboard the vessel when the fire broke out, but escaped uninjured.

Senator Warner Miller, Fish Commissioner E.G. Blackford, the Hon. Titus Sheard, Fred Mather, Amos Cummings, John D. Hewlett, Frank Lincoln, and Henry P. De Graaf returned a day or two ago from a fishing trip to Wilmurt Lake, in the southern part of Hamilton County, this State.
Ah Mon, the Chinaman who was murdered in Mott-street on Sunday night, was buried in the Evergreen Cemetery yesterday afternoon with both Christian and Mongolian services.

James Lick was not perfect--no man is in this world--but he was as near heaven in life as most men are. He was eccentric and odd, but he had a pretty good heart.
After administering a "Chicago" defeat to the Brooklyn team on Monday the Pittsburg nine encountered the Metropolitan players on the Polo Grounds yesterday.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 9.--The Funding Board report that they have funded up to date about $11,000,000 of State bonds, and have on hand new awaiting funding about $500,000.
MONTREAL, June 9.--The remains of the late Archbishop Bourget will lie in state at the Church of Sault au Recollet till Thursday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 9.--The following dispatch has been received at the War Department from Major-Gen. Schofield dated Chicago, June 6:

The movement in favor of closing stores early on Saturday afternoon is meeting with very general support, and promises to be in a large measure if not completely successful.

The retirement of Mr. WALLING from the place of Superintendent of Police cannot be called premature. It has been expected for a long time, and the act giving the Commissioners discretionary power in respect to the retirement of officers over 60 was understood, under the construction successfully sought to be given ...
The wisdom of the course of the President and his Cabinet in denying visitors on Saturday is demonstrated in the greater rapidity with which appointments are being disposed of.

MONTREAL, June 9.--The barge William, laden with 19,200 bushels of corn, from Kingston to Montreal, sank at the entrance to the new locks at Lachine this morning. The corn was insured. The barge, which is the property of the Kingston and Montreal Forwarding Company, was not insured, but it is believed that she can be raised and saved without damage.

LONDON, June 9.--The result of the defeat of the Government last night, when the House of Commons refused to pass the budget to a second reading on account of the obnoxious increase in the tax on spirits, has been, as was expected, the tendering of the resignations of Mr. Gladstone and his Ministry to the Queen, and all Great Britain to-night is in a state of excitement over the crisis.

OTTAWA, June 9.--Dispatches from Gen. Middleton to-day state that he is following up Big Bear with great difficulty, the trail being in very bad and almost impassable condition. He has been obliged to leave tents behind and send bridging parties ahead to enable the troops to advance.

It was expected by the persons who listened in the body of the court room yesterday to Judge Donohue's charge in the case of Louise Schafer Lafond against William Ernest Jetzkewitz that the jury would speedily find a verdict for the handsome plaintiff.
Ferdinand Ward is reported to have said, in reply to a friend who asked him what he thought of Mr. Fish's letter published in THE TIMES yesterday: "The communication strikes ....

CHICAGO, June 9.--Chicago men who have large dealings with people living in the country tributary to this city note an important improvement in the condition of the farmers and the spirits of the country people in general.
BAKER CITY, Oregon, June 9.--Fred Wickerman was overtaken and arrested in Grant County, Friday, and brought here to-day, charged with the murder of Lewis Rivers and E.A. Allen, prominent cattle men.

CHICAGO, June 9.--Senator H.L. Dawes, of Massachusetts, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, stopped to-day at the Grand Pacific Hotel, on his way home from the Indian Territory, where he has been for several ...
President Young, of the League, issued an order to his staff of umpires yesterday to change rule 27 so as to conform to the rule of last year. The order took effect yesterday.

CONCORD, N.H., June 9.--The legislators have returned to the capital to-day and the Senatorial canvass is resumed with vigor. No one is able to predict what the result will be, though the relative strength of the leading candidates ...

The Athletic Yacht Club's first regatta of the present season took place yesterday under the most favorable circumstances. The air was cool, but not uncomfortably so; the sun shone brightly, a brisk wind blew from the north ...

Secretary Manning's committee of Treasury officers to examine and report upon the use of distinctive paper and the improvement of the notes and securities have finished their report on distinctive paper.
Another fruitless meeting of the trunk line Presidents was held yesterday, all the roads save the Lackawanna and West Shore being represented.
BOSTON, June 9.--The New-York League club made its first appearance in this city this season to-day, and the visitors celebrated the event by defeating the Boston players by a score of 10 to 4.

MONTREAL, June 9.--This morning Robert Fox was again arraigned before the Court of Queen's Bench upon the charge of having forged paper in his possession. This arraignment was on the second of 12 indictments found against him by the Grand Jury, and he pleaded guility to this charge and all others, saying that although he had not forged any paper he supposed he would plead guilty.

Annie McClusky, of No. 517 East Fifteenth-street, was placed on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions under an indictment for homicide founded on the fact that on March 13 she threw her infant from a window and killed it.

LONDON, June 9.--It is announced to-day that the terms of the settlement of the slander case of Mr. Charles Warren Adams against Lord Coleridge have been arranged as follows: The Lord Chief-Justice settles an income of 600 yearly on his daughter, Miss Mildred, on ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 9.--To-day was Class Day at Vassar College. The class officers were Sarah Carrington Hening, Orange, N. J.; Anna Brown Wheeler, Chattanooga, Tenn.; Phoebe Loving, St. Joseph, Mo., and Ella Gertrude, Marlborough, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 9.--Two appointments made by the President to-day have suddenly deprived the hotels of a large number of convivial and talkative politicians, most of whom have gone home on "swearing trains."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 9.--The answer filed by P.L. Moen's counsel to the declaration filed by "Doe" Levi Wilson in his suit against the Worcester millionaire has not been received by Wilson's counsel as yet, but they will have a copy of it here to-morrow. Like the declaration the answer is vague as to the real merits of the now celebrated case.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 9.--Gen. William R. Terry, the father of Hanston Terry, who was lynched by a mob at Liberty about three weeks ago for the murder of F.A. Jeter, was informed to-day for the first time of his son's fate.
NEW-ORLEANS, June 9.--The famous band of the Eighth Mexican Cavalry, 66 pieces, which has been one of the attractions of the Exposition, left to-night for the North on the steamship City of Natchez.
HAVANA, June 9.--Angel Rodriguez, of the Sanchez expedition, has been captured.

OSWEGO, N.Y., June 9.--The seventeenth annual convention of the Diocese of Central New-York (Episcopalian) met at Christ Church, in this city, this evening. The Right Rev. Bishop F.D. Huntington presided.
LONDON, June 9.--A dispatch from Cairo says: "Some excitement has been created here among the English officials and residents by the arrival of a Coptic merchant from Khartoum.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 9.--Charles E. Miller, representing the Corporation Counsel of the city of New-York, appeared before Judge Phelps, in the Superior Court, to-day, and asked that Nathaniel Sands be allowed to present himself in court in New-York on Friday. Judge Phelps denied the motion. Sands is under arrest at Norwalk for receiving $75,000 from the city of New-York for negotiating a loan.
The woman who was arrested the other day on the charge of habitual and disorderly cat keeping was a melancholy example of the effects of intemperance in cats.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 9.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, Chief-Justice, and associates present, the following decisions were handed down:
WASHINGTON, June 9.--The Post to-morrow will publish the following interview with Minister West regarding the defeat of Mr. Gladstone:

MONTREAL, June 9.--The Rev. Father Sentenne has commenced a crusade against moonlight excursions down the river, and he designates the steamboats employed as dens of immorality. He threatens to call public meetings to protest against the actions of the owners of these boats, and see whether it is legal to trade in immorality or not.

HARTFORD, June 10.--There was a lively contest here to-day between officers from Massachusetts and New-Hampshire, who were fortified with requisitions from the Governors of those States, for the possession of Thomas A. Spencer, a notorious home thief, who was released from State prison, after serving two years, at 9 o'clock this morning.

RICHMOND, Va., June 10.--Edmond Waddill, the Mahone United States District Attorney for this district, has written a letter to President Cleveland acknowledging a notification from him of the appointment of Catlett Gibson as his Democratic successor.

WASHINGTON, Penn., June 10.--The monotony of college life was relieved this afternoon by a slugging match, in which W.S. Thomas, a student in Washington-Jefferson College, and a young man from Pittsburg named Baird, were the principals. The match was stopped during the sixth round by Prof. McClelland, who accidentally stepped into the college gymnasium, where the sluggers were at work. Both of the contestants were pretty well used up.

WASHINGTON, June 10.--The June report of the Department of Agriculture will make an increase in cotton area of 5 to 6 per cent.; Virginia, 107 per cent.; North Carolina, 102; South Carolina, 103; Georgia, 104; Florida, 102; Alabama, 109; Mississippi, 106; Louisiana, 107; Texas, 110; Arkansas, 100; Tennessee, 101. The total area exceeds 18,000,000 acres.

The proposal to hold in Fairmount Park a national militia encampment and series of competitive drills seems to have met with sufficient favor to insure the practical undertaking of the project. Many well known soldiers North and South, including Gens. SHERMAN, SHERIDAN, HANCOCK, SLOCUM, McCLELLAN, JOHNSTON, ...

The trunk line Passenger Agents, as had been expected, did nothing at the meeting yesterday. The official statement of the meeting conveyed the information that at the meeting to-day the last details for the new pool, with its eastern termini at New-York and Boston, and including Chicago, St. Louis, Toledo, and Cincinnati, would be arranged.
CARLISLE, Penn., June 10.--The pupils of the Carlisle Indian training school held their annual picnic to-day at Pine Grove Park. The number in attendance was about 400.

WASHINGTON, June 10.--In no department of the Government since Gen. Arthur relinquished the office of President to Mr. Cleveland has there been greater general activity than in the department of which Postmaster-General Vilas is the head.

PROVIDENCE, June 10.--Twenty-five hundred persons witnessed the champions defeat the Giants from New-York to-day. After a most interesting and well-played contest, the Providence Grays came off the winners by the close score of 2 to 1. Radbourne was hit very hard by the visitors, but clever fielding on the part of Carroll, Bassett, and Farrell kept their base hit column within limits.

In an inclosed lot adjoining Gabe Case's hotel, on Jerome-avenue, about 150 members of the Hoboken Turtle Club sat down to breakfast at 8 o'clock yesterday morning.
MONTREAL, June 10.--A little boy named Rudolph Ryan has died from glanders, and the health officers are at a loss to discover how the disease was communicated.

In a private dining room at Delmonico's yesterday afternoon the members of the American Wall Paper Association held their monthly meeting, and dicussed earnestly, and at times rather heatedly, the possibilities and probabilities of a continuance of their pool.

The waters of the Hudson River between this city and Sing Sing were plowed up yesterday afternoon as they never were before. It was a strange looking little vessel that did it. She was 95 feet long and 11 feet in beam--a perfect water knife.

The Conservative newspapers which implored Mr. GLADSTONE to remain in office after they had at last brought about a conjunction of forces to put him out seem to have been doing a very absurd and impudent thing. But, at whatever sacrifice of dignity and consistency, they have shown " business sense."
ALBANY, June 10.--Gov. Hill added 26 more laws to the statute book to-day. One of the most important of these is the measure imposing a tax of 5 per cent. on collateral inheritances of over $500.

The annual tournament for the championship of the Middle States among the clubs comprising the National Lawn Tennis Association was commenced yesterday on the grounds of the St. George's Cricket Club at Hoboken.

WEST POINT, June 10.--The graduating cadets are in high feather to-night. The class standing was published on dress parade, with not a man in it found deficient, and with the general average highly creditable.

With a big ruff around her neck, peaked shoulders on her handsome black silk and velvet robe, a pointed stomacher, and a peaked hat adorned with flaming ribbons, Mrs. Amanda Delphin looked, yesterday, as energetic Queen Bess is made to look in some of her portraits.

The scheme to clean the filthy streets in the vicinity of the water front with salt water, which is promoted by Fire Commissioner Henry D. Purroy, was given a trial last night. The fire boat Zophar Mills was made fast to the bridge wharf at the foot of Roosevelt-street, and two 3 -inch lines of hose were attached to the engines of the boat.

The Metropolitans played poorly in their game with the St. Louis Club on the Polo Grounds yesterday, and the result was the visitors won by figures of 7 to 3. The field work and base running of the St. Louis players was of the highest character.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 10.--At the meeting of the Board of Health last night the Chief Sanitary Inspector, Dr. W.H. Watkins, reported: "Notwithstanding the absence of epidemic infectious disease the mortality during the month has been very high.

The Exeutive Committee of the Western Union Telegraph Company met yesterday and recommended the declaration of the usual dividend of 1 per cent. for the quarter ending June 30, the net earnings for the quarter--partly estimated--showing a surplus over the expenses and interest of $56,391, the total surplus on July 1 being estimated at $4,303,334. The full board subsequently declared the dividend, which will be payable July 15.
PORT SAID, June 10.--A large dredger accidentally sank in the middle of the canal to-day. Traffic will, in consequence, be suspended for at least two weeks.
MADRID, June 10.--Two cases, suspected to be cholera, were reported in Madrid to-day. Three new cases were reported in Murcia, but none in Valencia.

ST. LOUIS, June 10.--From a letter received here to-day from E. Preller, the father of C. Arthur Preller, the victim of the Southern Hotel murder, it appears that the murderer was traveling under an assumed name, and that he was an escaped forger from England. The letter was written to Preller senior and forwarded by him to the Chief of Police in this city. It reads:
NEW-ORLEANS, June 10.--Indifferent as our police are to the whereabouts of our murderers, and harmless as they are to highwaymen and garroters, they are efficient at times in other directions.

SPRINGFIELD, June 10.--If any decided change has occurred in the various discussions and debates of to-day it is rather against Foraker than in his favor, although his arrival late this afternoon and the ovation that was given him may have started his chance on an upward grade.

TROY, N.Y., June 10.--Yesterday afternoon, William Vandecar, a messenger employed by the National Express Company, left the company's office in this city to make his usual run to Albany. He supposed that he had with him three packages containing about $10,000 in money, bonds, , as he had signed for them at the office.
WASHINGTON, June 10.--Secretary Manning to-day signed an order to Collectors of Customs, revoking all orders heretofore made regulating the inspection or importation of old rags.
James Morn, a watchman, and a bartender were chatting at Broome and East streets at 5:45 o'clock yesterday morning, when they ...
A three days' sale of horses consigned to Easton's National Horse and Cattte Exchange, limited, was begun at Madison-Square Garden yesterday.

LONDON, June 10.--It is rumored that the Queen has sent a telegram to Mr. Gladstone requesting him to reconsider his decision to resign. There is no reason, however, to believe that Mr. Gladstone will, under existing conditions, consent to resume office.
The First Assistant Postmaster-General has appointed the following-named fourth class Postmasters: Edward W. Kelly at Sodus, N.Y.; Joel S. Sherfield at Rose, N.Y.

The June meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club begins to-day at Sheepshead Bay, with the usual enormous list of entries. The principal event of the day is the Suburban Handicap, which has been the leading topic in the turf world during the Spring, and an immense amount of money will change hands on the result.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 10.--The resignation of President Caldwell, of Vassar College, yesterday, while it was not expected by the Alumnae, is hailed with rejoicing by many of them, who believe that his administration has been of great injury to Vassar.

ST. LOUIS, June 10.--Early this evening Sophia Bonnekamp and Martha Ziegeler, two young married women, residing at No. 205 Sidney-sereet, attempted to commit suicide by jumping into the river from the ferryboat Jacob Tamm, lying at the foot of Lamie-street.

WASHINGTON, June 10.--In a telegram dated Fort Bayard, New-Mexico, 6th inst., Col. Bradley states that it is certain that the hostile Apaches are making for Mexico by way of Stein's Peak Range.

WASHINGTON, June 10.--First Lieut. Francis E. Eltonhead, Twenty-first Infantry, now on leave of absence at Philadelphia, has been ordered to report to the Superintendent of the General Recruiting Service, New-York City, to accompany a detachment of recruits to the Department of the Platte.

CHICAGO, June 10.--Mr. Daly having received new papers and new evidence from Germany, has withdrawn his suit against Mr. Peattie from the United States Court and brought a new suit in the Supreme Court of Illinois, where he will have a more immediate hearing.

MONTREAL, June 10.--The Mayor to-day called a meeting of the leading merchants to consider in what manner they should express to United States Consul-General Steams, who has been superseded, the feelings of respect and esteem in which he is held.

It is altogether probable that the candidate agreed upon in the Republican caucus to be held at Concord this evening will be elected by the New-Hampshire Legislature as the United States Senator to succeed HENRY W. BLAIR.
At a recent meeting of the representatives of the English steamship companies it was decided to raise the eastward steerage rates for a period of three months, beginning next Monday.

It is a pleasure for ladies to shop in the new store of Le Boutillier Brothers in West Twenty-third-street. The first floor is not chopped up into little room, but occupies a clear space, from Twenty-third to Twenty-second-street, of 198 feet, with a width of 75 feet, and is 18 feet in height.

Two enthuuiastic admirers of the late Jesse Hoyt testified concerning his personal attributes and character, in the case of the contest of his will by his daughter, before Surrogate Rollins yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 10.--Judge Samuel E. Flanigan, of McLeansborough, Ill., has entered upon an investigation of the claims of the Coonz heirs to the larger portion of the business section of this city.
LONDON, June 10.--A sensation has been caused by the publication of Lord Wolseley's dispatches denouncing the evacuation of the Soudan.

AUGUSTA, June 10.--The body of Alexander H. Stephens was to-day taken from the vault in Atlanta, where it had been placed on March 8, 1883, and carried to Crawfordsville, his old home, 65 miles from Augusta.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., June 10.--P.L. Cable, of this city, has donated $25,000 to Augustana College toward the fund for the erection of the new building by that institution.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 10.--The Stafford case again came up in the Supreme Court to-day on the petition of Pardon P. Case and other creditors of Stafford Co.
PITTSBURG, June 10.--John Kuntz, who is traveling on a wager of $2,000 from NewYork to San Francisco, arrived here tonight.
The regular meeting of the Young Men's Republican Club was held at their rooms, No. 21 West Twenty-seventh-street, last evening, VicePresident James P. Foster presiding.

The dons and students of Columbia, College gathered at the Academy of Music yesterday morning to celebrate the one hundred and thirty-first Commencement of the college. Every seat in the body of the house was occupied, and there were few gaps in the rows of ladies who thronged the galleries.

Recorder Smyth sat all yesterday afternoon in Part II, of the General Sessions while the weary efforts of the lawyers about to engage in Charles A. Buddensiek's trial to secure a jury went slowly forward.

CINCINNATI, June 10.--George Schneider confined in the jail at Hamilton, 25 miles north of this city, under sentence of death, to-day confessed his crime--that of killing his mother. The murder occurred last Fall. The dead woman's body was found buried in a field on Schneider's farm.
CHICAGO, June 10.--Several losses of jewelry have occurred lately in the fashionable boarding house of C.D. Lester. No. 134 La Salleavenue.

In 1883 a company was formed for the construction of a line of railroad from the city of Mexico to Guatemala. NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 10.--The bill authorizing the Funding Board to borrow money enough to pay interest on State bonds and coupons that may hereafter be funded has passed both houses.

A method for transmitting electric currents across rivers or lakes was illustrated by Prof. P.H. Van der Weyde last evening to members of the New-York Electrical Society, of which he is the President.

MONTREAL, June 10.--The case of Mr. L. McDonald, who is suing the Directors of the Consolidated Bank to render them liable for the capital of the bank, $3,500,000, which the shareholders allege was lost through their culpable negligence, was concluded to-day.

Ten thousand packages of flannels, including all grades of twilled and plain goods, and 1,600 packages of wide sheetings were disposed of yesterday in a peremptory sale at the wererooms of Wilmerding, Hoguet Co., Nos. 64 and 66 White-street. The sale opened at 10 A.M., ...
A match broken off on the eve of a wedding is the theme of kindly and sympathetic comment among the villagers at Rockville Centre, Long Island. The wedding was to take place two weeks ago yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 10.--The Grand Jury found true bills to-day for criminal libel against Y.E. Allison, managing editor of the Daily Commercial, and George W. Smith, a reporter for the same paper.

The mysterious and unaccountable disappearance of a well-to-do resident of Brooklyn was reported at Brooklyn Police headquarters on Tuesday night, and the police in both Brooklyn and New-York are now engaged in trying to find some clue which will lead to the discovery of his present whereabouts.
TORONTO, June 10.--An interesting case regarding the Canadian Indians was decided here to-day by Chancellor Boyd, in the High Court.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 10.--The village of Naples, Ontario County, in this vicinity, was thrown into excitement yesterday afternoon at the news that Simeon Lyons, a prominent farmer had been killed while insane by his brother, Supervisor Irving Lyons, of the same town.
MILWAUKEE, June 10.--The annual meeting of the stockholders and Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway Company occurred to-day at the general offices in this city.
A little lot of old iron, recovered from the United States sloops Java and Colossus, which were recently broken up, was sold at auction at the navy yard yesterday.

NORFOLK, Va., June 10.--Subscribers to the stock of the new national bank met to-day, elected Directors, and made arrangements to begin business. It is thought the bank will be opened about July 1.
The new time table of the Manhattan Beach branch of the Long Island Railroad Company is published this morning.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 10.--Harlow, Spencer Co., grain and commission merchants, have failed. This firm for a great many years past has occupied a controlling position in the Southern grain trade, and has been known on 'Change and elsewhere as one of the prominent houses in St. Louis.

The family of William King, a boss painter in the employ of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad Company, live on the top floor of a small house at No. 10 Amos-street, in Clifton, Staten Island. Mr. King is very fond of canned salmon, and to gratify her husband's taste on Monday evening Mrs. King bought a can from a neighboring grocer for supper.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 10.--During the last two or three days there has been no news of importance from the front. Gen. Middleton and his force have been following Big Bear and his band with all possible speed, but naturally the Indians can move much faster than the General's force, but in spite of this they will soon be caught or will have to fight for victory.
A careful statistician recently obtained from three hundred and sixty-two trout fishermen the weight of the fish caught by each one during the year 1884, and also the number of fish caught.

ST. LOUIS, June 10.--Count Von Alt Leiningen Westerburg, who died last night at his residence, No. 2,920 Market-street, has been living in poverty in St. Louis and Cincinnati for several years.

The little examination room of the Jefferson Market Police Court was filled yesterday morning with the parties to the Keep libel suits, the benches for the spectators being crowded throughout the proceedings with Wall-street men and operators, who are taking great interest in the case.

It is now admitted on all sides that the latest plan of the Hewitt-McClellan committee for the reorganization of West Shore will not receive the support of the bondholders, and it is said that in view of this fact some members of the committee have virtually expressed a determination to retire from the field.
LANCASTER, Penn., June 10.--Frost occurred at various points in Lancaster County last night. The growing wheat was somewhat damaged, but the young tobacco is believed to have escaped injury.

FULTONVILLE, N.Y., June 10.--The NewYork Riding Club arrived here to-day. The riders were met by the leading citizens and the Thirteenth Brigade Band of Amsterdam. Tonight they were given a reception at ex-Congressman Starin's residence.
