OMAHA, Neb., June 12.--In the libel suit brought by Edward Rosewater, editor of the Bec, against the proprietors of the Omaha Republican, who had republished the charge that he was a Confederate spy and traitor during the war, the jury to-day brought in a verdict awarding $100 damages to the plaintiff.
Mark Brent Newth died yesterday at No. 236 Fourth-avenue, of a complication of diseases, due partly to the opium habit. He was born in Lyons, N.Y., in 1850, and received an excellent education.
PORTLAND, Me., June 12.--The annual Spring regatta of the Portland Yacht Club took place this morning. The weather was favorable, with a strong southerly breeze blowing.
MOUNT STERLING, Ky., June 12.--Monteville Hatfield, about 25 years of age, was this morning tried under an indictment for grand larceny.

ST. LOUIS, June 12.--This was the sixth day of the St. Louis Fair Association races. The weather was threatening, but the track was fast and the attendance large. The defeat of Freeland by the California horse Jim Douglas, and the victory of Volante, with 125 pounds up, in the 3-year-old event, one mile and a quarter, run in 2:12, were the leading incidents.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--Mr. Sparks, Commissioner of the Land Office, has not, as reported to-day, issued an order forfeiting the bulk of the fraudulent Maxwell land grant and restoring more than 1,500,000 acres of land to public entry. Mr. Sparks would be glad to do it, but he cannot.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, June 12.--Two men have just arrived from nine miles north of Sioux City. They were passengers on the Sioux Falls train on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Road due here at 7:10. The train was struck by a cyclone, and every car thrown from the track and smashed to pieces. There were three passenger coaches and a baggage car. A large number of persons were injured. No details have been received.
NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, June 12.--President Zaldivar, of Central America, and suite arrived here this morning and visited all points of interest.
WASHINGTON, June 12, 1885. The President to-day appointed Samuel L. Graham to be United States Marshal for the Western District of Virginia.

A slender blonde, 30 years old, who gave her address as No. 847 Seventh-avenue and her name as Annie M. Fletcher, testified in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday that she was the wife of a car driver, Francis Fletcher, of No. 411 West Fifty-sixth-street.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, June 12.--The following additional particulars have been received concerning the capture of the supply camp of Capt. Lawton, of the Fourth Cavalry, in Gandaloupe Canon, Sonora, and the massacre of five of his men: Capt. Lawton, with a troup of cavalry, entered the canon and, leaving the wagons in charge of seven men, started out on a scout.
READING, Penn., June 12.--The man who committed suicide yesterday by throwing himself in front of a passing train was Ezra Schmehl, a young cigarmaker.
The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a series of complimentary resolutions concerning the Bartholdi statue.
The first authoritative declaration of Republican doctrine since the party assumed the important function of opposition to the party in power appears in the platform of the Ohio Convention.

While Park Policeman Thompson was patrolling Tompkin's-square at about 6 o'clock yesterday morning he heard piercing screams coming from the direction of the church that fronts on Avenue B. He hurried to the spot from which the screams came and saw a man kneeling on the sidewalk and holding up his ...

MANCHESTER, June 12.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "There has been a fair business in cloths. Prices have not improved, however, buyers being able to place orders at previous rates and producers being unable to do better. Yarns are quiet but steady. Buyers are cautious. A further reduction in production is expected."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 12.--The expected deadlock in the Legislature on account of the Registration bill occurred this evening. Objections were made by the Republicans to the consideration of the measure, which was finally taken up. Amendments were offered thick and fast by the objectors, together with motions to adjourn, and it was insisted in every case that the yeas and nays be called.
GREENVILLE, Tenn., June 12.--In the Johnson murder trial to-day the State exhausted its testimony and the defense commenced filing depositions in proof of the high character of the defendant.

MONTREAL, June 12.--Sir Henry Tyler leaves here to-morrow for Ottawa to interview the Premier in reference to disposing of the North Shore Railway. He said there was no truth in the report that a pooling arrangement was made with the Canadian Pacific, as such a course was forbidden by law, but he hoped to come to an amicable arrangement with that road.

NEW-ORLEANS, June 12.--Yesterday, in the Civil District Court room, some sharp words passed between the presiding Judge, the Hon. Frank A. Monroe, and R. Stewart Denne, a practicing attorney, in which the former accused the latter of stating an untruth.

PRINCETON, June 12.--Princeton met Dartmouth for their first championship game this afternoon on the university grounds. The day was all that could be desired, and the grounds were in perfect condition.

WARSAW, N.Y., June 12.--Fred W. Vincent, of Attica, N.Y., has begun an action for a divorce in the Supreme Court of Wyoming County against Martha W. Vincent, his wife, now of San Jose, Cal. The plaintiff in his summons and complaint alleges that he was duly ...

Police Superintendent Murray, in a communication to the Commissioners yesterday, recommended several important changes in the administration of the Central Office, among them one that the offices of the inspection districts be abolished and the many men now attached to them transferred to places where their services are required.

An order has been made by Judge J.F. Daly, of the Court of Common Pleas, adjudging the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, its President, Norvin Green, and its Secretary, Abijah R. Brewer, guilty of contempt of court, ...

ALBANY, June 12.--Gov. Hill has been engaged most of the day with the Supply bill and had not finished his consideration of the items this evening. He expects to announce the vetoed appropriations to-morrow afternoon. No bills were signed or vetoed to-day.

CHICAGO, June 12.--It is reported on good authority that the Cook County Democratic Club, the "gang" organization which made so much noise at the last convention, during inauguration week, and which also backed McGarigle for United States Marshal, is about to dissolve, a collector having absconded with the funds, and the membership having dwindled down.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 12.--Reports from Cape Breton indicate a very heavy storm along the coast on the first three days of the week. A gale began blowing Sunday morning and continued with almost unabated vigor until Tuesday night, the wind being nearly north all the time.
SHANGHAI, June 11.--The following are provisions of the treaty of peace: French soldiers shall not enter Chinese territory nor shall Chinese soldiers enter French territory.
PETERSBURG, Va., June 12.--The headquarters of the United States Internal Revenue Department for the Second District of Virginia will be moved from Petersburg to Richmond at ...

NEWARK, N.J., June 12.--Some months ago a feeble old man named Clossen, who had suffered a paralytic stroke, was heard crying for help from his premises at Orange. The neighbors who went to his aid found him lying on the ground in front of his house.

MONTREAL, June 12.--A consignment of 42 dozen felt hats from a Montreal house to a firm in New-York have been seized at Rouse's Point by the United States customs officers for undervaluation. It is said that a number of other shipments to the same firm, and aggregating several thousand dollars, will also be seized.
BOSTON, June 12.--The Governor to-day signed the bill providing for a metropolitan police system for the city of Boston.
HALIFAX, June 12.--Admiral Sir J.E. Commerell will be relieved as Commander of the British North American Squadron in October by the Earl of Clarwilliam.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 12.--During an altercation this morning between Henry Neiertz and Peter Guidinger, farmers, residing about 12 miles north of this city, the former was shot and killed by Guidinger, who delivered himself up to the authorities soon after.
RALEIGH, N.C., June 12.--Thomas Gee, Thomas McNeill, and Joseph Howard, all colored, have been sentenced to be hanged at Fayetteville on July 25, all having been convicted of murder.

While Officer Clark, of the Sixth Precinct, Brooklyn, was attempting to disperse a gang of young ruffians on Withers-street, late on Thursday night, one of them knocked him down with a heavy stone, and immediately the whole gang set upon him.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 12.--The University of Pennsylvania, Brown University, and Bowdoin College boat crews have engaged quarters at O'Leary's boat house at Lake Quinsigamond, preparatory to the annual regatta of the Inter-collegiate Rowing Association to be contested between crews from Pennsylvania, Brown, Bowdoin, Columbia, and Cornell Colleges on the afternoon of July 4.

SPRINGVALE, Me., June 12.--Trouble, which has been brewing for some time over the enforcement of the prohibitory law, culminated last night in the organization of a mob, armed with revolvers and stones, and attacks upon a number of houses, in which windows were smashed and other damage was done.
MADRID, June 12.--Eleven cases of disease resembling cholera are reported in this city. Four deaths occurred here yesterday from the malady reported.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 12.--The Georgia Temperance Convention concluded its session yesterday. Resolutions were adopted petitioning the Legislature to pass a general local option law at its session next month, so that in every county in the State there can be an election on prohibition.

The new Commissioner of the General Land Office has submitted to Secretary LAMAR a very interesting report about the Maxwell land grant in New-Mexico. The summary of this report furnished to the press contains the names of one or two Government officers whose action with reference to the grant is criticised, but ...

PORTLAND, Oregon, June 11.--One of the curiosities in the railroad world is the Oregon Pacific Railway, which has been unable to turn a wheel since April 16 for want of $15,000 or $20,000 in ready cash, and which is to-day at a standstill.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 12.--Gen. Middleton's hunt for Big Bear has so far been a failure. The General has met with insurmountable difficulties in the pursuit, the course of the troops being impeded by muskegs and swamps, and through which supply and ammunition wagons could not be drawn.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 12.--The progress of the trial of William A. White, indicted for murder in the first degree for killing Samuel Proper at Dover Plains on Feb. 12, excites great interest. All day the court room has been thronged, and hundreds have been turned away unable to gain admission.

BOSTON, June 12.--The New-York players won their fourth successive game from the Bostons to-day. They batted the curves of Whitney very hard, Connor leading in this respect by making two singles and a two-baser. Keefe, who pitched for the visitors, was very effective.

The libel suit now pending in our courts against Charles D. Keep, editor of the WallStreet Daily News, is, perhaps, of more vital importance to the press of this country than any proceeding which has taken place for years.

WALKERTOWN, Ontario, June 12.--At this place to-night a bullet was fired through a window of the editorial room of the Bruce Herald, a prominent anti-temperance paper here. The ball passed over the editor's chair, which had been vacated only a minute before. The Scott temperance act is in force here, and is creating much ill-feeling.

ZACATECAS, Mexico, June 12.--Twelve miles from Zacatecas is situated the celebrated Santo Tiburcio de Laveta Grande mine, the mine that has produced ever since the Spanish conquest, yielding untold millions of silver during that time.

WASHINGTON, Penn., June 12.--Ignatius Buckingham, of Beallsville, dropped dead suddenly this morning. He had been at work upon the roads, and while resting for a few moments death overtook him without a moment's warning.

The closing exercises of the Naval Academy have already taken place and those of the Military Academy are in progress. The year at both institutions has been upon the whole quiet, and their respective Superintendents may be congratulated upon their gratifying state of efficiency.

The programme for to-day's races at Sheepshead Bay will afford some good sport. The entry list is not as large as on Thursday, but that is a great advantage to the public, and makes the contests more interesting.

CINCINNATI, June 12.--The accident reported at New River, Tenn., on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad yesterday, which was reported to have resulted from the caving in of a tunnel, was the result of the wrecking of a construction train instead.
The ladies of Staten Island had splendid weather yesterday for the games of the Ladies' Club for Outdoor Sports.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 12.--In the Com mon Pleas Court this morning Campbell C. Brown and Thomas Fleming, of New-York, who were recently granted a judgment for $105,000, ...

Charles A. Buddensiek's ferret-like eyes were riveted on the broad expanse of white ceiling in Part II, of the General Sessions yesterday morning. Occasionally they descended to the mundane scene being enacted in the court room, but it was only occasionally.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 12.--The Class Day exercises at Brown Univerisity were held to-day. Mr. Theron H. Carter, the class orator, delivered an oration on "Individualism in the State." The class poem, by Mr. Titcomb, on "Change," was a production of an unusually high standard of excellence.

Lizzie Shafer, of Brooklyn, was sentenced on June 3 under the new code by Judge Naeher to eight months in the Kings County Penitentiary, on complaint of John C. Agnew, for obtaining goods on lease of the Metropolitan Manufacturing Company and pawning them for her own benefit.

Commissioner Voorhis presented a resolution at the meeting of the Police Board yesterday to the effect that the vacant Inspectorship should be filled by promotion from the next lower grade by competitive examination before the Municipal Civil Service Board.

A complimentary dinner was given to Assemblyman Walter Howe at the Union League Club house last evening. A number of Mr. Howe's friends in the club determined to testify in this manner their appreciation of his services in the Legislature, and upon Hugh N. Camp, President of the Clearing House, devolved the pleasant task of arranging details.

CHICAGO, June 12.--F.W. Englebert came to this city from Germany about three years ago, bringing with him $23,000, part of which belonged to relatives, who had intrusted the money to him to speculate with.

The third and last day of the tournament for the lawn tennis championship of the Middle States brought together more people than either of the previous days. The delightful weather caused the ladies to put in an appearance in great numbers.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., June 12.--W.S. Nicholson Co., cotton factors, have made a cession of property to their creditors. Liabilities, $21,000; nominal assets, $11,000.

MONTREAL, June 12.--The bodies of Archbishop Bourget and Bishop Lartique were today taken from the churches where they had been deposited and carried in procession to St. Peter's Cathedral, where a handsome catafalque, surrounded by 100 lights, had been erected.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., June 12.--S.H. Seamans, of this city, Secretary of the Millers' National Association, has completed and to-day issued to the members of the association an exhaustive report of the present condition and ...

Some amusement has been caused among New-York bankers by the recent talk from Washington about removing Government deposits from the Sub-Treasuries and distributing the United States gold, silver, greenbacks, certificates, , among various banks, ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 12.--The Hon. J. W. Tate, the present incumbent, was nominated to-day by the State Central and Executive Committee, at Frankfort, as the Democratic candidate for State Treasurer at the August election. There was no opposition to Tate.

STAUNTON, Va., June 12.--Last week a boy living with his uncle, Jack Huffman, a mountaineer of Highland County, died, it was alleged, from the effects of a fall, and was buried. Suspicion was aroused and the body was exhumed.

"Denouncing" the Administration for lowering the flags on public buildings on the death of one who was formerly a Cabinet officer and "arraigning" the President for appointing "unrepentant rebels" to office is not the way to win at politics this year.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 12.--The London Bank, of this city, has made a flank movement against the National Bank of Mexico. The Government some months ago granted the National Bank the exclusive right to issue circulating notes.

An agent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children brought before Justice Kenna, in Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday morning, Francesca Naegle, a very pretty girl, 12 years old, who accused her father, Max Naegle, of No. 57 Stockholm-street, of having brutally treated her.

CHICAGO, June 12.--F.A. Talbot, alias Otto Funk, a young man who some time ago created a sensation by being discovered in the possession of several thousand valuable books he had stolen from the Public Library while in its ...

PHILADELPHIA, June 12.--A collision occurred on the Schuylkill Valley Branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad this afternoon, in which three men lost their lives and two others were injured. The accident happened within 50 yards of the little station of Spring Mill, just a mile ...
Miss Ada Gray has so greatly pleased west side theatregoers by her acting in "East Lynne" that her engagement at the Grand Opera House will be extended through next week.
ST. PETERSBURG, June 12.--An earthquake has occurred in the Eastern Caucasus. The town of Sikuch was completely swallowed, and the township suffered damage to the extent of several million rubles.

The Right Hon. Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoigne Cecil, K.G., Marquis of Salisbury, whom the Queen has summoned to Balmoral to form a new Cabinet, has been the leader of the Opposition in the House of Lords since Mr. Gladstone came into power the last time.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--So much of paragraph 11, special orders of May 13, as directs Capt. James H. Lord, Assistant Quartermaster, to proceed to Jeffersonville depot. Indiana, has been suspended until further orders, and he will, upon transferring his duties and public funds and property pertaining to the ...

LONDON, June 12.--A fire broke out this afternoon in the India Museum Annex to the great building in which is being held the International Exhibition of Inventions. This department is just north of the main entrance to the Exhibition and between the eastern wall of the Exhibition Building proper and Exhibition road.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 12.--To-day Abe Upton, colored, was sentenced to the penitentiary for 16 years for a highway robbery committed, yesterday. Last evening Upton snatched a purse from a young woman on the street, and was arrested this morning. At 2 P.M. an indictment was found against him in the Criminal Court, now in session here, and at 3 P.M. he was found guilty and sentenced.

The 1,500 persons who attended the Metropolitan-St. Louis game on the Polo Grounds yesterday witnessed a most remarkable feat in batting. It was performed by David Orr, the first baseman of the Mets. He went to the bat six times, and hit the ball safely on each acca sion.

The counsel for the city announced themselves as being ready to proceed with the case of the Mayor against Nathaniel Sands yesterday before Judge Lawrence, in the Supreme Court. Aaron J. Vanderpoel, however, asked for a postponement, saying that he had been only recently retained by the defendant, and ...

At a recent conference in this city of the Health Officers of the ports of New-York, Boston, New-Haven, Brooklyn, and Baltimore and the State Board of Health of New-York, the following quarantine regulations were adopted to prevent the introduction of cholera and other diseases into the United States the coming Summer, to go into effect immediately:

WEST POINT, June 12.--The cadets put on clean white trousers this afternoon and banged away with brass cannon on the plain in honor of the Russian Minister, Baron de Struve. The diplomat drove around the post with Secretary Endicott and Gen. Merritt, admiring everything ...

As the Croton express on the New-York Central was coming out of the tunnel at Ninetysixth-street and Fourth-avenue on the east track at, 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a man who had been loitering in the neighborhood for some time went to the Ninety-seventh-street bridge and threw himself off.

The tenth annual meeting of the National Association of Amateur Athletes will be held on the Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds, Eighty-sixth-street and Eighth-avenue, this afternoon, beginning at 3 o'clock.

CINCINNATI, June 12.--The Duckworth Club, of this city, last evening expelled M.L. Hawkins and Julius Reis, members of the Board of Police Commissioners, for permitting the third member of the commission, who is a Republican, to appoint three Republicans as policemen and indorsing their appointment.
LONDON, June 12.--The Marquis of Salisbury has consented to form a Ministry, with Sir Stafford Northcote as Chancellor of the Exchequer.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 12.--Judge Allen has decided that the pool selling law is unconstitutional. An appeal has been taken to the Supreme Court.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 12.--A novel suit was begun in the Chancery Court this morning by the filing of a petition by Mattie Palmer against William E. Montgomery, asking that a marriage between them be declared void, and that Montgomery be enjoined from making any claim to her children.

John Andrew Jackson, now an evangelist, who escaped from slavery in 1847, and who has lately been preaching and lecturing in behalf of the Southern colored people in the North, is now getting subscriptions to build a church and lecture hall at Magnolia, Lynchburg, S.C.
The suit brought by Isaac Blumenthal, as a Kansas Pacific bondholder, against Jay Gould and Russell Sage, as Trustees of the Kansas Pacific consolidated mortgage, has been discontinued.

The affairs of James D. Fish were brought up before Referee Cole yesterday afternoon in a suit of John H. Morris, Fish's Assignee, to set aside certain conveyances made by the exbank President on Dec. 21, 1883.

ZANESVILLE, Ohio, June 12.--The people of this locality are agitated over the elopement of Emma Thinger, daughter of a wealthy farmer, with Leonard Irwin, husband of her father's sister. The girl is 18 years of age. The pair are said to have been seen last in Cincinnati, where they purchased tickets for some point in the West.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., June 12.--The members of the New-York Riding Club left Fultonville this afternoon amid a salute from Starin's Battery and arrived at the Hotel Warner, in this place, where they were given a reception by the leading citizens. The band also welcomed them.
Mme. Fannie Restless, a wealthy lady of sporting proclivities, with a fondness for horses, dogs, and birds, living at No. 63 Madison-avenue, was arrested yesterday on a warrant issued by ...

Letters to this city state that the Government of Hayti has paid the debts of Charles A. Van Bokkelen, an American citizen, and released him from jail. It is said to have done so on account of a rumor on the streets of Port au Prince that Minister Thompson was proceeding from Washington in a man-of-war to demand the prisoner's release, and secure it by force if necessary.

George I. Seney continued his testimony yesterday before Referee Cole in the case of F. H. Smith, Receiver of the Atlantic National Bank, of Brooklyn, against the Metropolitan Bank for an accounting and recovery of $232,000, which was the amount of the Atlantic Bank's ...

Mr. E.O. Graves, chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, and Mr. O'Neil, the chief engraver of the bureau, to-day submitted to Postmaster-General Vilas half a dozen penand-ink designs for the new postal cards.

A series of very interesting experiments have recently been made upon dead dogs by scientific persons. The net result of them is to prove that a dog that has been dead for several hours can readily be brought back to life.

Mr. Alexander S. Fridberg, a diamond merchant, residing at No. 46 East Sixty-sixthstreet, was arraigned before Justice Smith, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon, charged with the larceny of diamonds ...

William M. Lent, Chairman of the Windsor Hotel meeting of West Shore stockholders and of a conference of the New-York, Philadelphia, and Utica Bondholders' Committees, having been asked to give his views of the present West Shore position, said:

The Irving Hall Executive Committee squabbled for an hour last evening over the contesting delegations in the Fourteenth Assembly District and finally referred the trouble to a committee consisting of Oscar H. Bogart, Robert ...

CHICAGO, June 12.--Theodore Henning, employed as a molder in the shops of the Chicago Hardware Company, came home drunk last night and picked a quarrel with his young wife. Getting thoroughly enraged, he picked up a large bowl to throw at her, but the heavy missile missed its aim, and, instead, struck the 3-year-old son of the couple, who was slumbering peacefully in his crib.
Miss Susan Rapylea, aged 80, died at her residence near Douglaston, Long Island, two months ago from injuries received by falling down stairs.
PARIS, June 12.--Mme. Nilsson has gained her action against her late husband's relatives, who have been ordered to pay Mme. Nilsson the sum of 8,400.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--With the approval of the President, and after consultation with the Cabinet, the Postmaster-General has decided not to advertise for bids to enter into contracts for the transportation of the foreign mails upon a mileage basis, under the permissive authority conferred by the act of Congress of March 3, 1885.

TARENTUM, Penn., June 12.--Henry Altmeyer's three sons, aged 7, 5, and 2 years, respectively, were terribly burned this morning by the explosion of a can of refined petroleum. The children in some manner obtained possession of the oil and one of them applied a match to it. An explosion followed and the burning fluid was scattered over the little unfortunates. Two of them are not expected to recover.

Mrs. Mary Bergman a few years ago kept a little dry goods store in Greenville, N.J. She was too eccentric to succeed as a business woman, and she finally went into retirement in a little dwelling house on Waverly-street in that place with her husband, who is a teamster in Doetweiller's fireworks factory.
Mr. GLADSTONE has not "gone to Canossa" as the Conservatives kindly advised him to do. He has not even gone to Balmoral, as the Queen was reported to have commanded him to do.

On May 18 last two children--Robert Blair, age 5 years, and John Henry O'Hara, 3 years old--were making a bonfire in Summerstreet, Paterson, when the younger was so severely burned that he died a week later from his injuries.
HARTFORD, Conn., June 12.--The June meeting at Charter Oak Park closed to-day with exciting races which resulted disastrously to backers of the favorites.
SARATOGA, N.Y., June 12.--The Court of Appeals day calendar for Monday, June 15, is as follows: Nos. 245, 247, 235, 248, 250, 252, 254.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 12.--Several State papers, representing both political parties, have recently spoken favorably of the Hon. Alfred E. Burr, of the Hartford Times, as the next Democratic candidate for Governor of Connecticut.

LONDON, June 12.--At to-day's hearing of the Lauderdale case before the House of Lords, Mr. Stephen Nash testified that between the years 1691 and 1830 the laws governing marriage in the State of New-York required only a contract of marriage made in the presence of witnesses without ceremony of any kind.

The Rev. Edwin Paxton Hood, Pastor of the Independent Chapel, Falcon-square, London, died yesterday in that city. Mr. Paxton was born at Westminster 65 years ago, and was educated privately. He was for many years the editor of the Eclectic Review, and for a number of years he edited the Preacher's Lantern.

An autopsy in the case of Joseph Levy, of Totowa-avenue, Paterson, showed that his death doubtless ensued from poison, probably chloral. Ex-Mayor Barnert, of Paterson, has interested himself to see that Levy is buried with Hebrew rites.

OTTAWA, Ontario, June 12.--In the House this afternoon Sir John Macdonald stated that he had received a telegram from Sir Leonard Tilley, conveying the information that he had successfully undergone the operation of lithotomy, and as a result will, in all probability, be restored to perfect health. The announcement was received with applause from both sides of the House.

Henry Jones, of No. 412 Baltic-street, Brooklyn, was arrested for abandoning his wife about a week ago. He was locked up in the Raymond-Street Jail, where he died on Monday last. The cause of his death was said to be apoplexy, superinduced by hard drinking.
LONDON, June 12.--The publication of the Queen's new book, "The Life and Letters of the Duke of Albany," has been postponed until the Autumn.
CHICAGO, June 12.--The funeral of the late Mrs. Horace White took place at 3 P.M. today from the residence of Mr. Francis B. Peabody, at the corner of Dearborn-avenue and Division-street.

PINE LEVEL, Fla., June 12.--In the trial of the Sarasota thugs, Charles B. Willard and Joseph C. Anderson have been found guilty of murder in the first degree, but were recommended by the jury to the mercy of the court. Edmund P. Bacon was acquitted. A motion for a new trial for Willard and Anderson has been entered. The trial of the other conspirators will proceed at once.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 12.--In the United States Court to-day, William Johnson and Jefferson Cook, both of Crenshaw County, pleaded guilty to the charge of defrauding the Government in the matter of the pension of the widow of a Federal soldier. They were sentenced to three years in prison and fined $1,400.

Representative Randall finds it hard to tear himself away from the departments and from Washington. He has been saying goodbye to his friends, but his friends still meet him on the street, and his face is as familiar in the offices of the different Secretaries as that of any Democratic politician in the office-hunting crowd.
HARRISBURG, Penn., June 12.--Both branches of the Pennsylvania Legislature adjourned to-day sine die.
PRINCETON, Ill., June 12.--The steamer Joe Fleming, owned by Mr. Lamp, of St. Louis, employed in the ice trade, was burned last night ...

PITTSBURG, June 12.--John Teemer, the oarsman, issued a challenge to Edward Hanlan to-day offering to row one race of either four or five miles for from $1,000 to $5,000 a side and the championship of America, or five races, each of...
CHICAGO, June 12.--R.J. Waters, an attorney, noticed last Monday that the name of his son Arthur was not in the list of the graduates from the preparatory department of the Chicago ...

VINCENNES, Ind., June 13.--Frederick Groteguth, who killed his wife on June 4, has made a confession of his crime to the Coroner. He says he is nearly 66 years old; that his wife had been quarreling with him for years, and he had told her he would kill her if she did not quit.

DETROIT, Mich., June 13.--The custom of the Chinese Government to present its exhibit at international fairs to some leading institution of the country in which the fair is held led President Angell and a few friends of the Michigan State University to petition the Chinese Government to present its New-Orleans exhibit to the university.

WEST POINT, June 13.--Up to a certain point graduation days at the Military Academy are as much alike as two peas in a pod. Innovation is steadily resisted by hidebound tradition. The same platform, draped in the same colors, is always put in the same place beneath the shady branches of the same oaks.
The Semiroo Mountain, the largest and most active of the Javanese volcanoes, was lately the scene of an eruption on a grand scale.

When a clever young novelist like Mr. Crawford makes mistakes through too great precipitancy, as in "The American Politician," a silly book, and "Dr. Claudius," a disjointed as well as ridiculous performance; when he writes "To Leeward"...

CINCINNATI, June 13.--Society on Mount Auburn was in a ferment to-day over the announcement that Miss Mary E. Lippencott, an attractive daughter of W.J. Lippencott, a millionaire manufacturer and railroad man, had quietly left her home on Thursday morning and...

I remember on one occasion I followed in a very fast frigate (my flagship) the Emperor of Russia's yacht Livadia too near to the fire of the forts of Sebastopol. I say too near, because I drew on my ship such a fire that, had I not "cleared pretty quickly out of that" I should not have been here to-day to tell the story.
On days when there are races at Jerome and Fleetwood Parks between 3,000 and 4,000 carriages cross Macomb's Dam bridge. Under ordinary circumstances hundreds of vehicles cross the bridge daily.

The terraces on Camp Washington ground, Staten Island, were well occupied by spectators yesterday to witness the lacrosse game between the New-York and New-York University teams for the metropolitan championship.

An incident that occurred at Moscow in December, 1880, affords an apt illustration of the trivial causes from which disorders sometimes arise. NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 13.--The extra session of the Legislature ended to-day. BOSTON, June 13.--The Giants from NewYork won their fifth successive game from the ex-champions to-day. They outbatted and outfielded the local players and easily won the contest. Connor's batting was the feature of the game.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 13.--Although there have been several rumors current in business circles of late regarding the management of the Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph office in this city, no definite information could be ascertained until an examination of the concern's books was made by the Assistant Superintendent and auditor of the company, who arrived in town yesterday.

The United States man-of-war Powhatan, Capt. Beardsley, arrived yesterday from Cartagena, by way of Key West, and anchored off Quarantine. She was the only United States vessel at Cartagena during the greater portion of the siege of that fortified town of the Colombian rebels.

TORONTO, June 13.--The Conference of the Methodist Church, which is assembled here, has investigated the case of the Rev. Thomas S. Keough, one of its members, against whom there was a charge of immorality. They found the charge sustained by evidence, and decided to-day to strike his name off the roll and take his appointment away from him. He was expelled from the Conference.

ERIE, Penn., June 13.--Mrs. Marion Kerschner committed suicide this afternoon, making the fourth violent death in her family within four weeks. First, her husband's head was cut off by a locomotive, and then her child was crushed to death by the hearse in which its father's corpse was being carried to the grave. Her father's drowning was to-day supplemented by her own poisoning.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 13.--United States Marshal Gross and Detective Baner returned from Versailles, Ky., to-day, bringing with them Alonzo Fuget, one of the best-known and most skillful counterfeiters in the country. Fuget's record covers pages of books in the Government's Secret Service, and he has produced some of the most deceptive currency ever issued.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., June 13.--The fron manufacturers met again to-day in conference with the workmen and accomplished nothing. The men were firm, and would not make the slightest concession. The manufacturers offered a compromise, which was rejected after a discussion of seven hours. The conference committees will meet again on Tuesday by request of the manufacturers.

CINCINNATI, June 13.--The expectation of a still more serious war in passenger rates from this point east, mentioned in a dispatch to THE TIMES two days ago, has been realized a little sooner than was predicted, and to-night it seems quite unavoidable.
ELIZABETH, N.J., June 13.--The funeral of Chevalier G.F. Secchide Casali was held at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in this city this afternoon. The Rev. F.M. McAllister officiated.

BALTIMORE, Md., June 13.--The Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company has filed an application in the United States Circuit Court here for a Receiver for the Rapid Telegraph Company, against which it holds a mortgage for $3,000,000. PHILADELPHIA, June 13.--The Cooper's Point planing mill and box factory, at Point and Elm streets, Camden, N.J., was destroyed by fire between 12 and 1 o'clock this afternoon, together with some adjoining property. About 20 employes narrowly escaped with their lives.

The third of the series of Association matches for National Guardsmen was shot at Creedmoor yesterday. The attendance was rather slim, owing, probably, to the nearness of the camping season. NYACK, N.Y., June 13.--A probable case of hydrophobia is creating considerable excitement in the village of Piermont, four miles south of this place. The subject of the disease is a young man named Andrew Dorfner, 19 years of age.

FALL RIVER, Mass., June 13.--Information was received yesterday that Bishop Hendricken had decided to reopen the Notre Dame French Catholic Church, at which there has been so much trouble recently, with the Rev. M.P. Cassidy as Pastor.
WASHINGTON, June 13.--Among the discharges noted to-day is that of Aaron Bradshaw, who was a member of the Board of Appeals in the Pension Office, who gave way for Gen. John Rogers, of Kansas.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., June 13.--Leading officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company state to-day that representations which have been repeatedly made that they intended to withdraw or had given notice of a withdrawal from the trunk line pool are utterly without foundation.

WASHINGTON, June 13.--T.O. Bullock, of Bullock Co., of New-York, will on Monday make an argument before Assistant Secretary Fairchild against the decision of the Appraiser in New-York by which broken rice is held dutiable at 2 cents a pound, instead of 20 per cent. ad valorem.

NEWARK, Ohio, June 13.--The brakemen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad are out on a general strike. The trouble is not on account of wages, but simply the result of a reduction of forces on freight trains.

CITY OF MEXICO, June 13, via Galveston.--Advices from Leon state that on the night of June 8 a tremendous waterspout broke a few miles above the town of Paso de Cuarenta, situated 20 miles from Lagos City. The flood was great and sudden.

Brisbin, Ninth Cavalry, to report to the commanding General Department of Missouri is amended so as to direct him to report to the commanding General Department of the Platte for assignment to station and to join his regiment.

HULETT'S LANDING, N.Y., June 13.--The steam yacht Galatea was successfully launched to-day in Lake George at Baldwin. She has been rechristened " Mary Anderson."

Circles within circles of benches were arranged about the music stand at Battery Park last evening in anticipation of the first concert of the season until there was seating room for about 1,000 people.

In the suit of Louise Schafer-Lafond against William Ernest Jetzkewitz a verdict was rendered yesterday in favor of Jetzkewitz. Mrs. Lafond asserted that Jetzkewitz had fraudulently Converted to his own use a paper he had given her in Riga, Russia, as security for 18,000 rubles she had loaned to him and which she had placed for safety in a box in his safe.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., June 19.--Mrs. Wagner, wife of George Wagner, an old drawing room car conductor, was found dead in her home this afternoon. She had accidentally fallen from a chair, breaking her neck.
The testimonial benefit to Mr. J.W. Collier, one of the managers of the Union-Square Theatre, will take place at the Academy of Music next Wednesday afternoon and evening.

GALENA, Ill., June 19.--Three hard characters, who robbed a store at Black Earth, Wis., a few nights ago, were tracked by armed citizens to a railroad cut near Cross Plains, suddenly pounced upon, and ordered to hold up their hands.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19.--The suspension of David S. Thompson, stock broker, was announced to-day.

Col. W.B. Johnston and daughter, Miss Mary Ellen, left Macon Saturday night for a trip to London, England.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19.--The Cornell University crew won the Childs Cup in the race with the University of Pennsylvania crew, over the Shawmont course, on the Schuylkill River, this afternoon.
WINNIPEG, June 19.--Gen. Middleton's Bear hunt is proving an ignominious failure. Big Bear still remains at large, with the troops having a wild goose chase all over the country after him.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, June 19.--Max J. Wieser, mailing clerk of the San Antonio Post Office, has been arrested by Special Inspector Dice, charged with purloining registered packages.

James Burns, J.J. Kane, James J. Hogan, John Tracey, Patrick Welsh, Thomas Conners, and Dennis Tracey, after spending a night in the Yonkers lockup, were arraigned before Judge Pentz yesterday morning charged with being disorderly on Ashburton-avenue and interfering with the police.

William Lent, the Chairman, and John P. Kelly, Secretary of the Committee of West Shore bondholders, appointed at the Windsor Hotel meeting, have issued a circular in which they say that the committee has been active in watching the interests of the bondholders and will continue its watchfulness until the rights of the bondholders are fully secured.
CHICAGO, June 19.--Every employe of the City Government has been requested by Mayor Harrison, through the various chiefs of departments, to hand in a written resignation.

GREENEVILLE, Tenn., June 19.--The State closed the rebuttal testimony in the Johnson murder case this afternoon. Argument begins to-morrow and will probably take up three days. Letters of Mrs. Johnson confessing her guilt to her husband were read to-day and produced quite a sensation.
The Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, in connection with the Brooklyn Bridge, is the acknowledged most direct and quickest route to Manhattan Beach, Sheepshead Bay, Brighton Beach, Canarsie, or Rockaway.

An unusually attractive girl, well dressed and refined in manner, was led into Justice Widman's court, in Newark, yesterday. She was Ella Brown, a resident of Brooklyn, and had been arrested to answer a charge of grand larceny, made by Christian Maurer, her uncle.
Herman Kipp, the 5-year-old Newark boy who was stricken with hydrophobia on Thursday, died yesterday afternoon after suffering the most intense agony.

We ran across an old New-Hampshire farmer last week in one of our rambles who had lived 65 years on the farm where he was born. He "guessed" he had about 500 acres of land, a large share of which is mountain pasture.

RICHMOND, Va., June 19.--Judge Bond, of the Circuit Court, has entered a decree in five suits brought by taxpayers who have tendered coupons in payment of State taxes, perpetually enjoining the defendant Treasurers from levying upon, selling, or returning as delinquent the property of complainants, or taking any other steps to collect taxes.

WHEELING, West Va., June 19.--For several weeks reports have been circulated of starvation and distress in several counties in the southern and central portions of this State, and the people have been represented to be in need of immediate relief from abroad.

BOSTON, June 19.--It has transpired here to-day that a prominent person high in the confidence of financiers is at work securing subscriptions to the bonds for the construction of the proposed new bridge over the Hudson River at "Storm King."

The Hon. S.S. Cox has purchased the ground fronting 31 feet on New-Hampshire-avenue and running through to Twentieth-street, containing 3,102 square feet. The price was $12,000, which is a trifle less than $4 per foot. This ground adjoins on the south the property recently owned by Mr. Cox on Dupont Circle.

DALLAS, Texas, June 19.--State Senator Terrell, of Kaufman, whose veracity is beyond questioning, is authority for some very remarkable utterances recently made by Congressman John H. Reagan, of the Second Texas District.

BOSTON, June 19.--James T. Fanning, familiarly known all over the country as an impersonator of Uncle Tom, but now a brokendown man, was, at his own request, sent to the House of Industry to-day for six months on a charge of vagrancy. The old actor asked that his dog be allowed to go with him, and the request was granted.

FREDERICKSBURG, Va., June 19.--On May 5, 1882, Capt. Edward Melson, commander of an oyster schooner, and his colored mate were found murdered on board the vessel in upper Mochodic Creek, in Prince George County.

The proposed voluntary liquidation of the Union National Bank--one of the oldest and most prosperous banking institutions in the State--is meeting with strenuous opposition from some of the heaviest stockholders.

BOSTON, Mass., June 19.--Class Day at Cambridge to-day well maintained the tradition of Harvard College. This is the graduates' day, pure and simple, with which the college authorities have little formally to do except to throw open the hospitalities and let the Seniors say their parting farewells and greet their friends in their own way. Nature could not have been kinder.

A game law having been recently passed which makes it a misdemeanor to sell striped bass from Jan. 1 to the 20th of May, some of the leading wholesale and retail fish dealers in New-York were asked by a representative of THE TIMES to give their opinion in regard to this law.

The racing to-day at the Sheepshead Bay track promises to be the most brilliant of the meeting thus far, for, with the exception of the 2-year-old race, the fields are large and made up of very fast horses, and so equitably weighted as to puzzle the student of racing form.

MANCHESTER, June 19.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market is weak. Cloths are selling at the lowest rates. India and China shirtings show the most weakness. Good makes are firm. Finishing cloths are fairly steady. Yarns are dull, with small sales and but little change in prices."

Clitho Moderati, a teacher of singing, got a judgment against tenor Harry Hilliard, in the City Court. Being unable to collect it by execution, he obtained an order directing the singer to appear for examination in supplementary proceedings. Hilliard did not appear, so counsel for Moderati procured from the court an order adjudging him guilty of contempt of court and fining him $100.
AUSTIN, Texas, June 19.--An important decision by the Court of Appeals of the State of interest to local option advocates is published.
MOUNT MCGREGOR, June 19.--Again Gen. Grant's day did not begin until noon. The family also made up for a broken night by rising late. The entire night had been an anxious one for all.

The broken roof stone of the Washington Monument was placed in position to-day without difficulty. Ropes were stretched around the top of the monument, and by driving wedges between them and the solid masonry and gently tapping the broken stone with a maul it was pressed into place and fitted nicely.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., June 19.--The Mount Nebo well is reported by a prominent oil scout to be through the sand and into the slate and dry. This caused the boom this afternoon on the oil market. Oil is selling here this evening at 83 cents and every one feels bullish.
A patient was removed from Bellevue Hospital a few days ago to the reception hospital at the foot of East Sixteenth-street, under the belief that he had the cholera.

OTTAWA, June 19.--The Government will give notice in the official gazette to-morrow of the discovery of a dangerous rock which threatens vessels navigating the upper lakes and Georgian Bay. The rock is situated two miles from the northeast extremity of Cape Smith, Georgian Bay, and lies under 13 feet of water.

TORONTO, June 19.--The New-York and Toronto Association Football Clubs played a game by electric light here last night, which resulted in favor of the latter by a score of 2 goals to 1.

LIMA, June 19, via Galveston.--Official telegrams from Chicla state that Gen. Caceres asks for a suspension of hostilities.

LONDON, June 19.--It is now known that upward of 160 persons were killed by the explosion in the Pendlebury Colliery, near Manches ter, yesterday. The chamber in which the explosion occurred is so filled with debris that thus far only 45 bodies have been recovered.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 19.--Last evening the family of E.F. Blakely, of this city, consisting of three children and a servant, were poisoned by drinking milk from a diseased cow. None of them will die, but two are very ill.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 19.--Pupils of city grammar schools, comprising a chorus of 1,050 voices, gave a music festival in Music Hall this afternoon.

SHARON, Penn., June 19.--Thomas O'Day was shot and killed by his son John this evening. John had been drinking heavily, and returning home with a shotgun killed the family cat. His father reprimanded him, when he picked up the gun and shot him in the abdomen. Death was almost instantaneous.
TORONTO, Ontario, June 19.--Alexander Somerville, "The Whistler at the Plow," was buried yesterday afternoon from an old shed, having died two days previous under deplorable circumstances.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., June 19.--It was definitely settled this afternoon that the miners' strike at Jeddo was over. All the strikers have accepted the company's terms and signed the agreement.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 19.--The body of Orson S. Murray, who died at his home in Warren County, Ohio, on Tuesday, arrived here this afternoon for cremation, in charge of his son, Charles Murray, editor of the Cincinnati Price Current.
ST. ALBANS, Vt., June 19.--Daniel Barnet's barn, in the town of Georgia, was burned yesterday. His mother-in-law, Mrs. Allen, aged about 60 years, was burned so badly that she died soon after.

O'Malley, a prominent physician of this city, and the proprietor of a drug store, was arrested here this afternoon by United States Marshal Barring, charged with taking Government stamps from cigar boxes and placing them on other boxes filled with cigars. He was held in $500 bail to answer.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 20.--The Supervisors of Westchester County having refused to obey the order of the Governor to provide means for abating the nuisance existing at Mount Vernon, the State Board of Health has notified the Executive of that fact. LANCASTER, Penn., June 20.--Jacob Zullinger, aged 14 years, was drowned in the Susquehanna River at Columbia this morning. He was employed at the Susquehanna Rolling Mill and went into the river to swim before working hours. The water here is deep and swift, and Zullinger either went beyond his depth or was attacked by cramp and sank. His body has not yet been found. Zullinger leaves a widowed mother.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 20.--The Wasson Car Wheel Works assigned to-day to Hon. H. Clay Evans. The unsecured liabilities are $17,617.25; unincumbered assets, $20,040.83. These are the largest car wheel works in the South. Mr. Evans will continue the business for the company for nine months and then dispose of the assets to the best advantage.

Merchant is one of the principal stockholders. The first edition under the new management made its appearance today.

WASHINGTON, June 20.--The body of Dr. Thomas O. Hills, Jr., of this city, was found lying in the grounds south of the Executive Mansion at an early hour this morning. In one of the pockets of the dead man was a note addressed to his father saying he was tired of life, being unable to longer stand the agony of the illness (Bright's disease) with which he suffered. Sun-burned and weary, the members of the Twenty-third Regiment returned to Brooklyn yesterday after their week of camp life at Peekskill. The trip down the Hudson on the steamer Long Branch was without incident, as every man sought a soft spot upon going aboard and fell asleep from sheer exhaustion.

RICHMOND, Va., June 20.--Counsel for Thomas J. Cluverius, who is under sentence of death for the murder of Fannie Lilian Madison, presented an affidavit to the court to-day tending to prove an alibi for the convicted man.

NEW-YORK, June 20.--You invite your best friend to make you a visit, and look forward to the good times you will have with him, and he comes and stays three months longer than you expected, and you grow tired of him. He may not wear out his welcome, but he becomes monotonous.
VALPARAISO, June 20.--The Hon. W.R. Roberts, the new American Minister to Chili, arrived here to-day by the steamer Mano.

TORONTO, Ontario, June 20.--A special cable dispatch to the Globe from London says: "The prospectus of a new Canadian Government loan was issued to-day through Glyn, Mills, Currie Co. and Baring Brothers. The amount of the loan is 4,000,000 and the minimum price is placed at 99 per cent. Subscription lists will remain open until the 29th inst. The circumstances for the issue of a loan of this character are regarded as very favorable.

MADRID, June 20.--The official reports of the march of cholera in Spain for the past 24 hours are as follows: In Madrid--New cases, 3; died, 1. Valencia (city)--New cases, 18; died, 14. Valencia (Province)--New cases, 249; died, 124.

MOBILE, Ala., June 21.--Lee Irwin, a popular young man, son of L.F. Irwin, proprietor of the Cherokee Cotton Mills, was drowned in Hooper's Creek, this afternoon. He died while saving the life of a companion.
WASHINGTON, June 21.--The President has not yet offered the Collectorship of New-York to anybody. He has not yet taken the matter up for final consideration, ...

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Capt. J.M. Marshall, Assistant Quartermaster, has been relieved from duty at St. Paul, Minn., and ordered to duty in the Department of Dakota. The following Assistant Engineers in the Navy have been detached from collegiate duty and ordered to hold themselves in readiness for sea service: W.F. C. Hasson, William S. Sample, William M. McFarland, W.F. Durand, and J.M. Whitman.

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 21.--A sad drowning case occurred at the dam in the James River, near this city, this afternoon. J.B. McLamore, bookkeeper of a wholesale grocery firm here, while bathing waded into a deep hole, sank, and did not rise at all. All efforts to recover the body have failed.

Singleton Rice, a negro, 30 years of age, who claims to come from Savannah, Ga., where he was a steamboat fireman, was arrested last evening on suspicion of having killed Frank Peterson by striking him on the head with some blunt instrument during a fracas on the 24th ult.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 21.--Alexander Bolton, Frank McConnell, and J.H. Consadine, members of the police force, were arrested tonight on the charge of killing R.H. Schreiber, late of Milwaukee, at 2 o'clock this morning. Eight or 10 shots were heard on Collegestreet, and persons who ran to the spot ...

Just before midnight a thousand or more discouraged and disconsolate New-Yorkers, who started away yesterday morning on a pleasure excursion up the Hudson, were wandering around in the dreary shades of Iona Island with little prospect of getting home in time for an early breakfast.

PARIS, June 8.--In the days of Horace Maecenas was a protector of poets. In this nineteenth century, when bards and troubadours are as numerous as sand grains on the seashore, Maecenas extends his patronage.

It is not many years ago that the officers of the associated banks of the city of New-York were discussing with much care a proposition made by some of the most conservative as well as eminent of their number to agree among themselves to offer no interest to depositors.
PORT AU PRINCE, June 9.--The paper currency is causing a panic, drafts being at 45 per cent. against it.

The big elephant at Coney Island was astonishingly hungry yesterday. Six days of comparative famine had braced up its digestive faculties to a marvelously healthy condition, and its two shining eyes gazed eagerly over the crowded beach in search of prey.
Inoculation for yellow fever is still being prosecuted in the San Antonic barracks, Orizava. Thirty-six soldiers of the Vera Cruz garrison have been treated by this prophylactic method.

OTTAWA, June 21.--As a result of being denied the right to negotiate her own commercial treaties, Canada has now to wait until permission can be obtained from Windsor Castle before her Government can approach the Government of the United States on the subject of either a renewal of the fishery treaty or an arrangement by which reciprocal trade relations may be established between the two countries.

The Mexican Typical Orchestra gave its first public concert at the Star Theatre last evening. The programme of music interpreted Friday and referred to in this place on the morning following, was rendered once more, and with excellent results in respect to applause.

MONTREAL, June 21.--For some time past the volunteers have been complaining of the defective ammunition served out to them by the Government, and yesterday afternoon some of the crack shots of Montreal determined to test it with English ammunition.

NORFOLK, Va., June 21.--Jacob Butler, the negro who shot and killed Samuel Griffin at Yorktown two weeks ago and escaped from the officers while being carried to jail, was rearrested at Seawell's Point, Norfolk County, yesterday afternoon.
READING, Penn., June 21.--The home of Jacob Wasson, at No. 115 Carpenter-street, was the scene of a domestic tragedy this morning. Mr. Wasson is a hard-working mechanic.

WINNIPEG, June 21.--The Manitoba Department of Agriculture has issued its first bulletin of the season, based on returns from 500 correspondents.

Mr. Phelps's performance at the Man-- sion House last Wednesday was an earnest that he is not behind Mr. Lowell in the American capacity for after-dinner speech-making, which appears to be the chief and most useful function of a United States Minister in this country.

EL PASO, Texas, June 21.--The jewelry store of Dendorz Libro, in Zacatecas, Mexico, was broken open and robbed of $15,000 worth of jewelry on Thursday night. The authorities have no clue to the robbers.

RALEIGH, June 21.--The Morganton Star reports a marvelous escape from instant death which throws Robert Odlum's exploit in the shade.

EASTON, Ponn., June 21.--President Knox, of Lafayette College, delivered the Baccalaureate sermon to the graduates this morning. The attendance of strangers is large, but there is a notable absence of Alumni. The graduating class numbers 56. This evening the Rev. Dr. Robinson, of the Memorial Church, New-York, preached the annual sermon before the college Young Men's Christian Association.

ST. LOUIS, June 21.--Advices from Northern Texas are to the effect that serious trouble is looked for in the Panhandle over the driving of Southern Texas cattle through Kansas.

Although many of the most noted roadsmen have disappeared from St. Nicholas-avenue and the King's Bridge road for the Summer, the number of horsemen at the grounds of the NewYork Driving Club during the forenoon yesterday was quite large.

The golden sword which the Emperor of Russia has presented to Gen. Komaroff, and which has just been completed by M. Kleiber, a St. Petersburg jeweler, is described as being a very magnificent weapon indeed.

ELKHART, Texas, June 21.--The prophecy of last night was fulfilled at 2 o'clock this morning, when five of the black fiends who participated in the outrage and murder of young Mrs. Randolph Hazell were taken out and hanged.
CAIRO, June 21.--The Suez Canal has been reopened to traffic. LONDON, June 21.--The French squadron has arrived at Alexandria.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., June 21.--Michael Kline and his brother Nicholas, young men, quarreled with their companion, C.D. Phoenix, this morning, when Michael stabbed Phoenix just above the heart, inflicting a wound which will prove fatal. The brothers have been arrested.

A singular case recently occupied a court martial at Marseilles. The prisoner, a Sergeant-Major named Ebrard, absconded some time ago, having embezzled a large sum of money, fled to Monaco, where he soon spent the whole of the amount, being, in the meantime, condemned to 30 years' penal servitude and 30 years' police surveillance.
Yesterday was Policeman Kane's first say in the Railroad-avenue "hoodlum" region, in Jersey City, his post having just been changed to that locality.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 21.--Denis Kearney announces to-day his intention to run for Governor of the State next year on the Workingmen's ticket. The chief plank in his platform will be that municipalities have the right to regulate workingmen's hours of labor. He says he will make a six months' campaign and adds: "It will be the most magnificent campaign ever witnessed in California, and I will be elected, too."

St. PAUL, June 21.--Specials to the Globe show a strong sentiment in Central Dakota against the Sioux Falls Constitutional Convention called for September, and against the division on the forty-sixth parallel. Both the parties are pledging delegates to vote against the division on any basis. It is believed that the sentiment is so strong that a sine die adjournment will be forced almost immediately on assembling.

The widow of the late Rev. Glazen Fillmore, for over 50 years an eminent minister of the Methodist church in Western New-York, and known as "Father" Fillmore, is still living, in a serene and beautiful old age, at her home in Clarence.

JOLIET, Ill., June 21.--Louis Bachus, the man who shot and killed the seducer of his daughter in Chicago last April, and who was sent to the penitentiary on a four years' sentence for the crime, was restored to liberty on Gov. Oglesby's pardon on Saturday. The wife and children of Bachus had been to see the Governor and their pleadings for his release were successful.
There were 102 prisoners arraigned before Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning.

SARATOGA, June 21.--James H. Darrow, 70 years old, formerly of Saratoga and now a resident of New-York, accidently shot himself this afternoon while attempting to shoot John P. Freeman, of this town.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 21.--The Baccalaureate sermon at Hobart College at the sixtieth annual Commencement was delivered this evening in Trinity Church, Geneva, by Assistant Bishop Potter, of the Diocese of New-York.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 21.--The Cornell University four, fresh from their victory over the University of Pennsylvania crew at Philadelphia, arrived at Lake Quinsigamond this morning. The crew was out for a practice spin this afternoon, and, although the water was unusually rough, rowed over the course in fine style. Charles Courtney is to coach the crew preparatory to the intercollegiate race on July 4.

MADRID, June 21.--King Alfonso having determined to visit the cholera infected districts, although the Ministry threatened to resign if he did so, immense crowds gathered on the streets on Saturday and made a demonstration in favor of the King and Queen as against the Ministry and municipal authorities.

VENICE, Ill., June 21.--Daniel Price, a fish dealer, was stabbed in the left side to-day by an unknown Frenchman. After the affray the assassin ran to his boat, and, jumping over board, hung on by one hand while his wife pulled out into the Mississippi and went below defying the town Marshal an braving a volley of bullets.

LONDON, June 22.--Mr. Gladstone and his colleagues had a short conference yesterday. The Daily News, in an editorial on the political deadlock, says: "The alternative is simple. Either Lord Salisbury must form a Cabinet and the Liberal leaders be controlled by public opinion, or Mr. Gladstone must return to office."

A group individuals exercising the lucrative profession of exiles of the 2d of December have petitioned the Ministry of the Interior for an indemnity for attending Victor Hugo's funeral. The demand is signed by 14 men, who claim a right to compensation from the Government "for having been disturbed in their occupations."

LYNCHBURG, Va., June 21.--At 4 o'clock this morning at Thomas Store, Campbell County, William Atkinson and Peter Gillian, both colored, when leaving a church fair, which had been in progress all night, quarreled as to which should accompany a girl to whom both were paying attention.

QUEBEC, June 22.--A telegram from Cape Race to the Signal Service Superintendent today reports that the German steamer Grasbrook, Capt. Schwaner, laden with glass, iron, and spirits, from Antwerp for Montreal, went ashore at Seal Cove, near Cape Ballard, on the southeast coast of Newfoundland, Sunday afternoon, during a dense fog. The crew were saved, but the vessel and its cargo will probably prove a total loss.

RACINE, Wis., June 22.--Late this afternoon an aged widow set fire to her residence, locked all the doors, and going into the cellar hanged herself. The fire was readily extinguished by the Fire Department. When found by the firemen the widow was dead. It is supposed that she was insane.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22.--A cricket match between teams representing Harvard and Haverford Colleges was played at Haverford today, and resulted in an easy victory for Haverford, who had a full inning to spare. Two members of the visiting team were absent, and only nine men batted in each inning.

LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., June 23.--Thomas Jordan, one of the most prominent young men of this county, died under peculiar circumstances to-day. A note was found in his effects written on the back of a prescription which called for strychnine. The note said: "Please bury me, and let everybody go away rejoicing. Oh, how I hate to leave the Sunday school. Oh, how I love every scholar, Farewell." Religious frenzy drove him to suicide.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 23.--Sixty thousand quarts of strawberries came into this market from within a radius of 10 miles of the city today. This is the largest receipt ever known in one day. The sales were at from 3 to 6 cents a quart.

PARIS, June 25.--All accounts received from Tonguin show that the ravages of disease among the Freneh troops there are simply appalling. Three thousand invalided soldiers have been sent home. CITY OF MEXICO, June 26, via Galveston. --The recent and unexpected decree funding the outstanding obligation against the Government in a twenty-five-million-dollar issue of bonds has had the effect of making the money market tighter than ever. The National Bank on Tuesday stopped all discount business, a step that has been generally followed by brokers.

CHICAGO, June 26.--The authorities in this city are taking active measures to ward off the introduction of cholera in case it reaches the United States.

LEWES, Del., June 26.--Olaf Olsen, of Arendal, Norway, a cabin boy from the bark Nat, from Cienfuegos, for Philadelphia, died this afternoon at the hospital from well defined yellow fever. A sailor from the same bark is convalescing. The Board of Health of the town of Lewes adopted stringent resolutions to-day concerning eommunication with the hospital employes and all persons connected with the infected vessel.
TROY, N.Y., June 26.--Vice-President Hendricks arrived at Pittsfield at noon to-day as the guest of James W. Hull.

HOPKINSVILLE, Ky., June 26.--Jordan Taylor, colored, was hanged to-day at 12:30 practically in public, as several thousand people, mostly colored, could see into the inclosure from the surrounding hills. He was baptized in the river yesterday in the presence of hundreds. He bassed a restless night, but laughed and joked this morning.

WASHINGTON,June 26.--It was announced positively this afternoon at the White House that the President would not appoint a Collector for New-York this week, and perhaps would take several days to consider the matter before deciding upon a candidate.

MONTREAL, June 26.--In the case of the Scribner Company, of New-York, whose consignments of the Encyclopaedia Brittanica were seized, the Minister of Customs has allowed the books to be released from detention on a deposit of the full duty claimed being made pending a fair and full investigation.
Susan Cotton, an Englishwoman, 32 years of age, was a prisoner at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, having been arrested on Thursday night on a charge of bigamy.

Alonzo Follett, the note broker and banker, who failed disastrously in 1882, had in his possession several notes made by the firm of Boorum Pease. Two of them, representing $10,000 he conveyed to George I. Seney, who discounted them at 10 per cent. The notes were passed by Seney on to H.B. Claflin Co., and that firm sued Boorum Pease.

SCRANTON, Penn., June 26.--The trial of Thomas Munley, who is charged with the murder of John Morrow, was begun here to-day in a crowded court room. The killing of Morrow took place in the town of Archbald, about nine miles from Scranton, on April 7.

CHICAGO,June 26.--The Hazeltine sale of paintings, which has been in progress here this week, has so far netted $78,200. With the exception of $12,000 which was paid by E.P. Allis, of Milwaukee, for Troyon's "Sunshine and Shadow," this sum came from the pockets of Chicago art lovers. A.A. Munger, who bought $46,000 worth of paintings, paid $35,000 for Meissonier's "Violette."

TROY, N.Y., June 26.--The Court of Appeals to-day affirmed the decisions of the Oyer and Terminer Court and the General Term in the case of John Horace. Jones, who murdered his wife in this city about a year ago. The death sentence will again be passed upon him next Monday.

When a TIMES reporter called at the office of the Taylor Committee of West Shore Bondholders, in the Continental National Bank Building, yesterday morning, he found several bondholders there waiting their turn to sign the agreement committing their interests to the care of the committee.
PARIS, June 26.--M.De Freycinet, Minister of Foreign Affairs, has issued a circular to the powers suggesting that they join in an endeavor to solve the Suez Canal problem.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 26.--The Kappa Alpha Fraternity of Hobart College held its annual banquet and reunion at the Kirkwood tonight. Fifty guests sat down to a generous repast. Senator Hammond, the Hon. Jonathan Childs, the Rev. William Bishop, and President Potter were among those present.

MOUNT MCGREGOR, June 26.--The smiling and expectant faces of his entire household greeted Gen. Grant as he came out on the cottage porch a little after 11 o'clock this morning. He was dressed for a drive. His longing took that form yesterday, and while treating him this morning Dr. Shrady had interwoven into his pleasantries the promise that if the General would be good he might go to ride after breakfast.

Canadian dispatches indicate not a little irritation because of a trifling balance against Canada in the fisheries matter. Both Governments have undertaken to postpone enforcing the penal and restrictive laws regulating fishing upon the coast until the season of 1885 is ended.

The Toledo, Ann Arbor and North Michigan Railway Company has executed a contract with a wealthy syndicate in this city to acquire and construct 42 miles of track from South Lyons to Owasso, Mich., thereby connecting its Northern and Southern Divisions.

NEW-LONDON, June 26.--The Yale oarsmen anticipated a hard contest with Harvard, and their warmest friends were not free from a fear of possible defeat, but no one expected such a doleful display of courage and strength as the wearers of blue made in the university race on the Thames to-day.

The deficit in the bank amounts to about $170,000.

The third day's play in the open tournament of the Far and Near Club, at Hastings-onthe-Hudson, was productive of some of the finest double tennis playing ever seen. Beekman and Taylor, who won the doubles at the Orange tournament, won yesterday, but only on the fifth set. The fine service of Taylor and the volleying of Beekman in the last game fully merited the frequent applause of the onlookers.

The four years' term of William H. Robertson as Collector of the Port of New-York expires to-day. He leaves the office with a clean record, and certainly no Collector ever left the affairs of the office in better shape. Judge Robertson's administration of the Custom House has won praise from importers, merchants, ship owners, and others for its honesty, its fairness. its dignity, and its uniform courtesy.
A recent book upon "Congressional Government" has had the effect of directing attention to the fact that the work of Congress and of our Legislatures is actually done by committees.

CHICAGO, June 26.--Judging from present indications, the Washington Park Club race meeting, which begins in this city to-morrow, will be one of the finest held either in the South or West this season, there being 500 horses now at the track, while the city is filled with strangers from all sections of the country.

TORONTO, June 26.--Hanlan, the oarsman, announced to-day that he would give an exhibition on Toronto Bay to-morrow of a new invention, by which he is able to walk on the water. The invention, which, it is understood, is his own, consists of large galvanized tin shoes filled with air. Considerable curiosity and interest has been awakened to see a trial of these shoes by the ex-champion.

The Metropolitans won their contest with the Baltimore team on the Polo Grounds yesterday. They hit the pitching of Forman, a new man, hard. Brady led in the work with the bat. He made four hits, one of them for two bases. His work with the ash was instrumental in winning the contest.

LANCASTER, Penn., June 26.--William B. Carman, express agent on the Harrisburg express train due here at 8:10 o'clock, was unfortunate this morning.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 26.--The Mexican Associated Press party arrived here this morning from Kansas City.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 26.--In the contest for the Richmond Cup at the State Sportsmen's tournament to-day the Audubon Club, of Buffalo, won by a score of 57 out of a possible 60. The Genesee Club, of Rochester, was second, with a score of 55; the Onondaga Club, of Syracuse, third, with 52; the Monroe Club, of Rochester, fourth, with 49 and the Queen City Club fifth, with 47.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 26.--Counsel appointed by the Government for the prosecution of Riel arrived here this evening. They will proceed West to Regina immediately, where the Riel trial will take place as soon as possible. The charge will be treason-felony, the only punishment for which, if he is found guilty, is hanging. Riel is confident that he will be given his liberty.

WASHINGTON, June 26. 1885. The work of placing lightning rods on the roof of the Washington Monument has been completed. It is thought that all danger to the monument from lightning will now be averted.

BOSTON, June 26.--The Rev. Dr. Joseph T. Duryea, of this city, who has just been elected President of Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., has not decided whether to accept the position or not. He said to a reporter to-day that the offer was tempting, as it afforded great opportunities, and it would be something to be backed by 4,000 Alumni of any institution of learning, as he was assured he would be by those of Union.

GREENVILLE, Tenn., June 26.--Dr. R.M. Cohen, a traveling oculist, was married the other night secretly to Miss Annie Paton, a highly respected young lady of this place. ITHACA, N.Y., June 27.--The mangled remains of the 17-year-old son of ex-Alderman Patrick Shannon were picked up at the base of the Ithaca Falls to-night. While going through the Ithaca gorgo be lost his balance, and, falling over a hundred feet, struck the falls in his descent and was picked up from the pool below with his legs driven up into his body.

IONIA, Mich., June 27.--The west-bound night express on the Detroit, Lansing and Northern Railroad ran into an open switch at Stone Quarry, four miles east of here, last night. The engine was ditched and Engineer Dolan seriously injured and the passengers greatly terrified. The switch had been opened and the lock and lamp stolen. It is believed that the intention was to wreck the Forepaugh Circus train, which was following the express.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 27.--The census enumeration of Des Moines proper, now nearly finised, will show a population in round numbers' of 36,000, and of the adjacent suburbs of nearly 4,000 more, a gain of 18,000 since the Federal census of 1880. All the cities of Iowa show fair to flattering gains. The State enumeration is likely to reach 2,200,000, a gain of 600,000 in five years.

A well dressed woman, with a two-hundred-dollar violin, played in up-town streets wits a strolling German band yesterday. She seemed to be the leader, and sent a boy around to collect pennies thrown from windows. People smiled at the novel sight, and felt for their purses. At a restaurant where a shower of dimes fell on the pavement the woman sang an Italian song in a harsh contralto voice, playing her own accompaniment.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 27.--The Buffalo Cremation Society has just purchased a lot near the cemetery and will erect the finest crematory temple in the country. A contract has been made for the apparatus with Joseph Venini, of Milan, Italy. The crematory will be ready for use about the 1st of November.

Forty-five hundred parsons witnessed the Metropolitans defeat the Brooklyn Club on the Polo Grounds--yesterday. Although the score was one-sided at the termination of the game, the contest was a rather interesting one.

OTTAWA, June 27.--Mr. J.C. Forbes, the Canadian artist who was attacked with a severe hemorrhage at the nose some days ago and who has suffered severely since, is improving. His physicians anticipate a speedy recovery.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27.--It was altogether the bowlers' day in the match between the Merion and Staten Island Cricket Clubs today at Ardmore. The visitors won by the score of the first inning, although if they had sent their men according to rule in the second they would have been easily defeated.

NEW-BEDFORD, June 27.--The amateur champion double scull race between C.C. Tilton and W.S. Sheehy, of New-Bedford, and William and Frank Wood, of Fall River, was rowed in working boats here to-day. The distance was a mile and a quarter, with a turn. The Fall River representatives won by a length in 13m. 28s.

WASHINGTON, June 27.--Secretary Whitney had invited a party of friends to take a trip to Mount Vernon this afternoon, and the proposed excursion was in the nature of a novelty, as it was announced to be made on a chartered steamer at the expense of Mr. Whitney, instead of on a Government ship at the expense of the taxpayers of the whole country. Rain and muggy weather spoiled the excursion.
