Collector Robertson received a telegram from Secretary Manning early yesterday morning, asking him to continue to perform the duties of the office until his successor qualified. Judge Robertson's commission as Collector lapsed at 12 o'clock noon.

BOSTON, June 27.--The Hon. Charles Francis Adams is seriously ill at his residence in Quincy. He has been in poor health for the past two or three years and has now, it is said, completely last control of his mental faculties. His condition to-day is reported as quite critical.

MONTREAL, June 28.--The religious ceremonies connected with the celebration of the festival of St. Jean Baptiste were held at the Church of Notre Dame to-day. Bishop Fabre celebrated high mass.

MONTREAL, June 28.--D.D. McTaggart, of the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association, ran a mile at the Bankers' Sports, in Toronto, yesterday, in 4:38 1-5, beating the best Canadian amateur record by 2 seconds.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, June 28.--The ninety-first Commencement of Williams College marks the close of an interesting and progressive year. The changes in instruction have given all the satisfaction that could be desired. Dr. Woodbridge has tried his first year as Professor of Anatomy and Physiology, and Mr. Lefavour as Instructor in French and Mathematics. Mr. Lefavour will teach another year.

Never an adept in small talk, Valentine Baker grows more silent as the years pass. When he does thaw into conversation it is in the company of his intimates--the presence of mere acquaintances would freeze him. The only man who could properly draw out Baker, unloosen his tongue for him, set it merrily wagging to the accompaniment of smile and twinkling eye, was his fast and loyal friend Col. Fred Burnaby.

CHICAGO, June 28.--The assignment of J.V. Jones Co., lumber dealers, of Racine, Wis., has been rendered void by reason of the fact that the time of the court commission had expired before whom the Assignee acknowledged his bond. A fearful Crime has been perpetrated. On Wednesday Mrs. Andrea Rodriguez de Banda was on her way from Ecatepec to Tianepantla, near this city, in a coach. The coach was stopped and she was murdered. It is supposed the object of the murder was to destroy a will which the lady was taking to Tianepantla to sign. The will provided for the disposal of her property.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 28.--Lieut.-Col. W.T. Gentry, of the Twenty-fifth Infantry, commanding officer at Fort Snelling for a year past, died to-night of Bright's disease. He was 53 years of age, a native of Centreville, Ind. He was a graduate at West Point in the Class of '56, and was an aide-de-camp to Gen. Meade during the last war. He leaves no family.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 28.--The liquor and beer saloons and the drug and candy stores here were open to-day in opposition to the new ordinance passed by the Board of Commissioners last week. The restaurants were also kept open.

PITTSBURG, June 28.--On Tuesday the green glass bottle factories will close down, to remain shut until September. This is the regular Summer vacation. One of the workers stated this evening that if a dispute on the wages question occurs next season a compromise will be made, so as to virtually shut out all importation of green bottles.

OTTAWA, June 28.--It is evident from reports reaching here that the fishermen of the maritime Provinces are not going to allow the terms of the understanding recently arrived at between the United States and Canada regarding the Dominion fisheries to be carried out without entering their protests in some formidable way.

Hollingsworth, who has held the office for many years. Mr. Dodge is about 35 years of age, and is a clerk in the Riggs Bank in this city.

BOMBAY, June 29.--It is reported from Cabul that Isa Khan, supported by Russian allies, has risen against Abdullan Khan. Isa Khan marched upon Khana-i-Bad and seized the treasure there, valued at a million pounds sterling, and belonging to the Ameer of Afghanistan.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29.--Over a thousand men went to Pastime Park this afternoon to witness an advertised wrestling match between Joe Acton, of this city, and Carl Abs, of Germany. Posters had been spread about the city announcing that England would be pitted against Germany for the Championship of the world and $1,000. The match was set down for 4 o'clock.

CLINTON, N.Y., June 29.--The McKinney prize debate took place at Hamilton College last evening before a large audience. The question for discussion was "Is the abolition of the contract labor system in our prisons for the best interests of the State?" Prof. Henry A. Frink presided.

For many years the short, slim figure of Thomas O'Shea, better known as "Tommy the Piper," who earned a livelihood by playing the bagpipes in the streets, has been familiar in South Brooklyn. Tommy is known as a goodnatured creature, not overburdened with brains, by almost every resident in that part of the city.

WASHINGTON, June 29.--A delegation of representatives of the various American steamship lines called on Postmaster-General Vilas to-day to reargue the claim for the distribution of the $400,000 appropriated by the last Congress for carrying the United States mails.
